IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Many infants exposed to opioids before birth due to use of these drugs by the mother develop Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (NOWS). In this project, our center (the Regional Neonatal ICU at the University of Alabama at Birmingham) will join other centers in doing a clinical trial on infants to identify the best medicines that can be used to treat infants who develop Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome. Our center has much experience in participating in similar multicenter studies, and will be able to enroll many newborn infants with opioid withdrawal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: HABS-HD OVERALL SUMMARY By 2060 the U.S. will become largely “non-white” with 15% of the population being African American and 27.5% being Hispanic (65% of which are Mexican American). African Americans currently have the highest burden of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) while Hispanics will experience the greatest increase in AD by 2060; however, our understanding of the factors that contribute to these health disparities remains very limited. HABS-HD is conducting the first-ever comprehensive simultaneous study of the biological, medical, environmental and social factors, all within a health disparities framework, to understand the factors that contribute to AD risk over adulthood across the three largest racial/ethnic groups in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to investigate the ethical, social, and policy implications of a new kind of genetic information currently available to the public: polygenic scores for educational attainment (EA-PGS). The proposal includes a research plan to 1) qualitatively investigate individuals who have received EA-PGS results via direct-to-consumer (DTC) genetic testing, 2) quantitatively investigate how exposure to EA-PGS research in popular media influences attitudes about educational disparities in the US, and 3) develop an ethical framework on the potential harms and benefits of EA-PGS. The proposal includes a career development plan for the PI to complete training and coursework in qualitative methods, quantitative methods, and bioethics.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smartphone-based education and remote self-monitoring are scalable solutions that can address unmet information needs and address poor care coordination, anxiety, and caregiver burden among older adults transitioning home after major surgery. This proposal outlines the development and refinement of the myPOSH intervention, a digital health solution to support the needs of older adults undergoing major surgery and their care-partners. The findings from this work can be scaled and spread to increase the value of care provided for a variety of health conditions and will drive future efforts to improve transitions home after major surgery.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Scalable Digital Communication Intervention to Support Older Adults and Care-partners Transitioning Home After Major Surgery

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Regular physical activity is associated with reduced risk of several diseases important to Veterans, including cardiovascular disease and diabetes, and is associated with better mental health. Walking is a safe and effective way to get the recommended amount of physical activity. Unfortunately, more than 1 in 3 Veterans over age 45 meet the definition of physically inactive. Behavioral economics suggests that our inability to start and stick to an exercise routine may be the result of “present bias,” which is a tendency to value the immediate reward of remaining sedentary over large rewards of long-run physical activity. Patient incentives may overcome present bias by moving the rewards for healthy behaviors forward in time. In the proposed study we will determine the optimal design for an incentive program that gives Veterans tangible, timely rewards for walking a target average number of steps per day. If effective, an incentive program may be an economical way to improve Veterans’ physical and mental health without taxing the healthcare delivery system.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Periviable birth is among the leading causes of infant death and childhood disability, with disproportionate impact in low-income and minority communities, and although relatively rare, the CDC estimates that extremely premature deliveries result in societal costs exceeding $26 billion dollars annually. To optimize high-stakes periviable counseling encounters, we propose to test, in a multisite, randomized controlled trial, a decision support intervention (i.e., Periviable GOALS DST) developed by our research team to facilitate informed, shared decision-making regarding neonatal resuscitation among women who present to labor and delivery at periviable gestations (from 22 0/7 to 24 6/7 weeks gestational age) and their physicians. The proposed work stands to improve the quality of periviable care by enabling more informed and patient-centered decisions, and our results will have immediate clinical relevance because the regional and institutional diversity of our trial sites, which improves generalizability, allowing for broad application and dissemination of the tool.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Promoting Shared Decision Making in Periviable Care: A randomized controlled trial of the Periviable GOALS Decision Support Tool

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Over 10 million people worldwide live with Parkinson’s Disease (PD) - the world’s second most prevalent neurodegenerative disease: PD’s economic cost is ~$14.4 billion in the U.S. alone. Here we launch ENIGMA’s Worldwide Parkinson’s Initiative - the largest and most highly-powered neuroimaging investigation of PD - pooling data from 21 cohorts from North America (US), South America (Brazil), Europe (Netherlands, Belgium, Italy, Austria, Switzerland, UK), Asia (China, Taiwan, Japan), Africa (South Africa) and Oceania (New Zealand). Using global data to offer unprecedented power, we will identify genomic, interventional, and environmental factors that consistently impact disease severity and progression, supporting the development of personalized treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The ILLUMINATE study promises to produce a greater understanding of coping behavior as a key mechanism of action in the linkages between social isolation, loneliness, and alcohol use/misuse. Possessing greater understanding of this interplay will open important new avenues for developing and implementing more effective, contextually valid prevention and intervention efforts for substance use and misuse with the potential for substantial public health impacts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer neoantigens are important targets of cancer immunotherapy. Neoantigen vaccines have generated great enthusiasm as a potential safe and effective strategy to induce/enhance the immune response to pancreatic cancer. We have obtained funding to test optimized neoantigen vaccines in a window trial in pancreatic cancer, and propose preclinical and human translational studies to assess the mechanisms of response and resistance to neoantigen vaccines in pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extreme resistance to chemotherapy is one of the major factors that underlies the poor prognosis of pancreatic cancer. Using an unbiased protein array analysis, we have identified a novel mechanism of resistance governed by MK2 kinase, that when overcome, renders chemotherapy effective. In this study we propose to conduct a phase 1 clinical trial combining a novel MK2 inhibitor ATI-450 with FOLFIRINOX chemotherapy for patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer and to develop a novel immunotherapeutic strategy that can be tested in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes poses a major health threat in the US, and there is a disproportionate burden of diabetes among African Americans. However, the environmental and/or genetic reasons remain incompletely defined. Our goal is to use novel technologies to study blood chemistry to identify those most at risk so that preventive interventions can be made as early as possible – and to improve our understanding of the underlying disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Signaling between tumor cells and their host environment that results in enhanced tumor cell survival via diverse mechanisms, growth and promotion of invasion into other tissues. Most cancer victims succumb to their disease because of the size of the tumor and/or metastases to different organs. This CoBRE will 1) increase our mechanistic understanding of the interaction between the tumor and its environment, 2) position junior faculty for success by improving competitiveness for extramural support through diverse training opportunities and specific mentoring strategies and 3) support critical infrastructure for the projects of focus in the current application but also to recruit additional tumor microenvironment focused scientists to West Virginia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the increased risk of cervical cancer for women living with HIV, access to cervical cancer screening in Nigeria is limited. We will leverage existing HIV treatment infrastructure in Nigeria to integrate cervical cancer control activities into the successful MoMent (MOther MENTor) peer-based HIV support program. Using implementation science frameworks, we will implement and evaluate the sustainability of the adapted MoMent HIV + Homebased Cervical Cancer program to advance cervical cancer control in Nigerian women living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite widespread recognition of the benefit of having more than one mentor for success in biomedical research, the roles and types of mentors important for early career researchers is not well-understood. This application will identify and test patterns of successful mentorship networks to enhance biomedical research outcomes and close mentoring gaps for trainees from underrepresented backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical lack of individuals from under-represented segments of the US population in the toxicology workforce and the Society of Toxicology (SOT) is pleased to serve as a partner in the Toxicology Mentoring and Skills Development Training (ToxMSDT) Program that has a purpose to mentor high undergraduate students from underrepresented groups to build a pathway for toxicology research and workforce. Together SOT and the ToxMSDT will establish a sustained network of toxicology students, researchers, and professionals committed to expanding toxicology mentoring and career opportunities for underrepresented segments of the US population. Thus, contributing to the development of a diverse toxicology workforce in solving toxicology-related health issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke is a leading cause of death and disability globally and in the United States for both women and men, and sex differences in both risk factors and stroke incidence have been consistently demonstrated. We lack, however, a detailed understanding of pathways by which alterations in sex hormones contribute to stroke risk in women and men, knowledge that could help to inform improved, more personalized stroke prediction and prevention. Our planned project will use the biologic footprints (genomic, epigenomic, and metabolomic data) of individuals in national and international prospective cohort studies to advance our knowledge of the critical role of sex hormones in stroke risk in women and men across the lifespan, enabling more personalized approaches to stroke prevention and improved brain health in the population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Membrane proteins represent about 25% of the human genome (~5,000 genes). Of these, about 1700 transmembrane proteins are localized on the plasma membrane (PM) (9% of the genome) and they constitute 60% of the existing FDA-approved drug targets. Understanding the endocytic dynamics of surface receptors are fundamentally important in designing more effective therapies, and the receptors studied in this proposed research will provide new insights in understanding the key drug target for a number of inflammatory and autoimmune diseases in particular.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE While reproductive-age women with rheumatic diseases and their children are at strikingly high risk of adverse pregnancy and perinatal outcomes, little is known about how patient- and health services-level variables (e.g., low patient knowledge, inadequate health services receipt, nonadherence to anti-rheumatic drugs) contribute to these outcomes. As women who make informed pregnancy decisions and have the ability to execute these decisions likely experience better reproductive outcomes, I will develop a novel clinical intervention to enhance pregnancy decision-making and planning in the rheumatology clinical setting. I will also develop a prospective longitudinal cohort of young women with rheumatic diseases to advance understanding about how reproductive knowledge, family planning care receipt, and other key patient and health services variables change over time and predict adherence to anti-rheumatic drugs— which we hypothesize is a critical intermediate factor in the pathway to adverse pregnancy and perinatal outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With improved treatments, the vast majority of children diagnosed with cancer are now cured. However, premature cardiovascular disease has become the leading non-cancer cause of death among childhood cancer survivors. Using an adaptive study design, the proposed trial seeks to determine if various innovative intervention strategies can help childhood cancer survivors improve their physical activity and dietary habits in order to reduce their long-term risk of early cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes mellitus (DM) and hypertension (HTN) are two prototypical vascular diseases that ultimately lead to capillary dysfunction, capillary closure, ischemia and vision loss. Current clinical methods and diagnostics for staging these diseases are neither effective in detecting the earliest capillary changes nor in detecting incremental capillary changes (improvement or worsening) in later stages of the disease. The successful outcome of this proposal will develop and implement novel SD- and SS-OCTA based technology in human subjects to identify novel biomarkers of capillary loss or closure in DM and HTN to improve the diagnosis and management of disease by allowing direct evaluation of capillary changes and ischemia in a clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Liver transplantation is the only treatment for the tens of thousands of patients suffering from liver failure in the U.S., yet thousands of potentially transplantable livers are discarded each year. The ability to preserve donor livers, and organs in general, could eventually be life-saving for hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of people around the world. To help overcome these barriers, we have developed a nature inspired, holistic solution to dramatically extend organ preservation times which has the potential to immediately make accessible lifepreserving liver transplants for emergency cases, while facilitating widespread banking of all types of organs and tissues in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Activity of most genes in mammals are controlled by transcription factor proteins, which activate and suppress their target genes via epigenetic regulation without changing the DNA sequence. This regulation is best modeled by network models with directed edges from transcription factors to their target genes and many developmental processes and complex diseases are associated with dysregulation in these networks. In this proposed research program, we will develop a set of frameworks to model transcriptional regulatory networks at the cellular level with epigenetic data and use them to discover key regulators and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rates of obesity for Black adolescents are among the highest of any racial or ethnic group in the United States, and loss of control over eating (LOC; being unable to control what or how much one is eating) confers greater risk for the development and maintenance of excess weight. The goal of the present study is to use a synthesis of qualitative data and ecological momentary assessment to understand the social contexts in which LOC occurs in Black adolescents, and specifically to probe the association between racial discrimination and LOC. This innovative research project has the potential to inform culturally-adaptive treatment and prevention programs that address both obesity and LOC and are effective in racial and ethnic minority youth.

PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to advance technology to monitor dietary intake in support of precision nutrition, which is important in managing many chronic conditions. An innovative combination of insertable and wearable devices with advanced computational methods is proposed to enable continuous or “on-demand” measurement of several metabolites and use them as nutritional biomarkers for estimation of macronutrient intake.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Relevance Statement): Endometriosis affects ~10% of childbearing-age women and 35–50% of women with pelvic pain or infertility. Despite advances in medical treatment, there is no cure for this disorder. We propose a novel therapeutic approach based on magnetic nanoparticles that can specifically accumulate in endometriotic lesions following systemic administration and eradicate the disease by generating therapeutic temperatures (> 43 0C) inside the lesions upon exposure to the external magnetic field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Targeted Neural Text Summarization of Electronic Medical Records to Improve Imaging Diagnosis Relevant information from a patient's medical history is essential to allowing specialists (such as radiologists) come to accurate diagnoses; unfortunately, this key information is often buried in the unstructured clinical notes within patient Electronic Health Records (EHRs), making it difficult to find and draw upon to inform diagnosis. We propose to design and evaluate novel Natural Language Processing methods that provide focussed extractive summaries of the text within patient EHR to aid radiologists performing imaging diagnosis and counteract the cognitive biases of radiologists (while our focus is on radiology, the proposed approach will generalize to other specialties, providing a potentially novel and impactful means for domain experts to better harness EHR to improve care). We will assess whether and how these automatically generated summaries affect diagnosis in a pilot user study, providing insights into how (interactive) machine learning models might influence clinical practice.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Leveraging novel population-representative survey and time diary data collected during the COVID-19 pandemic and the co-occurring period of intense racial trauma from the NICHD-supported National Couples’ Health and Time Study (NCHAT), the only fully-powered, multi-method study of American couples that includes fully- powered samples of racial and ethnic minorities and sexual minorities, the current study aims to identify mechanisms underlying gender, racial and ethnic minority, and sexual minority disparities in parenting stress and parental well-being. As part of the Social, Behavioral, and Economic Research on COVID-19 Consortium Coordination Center (SBECCC), the NCHAT data, the contextual data on structural racism, sexism, and heterosexism produced for this project, and the NCHAT survey items for harmonization will be shared with the SBECCC and the wider health research community to enable further understanding of the health and well-being impacts of the pandemic for underserved and vulnerable populations in particular.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: B. PROJECT NARRATIVE Resistance training is a popular exercise modality for individuals across the lifespan and of all body types; however, the role of resistance training on measures of cardiovascular and metabolic disease is not known. This research will 1) develop and validate an epidemiological instrument to collect resistance training volume, 2) assess the effect of resistance training volume on estimates of insulin resistance and blood pressure, and 3) determine the optimal ratios for physical activity for improved estimates of insulin resistance and blood pressure. This research has to potential to inform future tailored intervention studies to target specific measures of cardiovascular and metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although teen dating violence (TDV) is a major public health problem with serious consequences, we and others have shown that it can be prevented. The current study will test whether the seventh-grade version of an evidence-based TDV prevention program (Fourth R) is effective in the long-term reduction of the perpetration and victimization of physical, psychological, and sexual TDV. The study will also test whether a text-based booster session administered five years after the intervention will enhance the long-term effectiveness of Fourth R in reducing TDV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Despite well-intentioned efforts, there has been a decline in the numbers of researchers in neurological disorders from ethnic and racial groups historically underrepresented in science. The goal of this project is to develop an innovative longitudinal approach to recruiting and retaining talented underrepresented individuals among graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and early stage investigators. This program will ultimately create a sustaining network of researchers contributing to increased diversity and novelty of thought to solve the human problem of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal genes have important effects on offspring development, but few studies to date have identified how variation in these maternal genetic loci alter regulatory processes and shape developmental outcomes. This project uses a unique model system to understand how genetic interactions between maternal background and offspring genotype influence embryogenesis and ontogeny. Maternal genetic effects impact development in humans through gene-by-gene and gene-by-environment epistasis, and this project contributes to our understanding of how these processes affect human health and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Glycans, complex carbohydrates that bind to proteins, are regularly analyzed by electrospray ionization (ESI) – mass spectrometry (MS). The goal of this proposal is to provide a molecular perspective on how ESI affects the glycan and protein structures that are analyzed by MS. Ultimately, this work will enable the validation of these MS-based methods and generate new analytical methods for characterizing these molecules, which are important in cell biology, disease progression, and pathogen infection.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Kentucky ECHO-Pediatric IDeA Research Center (KE-PIRC), as part of the ECHO IDeA States Pediatric Clinical Trials Network, will continue to make it possible for 1) rural and underserved infants, children and adolescents to participate in clinical research; 2) junior investigators to be trained in clinical research and community engagement, improve the health of both children and adults in Kentucky through this research, and develop their academic career; and 3) the development of a regional network of partners to sustain this clinical research initiative. The five primary focus areas are 1) pre-, peri- and postnatal outcomes; 2) neurodevelopmental; 3) upper and lower airway disease; 4) obesity; and 5) positive health. These primary focus areas are highly prevalent in Kentucky, therefore the efforts of the KE-PIRC in collaboration with our community partners will improve the health outcomes of Kentucky children and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CSUF/UCI-CFCCC Cancer Health Equity Research Partnership (CHERP)  Cancer Research Education Program (CREP): Narrative The Cancer-Related Education Program (CREP) will contribute to the enhancement of cancer health equity in Southern California. CREP will promote an increase in the diversity of the cancer research workforce by training undergraduate and master’s graduate students in cancer health disparities-related research efforts, especially those from underrepresented groups. CREP will provide cancer and cancer health disparities education to undergraduate and master’s students. CREP will also include several outreach activities at CSUF and UCI to disseminate information about the program and the importance of cancer research and cancer disparities. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This multicenter clinical trial will examine whether the use of an antiviral drug called ganciclovir can safely and effectively prevent reactivation of a common virus called cytomegalovirus and improve clinical outcomes in adults with sepsis-associated acute respiratory failure. If this study shows a clinical benefit, routine use of this antiviral drug could become standard therapy to improve the outcomes of adults with prior exposure to CMV and who have sepsis-associated acute respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity and its metabolic sequelae place severe medical and economic burdens on the United States, and adipose tissue plays a central role in these pathologies. The proposed research aims to understand the cellular compositions and cell-to-cell interactions of thermogenic adipose tissue. The results will improve our knowledge of the regulation of thermogenic metabolism and may ultimately lead to new therapeutic approaches for the treatment and prevention of obesity and metabolic diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Pathways to Cancer Research Renewal attracts underrepresented and economically disadvantaged students to science, inspires them to pursue research careers, and supports them as they advance professionally. Increasing diversity among researchers brings new perspectives that stimulate innovation and that ensures future cancer researchers will represent the communities they serve, including populations disproportionately impacted by cancer. This renewal has a special emphasis on two areas of need identified by the NCI: the role of computational biology in current and future research and the importance of working with communities to address health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Adiponectin has morphed into a widely-used biomarker reflecting the health of adipose tissue and systemic insulin sensitivity. Understanding the cellular and systemic physiology of adiponectin and its receptors has proven invaluable for a better understanding of the role of the adipocyte in systemic metabolic homeostasis. The experiments outlined here will not only focus on novel adiponectin fragments that act inside the cell, but will also focus on the role of adiponectin in non-adipocytes, particularly the cells of the proximal tubules in the kidney and in hepatic stellate cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The role of the pancreatic b-cell is to secrete insulin in response to glucose. Defects in this process can result in inadequate insulin secretion causing diabetes or excessive insulin secretion causing hyperinsulinism. The goal of this project is to understand how the same mutations in the transcription factor HNF1a can cause both of these opposing diseases through disruption at different points along the insulin secretion cascade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed R36 application seeks to examine how police officers in Baltimore City, Maryland, are responding to drug policy reforms and the broader cultural shift away from punitive responses to substance abuse that are associated with negative health outcomes for people who use drugs (PWUD) in favor of evidence-based public health approaches rooted in harm reduction. Through in-depth interviews with 20 senior officers of the Baltimore Police Department (BPD), observation of 15 public-facing BPD events, and 60 observations of street-level officers in the form of ride-alongs with patrol and detective units, this research will qualitatively explore the way BPD leadership integrate harm reduction approaches to drug enforcement into the department’s organizational approach toward PWUD, and street-level officers’ beliefs, attitudes, and enforcement practices towards PWUD. Findings will inform ongoing debates over drug policy and the role of law enforcement in harm reduction, as well as identify barriers and avenues for widespread and enduring police reform that facilitates police enforcement practices that are in alignment with, not antithetical to, public health.

PHR: Project Narrative Low back pain that continues beyond three months is not well understood. Reasons, why this pain persists, may be due to the body's reaction to this initial painful event. Identifying these reasons that individuals have low back pain could lead to new treatments to prevent chronic LBP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  A paradigm of molecular evolution and biophysics is that proteins adopt regular three-dimensional shapes necessary for their cellular functions, yet recent studies of intrinsically disordered proteins support that protein dynamics contribute to both functional plasticity and evolvability over millions of years. The goals of this R35 MIRA are to integrate high throughput mutagenesis screens with biophysical assays and the development of new deep learning models to understand how rapid evolution shapes molecular dynamics and interfaces. These questions will be explored using species-specificity of fertilization as a model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The current countermeasures against arsenical-induced toxicity are chelating agents of arsenic and are not effective and highly toxic. We recently reported that Bromodomain 4 (BRD4) inhibitors can significantly improve the severe cutaneous injuries caused by phenylarsine oxide (PAO), an arsenical surrogate that demonstrates similar pathophysiological alterations in the skin and other organs that are caused by other warfare arsenicals. The proposed effort will be focused on the development of orally/topically active hybrid inhibitors of BRD4, RIPK3 and IL6 that lead to the development of a novel and highly effective treatment in reducing arsenical-induced cutaneous inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Pathologically altered affective learning is at the core of nearly every psychiatric disorder. Despite this, little is known about the patterns of neural activity or pathways that are engaged when learning is enhanced or diminished by varying task demands. Using a combination of behavioral tasks, neurophysiology, chemogenetic, and computational modeling approaches this project will establish the specific pathways and mechanisms through which affective learning can be altered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The ability to reproduce clinical aspects of human heart disease in cellular models using induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) has enormous potential for drug discovery. Realizing this potential, however, has been hampered by the lack of sophisticated tools to read out disease-relevant parameters and relate drug effects to alterations in disease processes. The proposed project will deliver reagents and software to evaluate genes, proteins and drugs for disease-modifying activity in iPSC models in a user-friendly, accessible manner suitable for drug discovery in the biopharmaceutical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transfer RNAs (tRNAs) are the universal adaptor molecules essential for protein synthesis in all living cells and their coordinated and accurate processing is critical to ensure production of a high-quality tRNA pool. Mutations in the human tRNA methyltransferase enzyme Trm10 are associated with a multi-faceted disease phenotype that indicates important functions for Trm10. This project will uncover how diverse Trm10 enzymes modify their specific tRNA substrates and the biological effects of the modification they introduce, to define the role of Trm10 in maintaining optimal cellular health and as a potential novel target for therapies for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related changes in the vitreous can cause retinal detachment, which often leads to permanent vision problems that affect quality of life. The goal of this project is to find out why the vitreous changes with age, so that ways to prevent vitreous aging can be developed to prevent retinal detachment in high-risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-invasive cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) is a quantitative, clinical assessment of the integrated functioning of the neuromuscular, cardiovascular and ventilatory systems under the stress of exercise. It uses combined pulmonary gas exchange, electrocardiography, blood pressure and pulse oximetry to identify functional abnormalities and inform diagnosis and prognosis. This study develops a novel modified CPET protocol and reference values that enriches the clinical utility of CPET by independent assessment of neuromuscular system performance (weakness, fatigue, limitation), at rest and peak exercise, in combination with standard CPET measurements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Cleveland Alzheimer's Disease Research Center (CADRC) is a collaborative effort amongst Northeast Ohio physicians and scientists from Case Western Reserve University (CWRU), Cleveland Clinic Foundation (CCF), MetroHealth Systems (MHS), University Hospitals (UH), and the Louis Stokes Cleveland VA Medical Center (LSCVAMC) to improve our understanding of why Alzheimer's disease (AD) and Alzheimer's disease- related dementias (ADRD) vary from person to person. The CADRC will create an infrastructure to increase the speed of research efforts of local, national and international investigators and to train the next generation of investigators. Ultimately, the CADRC will contribute to a more individualized treatment approach for individuals suffering with aging-associated brain disorders such as AD and AD-related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Providing the education community and students with knowledge of the various health professions and multiple ways to reach these professions is a critical need of public health. In addition, an understanding of the various social impacts on health (Social Determinants of Health) and use of data science tools modeled after Precision Health’s use of large data will inform teachers and students of how these tools may inform healthcare. PATHS will use a culturally relevant lens to develop curriculum materials and deliver professional development designed to support teachers and their students and will provide an array of supports for community-engaged projects such as health fairs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Because older adults with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) have a 2-fold increased risk of clinical bone fracture, the project is relevant to public health by measuring the effect of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors on bone metabolism (bone density, bone turnover, and bone quality) among older adults with ADRD. In line with several NIA priorities including multiple comorbidities and care for adults with ADRD, the study will focus on fracture risk factors among older adults with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Subcutaneous injections of protein-based therapeutics enable home administration and reduce the load on the healthcare facilities and healthcare costs. However, the injectability of protein-based formulations at the necessary high concentrations for injection cannot be determined at early stages of drug development due to a lack of material and still has high time and material costs at later stages. Our technology addresses this by allowing the measurement of viscosity at shear-rate ranges relevant to injectability and manufacturability using very small volumes of formulations. This technology will enable prescreening and optimizing proteins for injectability during early stages of drug development and reduce the risk of scaling, and the associated costs, of uninjectable proteins. In the long-term, the availability of this technology is expected to increase the number of injectable protein-based therapeutics to address patients needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) use and adherence among Black men who have sex with men (MSM) is hampered by structural and psychosocial barriers, resulting in inadequate coverage to reduce HIV infections among this population. We will conduct a randomized control trial (RCT) with a standard of care (SOC) waitlist control to determine the efficacy of C4, an intervention based on self-determination theory, to increase PrEP use and adherence among Black MSM. The findings of this trial will result in an intervention tailored for Black MSM which can be implemented in community setting to increase PrEP use and adherence among Black MSM.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Environmental exposures profoundly shape lifespan health and disease trajectories. The ECHO Measurement Core will advise, orchestrate, and frame the coordinated, sensitive measurement of exposures, developmental processes, and health outcomes central to achieving ECHO's objective of mapping the impact of early exposures on child health and development. We will develop and refine measures for the ECHO Cohort Protocol (ECP), including methods to implement the measures that are culturally sensitive and valid for diverse populations, assist the ECHO Consortium in implementing and evaluating the ECP, and we will lead strategic decision-making and operational strategies to incorporate new and revised measures to advance ECHO Cohort science while minimizing participant and staff burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper segregation of chromosomes during mitosis is essential for genome integrity and cellular viability. Despite chromosome segregation being a fundamental biological process, the DNA and proteins that make up the segregation machinery (i.e. the centromere) rapidly evolve. This proposal studies the functional consequences of rapid centromere evolution on genome integrity during early embryogenesis and how they might contribute to infertility and aneuploidy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Galectin-3 promotes insulin resistance of type 2 diabetes by interacting with the insulin receptor. GlycoMantra’s commercial goal is to develop a high-affinity galectin-3 antagonist to restore insulin sensitivity. During this funding period, we will complete the critical path preclinical studies required for our IND submission to the FDA to enable the initiation of a first–in–human Phase 1 clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: We will optimize and establish clinical-grade protocols to minimize potential assay variabilities for cell free messenger RNA sequencing (cf-mRNA-Seq). Subsequently, we will profile the cf-mRNA transcriptome of well-characterized Alzheimer’s disease (AD), mild cognitive impaired (MCI) subject samples and build and validate diagnostic and prognostic classifiers for AD. If successful, our assay may transform non-invasive diagnosis and prognosis of AD and has a potential of developing a robust and cost-effective clinical assay.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Internal tandem duplication within FLT3 (FLT3-ITD) is frequently mutated in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and correlates with poor prognosis. Mechanisms underlying the aberrant FLT3-ITD subcellular localization and signaling remain poorly understood. We discovered that FLT3-ITD is palmitoylated, disruption of which relocalizes FLT3-ITD and rewires FLT-ITD signaling, thus we propose to define the physiological and clinical significance of FLT3-ITD palmitoylation in AML and identify novel therapeutics to target FLT3-ITD+ AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Biocatalysis is revolutionizing the pharmaceutical and chemical industries, with recent advances in enzyme engineering enabling the synthesis of complex molecules with high efficiency and selectivity. However, the chemical transformations enzymes catalyze are restricted compared to their chemical equivalents, limiting their application. Herein are described two proposals to engineer two distinct enzyme classes, heme enzymes and methionine sulfoxide reductase, to expand their capabilities outside their natural function to synthesize chiral α- CF3 amines, sulfoxides, and sulfoximines, functional groups with great medicinal value.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 2 million older persons are admitted to an intensive care unit (ICU) every year; of those who survive, half will not achieve functional recovery, with profound consequences for patients, caregivers, and society. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will ascertain the unmet needs of older adults who return home (either directly or after short-term rehab) after an ICU hospitalization, evaluate the association of these unmet needs with clinically relevant outcomes, and assess barriers and facilitators to addressing these unmet needs. The proposed research will inform the development and evaluation of a subsequent intervention to improve functional outcomes among older ICU survivors, in alignment with the NIH’s mission to reduce disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabis use is common among adolescents and linked to psychiatric risks. Understanding the neural processes that predict and result from adolescent cannabis use may lead to improved interventions for cannabis use and cannabis use disorder prevention and treatment. Through this award, I will gain training in complementary big data methods and precision neuroimaging within patient intervention designs to optimize neural markers of adolescent cannabis use and provide actionable information towards future clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The spectrum of post-liver transplant (LT) cognitive impairment—from subtle attentional changes to Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD)—is not well characterized and as a result, clinicians do not screen for cognitive impairment in the post-LT setting, LT patients are not referred to specialists for timely diagnosis of their cognitive impairment, and strategies that might reduce cognitive decline are not implemented. This project will address an enormous unmet need for deep characterization of the spectrum of cognitive impairment in the LT population that has a high burden of conventional ADRD risk factors but has traditionally been excluded from ADRD studies. Furthermore, we will establish new neuro-hepatology collaborations and develop a unique cohort of LT recipients with rich cognitive data that may yield novel insights into liver- and transplant-specific contributors to ADRD in all populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Household air pollution (HAP) describes the health and environmental impacts of pollutants produced from incomplete combustion of solid fuels such as wood, coal, and charcoal that are burnt on open fires or wood- burning stoves in poorly ventilated homes and releases suspended particulate matter (PM). Exposure to household air pollution is thought to be related to worse cardiovascular and kidney health beginning in childhood and this study will examine how household air pollution increases risk for hypertension in obese children and adolescents. Understanding and identifying these children and adolescents at greatest risk for disease due to household air pollution will develop new treatments to improve their health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Up to 42% of patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) experience uncontrolled, chronic symptoms and nearly 50% demonstrate low patient activation scores. This proposal aims to improve health outcomes for patients with GERD, by harnessing patient activation and motivating behavioral change as a framework for a mobile health (mHealth) Question Prompt List (QPL) intervention. Results will develop a usable mHealth application and collect preliminary data on health outcomes to inform a future R01-funded clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative More than 200,000 patients every year are affected by malignant brain tumors and these tumors show very high proliferation with increased energy demand for their growth. The goal of this proposal is to identify the key energy sources for brain tumor growth in patients through a translational molecular imaging approach that uses non-radioactive 13C-enriched nutrients and NMR Spectroscopy. Expected outcome of this study will generate key information to develop new targeted therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To date, research has mainly focused on the participation of afferent fibers of the pelvic nerve in the etiology of bladder pathology, such as Overactive Bladder (OAB) or Interstitial Cystitis/Bladder Pain Syndrome (IC/BPS). However, the bladder is also innervated by hypogastric afferents, and little is known about how these afferents contribute to bladder function. Our project will anatomically and functionally map the peripheral fiber types and central projections of the nociceptive bladder afferent pathway in the hypogastric nerve, which could reveal the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying bladder pathology and direct research efforts to develop new drugs/devices targeting the sympathetic hypogastric afferent pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in brain function are thought to underlie the development of obesity and type 2 diabetes. Neurons located in the lateral hypothalamic area control feeding behavior, energy homeostasis, and body weight, but their role in the development of obesity is unclear. Addressing lateral hypothalamic involvement in overeating will help us understand the neurocircuit mechanisms that control diet-induced obesity and will inform future therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE In all animals, the fertilized egg undergo activation of its own genome and the regulation of the maternally deposited instructions (mRNAs and proteins). This proposal studies how the vertebrate embryos organizes multiple players to undertake these tasks, with the goal of understanding basic conserved principles of how genes are regulated that can be applied to other systems, including reprogramming of the cellular fates and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital hyperinsulinism is the most common cause of persistent low blood sugar in infants and children and is associated with high rates of neurocognitive impairment. This project will examine trajectories of neurocognitive development in school-aged children with congenital hyperinsulinism and will guide future strategies to improve neurocognitive outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to address the high rates of overweight/ obesity in Puerto Rican men, we propose a proof-of-concept study to determine if a telehealth intervention, tailored to target Puerto Rican men of varying levels of acculturation, is acceptable and feasible, and can achieve clinically meaningful weight loss. The “TeleSalud Healthy Eating, Physical Activity, and Sedentary Behavior Intervention” (TeleSalud HE-PA/SB) will consist of 4 months of twice-weekly classes on increasing HE and PA and decreasing SB, followed by a 4-month HE, PA and SB maintenance intervention. This intervention will be compared to the “TeleSalud General Health” (GH) intervention, consisting of 4 months of twice weekly telehealth classes on general health issues, followed by a 4-month General Health intervention.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of the proposed research is to produce an integrative study of the epigenetic process of caste development in ants. The research will advance our understanding of this cell-type-like differentiation process using three complementary scientific approaches: laboratory, field, and museum studies. Caste is one of the most exaggerated and robust examples of phenotypic plasticity in nature, and this research important advances in understanding the mechanisms and evolution of animal development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents with asthma have alarmingly low medication adherence rates and thus novel approaches to increasing medication adherence and subsequent asthma health are needed. The proposed research will examine how momentary-positive-affect prospectively relates to adherence and stress, and subsequent asthma health in adolescents with moderate to severe persistent asthma. Understanding these associations at the momentary level will help inform future positive affect interventions to treat asthma in adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Non-traumatic lower extremity amputations (NLEA) in people with diabetic peripheral neuropathy have devastating consequences, most notable a 3-year mortality rate of up to 71%. The highest rate of NLEA occurs in individuals with diabetes-induced end-stage chronic kidney disease, who have marked loss of bone quantity and quality and an increase in vascular calcification due to the progression of both diabetic peripheral neuropathy and chronic kidney disease. This renewal application will extend our discoveries and test the central hypothesis that chronic kidney disease-mineral bone disorder syndrome synergistically combines with diabetic peripheral neuropathy in the bone and vascular deterioration pathway to place the diabetic neuropathic foot at the highest risk for NLEA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will provide a molecular understanding of the mechanisms that control the activation of resident cytolytic T cells that mediate tissue destruction. Furthermore, our study will provide a knowledge base that will help with the interpretation of the outcome of clinical trials and identify appropriate treatment strategies to individual patients. It will have a significant positive impact on human health because it will help define curative and preventive strategies that have the potential to prevent tissue destruction in celiac disease. Thus, this work will directly support the NIDDK mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burden of human disease, and improve the health of patients with digestive disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemotherapy for primary breast cancer causes significant declines in cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) predisposing patients to increased symptom burden and increased risk of morbidity and mortality from cancer and non-cancer conditions. We propose to investigate the effects of flexible and response-adapted aerobic training (AT) on CRF response rate in patients with primary breast cancer. Results from this investigation will identify the AT regimen that maximizes CRF response rate with potential translational value to clinical cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer remains the top killer of adults under 85 worldwide, but recent advances that unleash the power of the immune system against tumors has shown impressive progress against many forms of intractable cancer, necessitating the advanced training of research specialists at the interface of oncology and immunology. The UCLA Tumor Immunology Training Program (TITP) is dedicated to mentored, interdisciplinary team-based training of a new generation of academic and industry leaders in basic, translational, and clinical research in tumor immunology. By deploying facilities and resources of a renowned immunotherapy trials epicenter that includes the NCI-designated Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center and the Parker Institute for Cancer Immunotherapy, we aim to fulfill this training mission while uncovering basic principles in host-tumor interactions and developing next-generation therapies based in fundamental tumor immunology for the betterment of cancer patients and their families.

PROJECT_TITLE: UCLA Tumor Immunology Institutional Training Grant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nigerian sexual minority men (SMM) have high rates of HIV infection and pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) uptake remains low. This project will investigate how a telehealth intervention might help improve PrEP knowledge, uptake, and adherence among SMM in Nigeria. The study will provide pertinent data to inform effective design of culturally appropriate PrEP interventions for this vulnerable group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  With each breath and across the lifespan in health and disease, the lung is under dynamic changes of mechanical force. How this force is sensed and translated into molecular cues that impact lung formation, injury repair and function is poorly understood. In this study, we will investigate the role of the cardinal mechanosensor PIEZO channels at the center a molecular feedback mechanism that controls gas exchange niche size and composition during the construction and reconstruction of the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social interactions affect the way we think and feel and impact our overall health, which makes understanding the biology of social behavior an important research topic. The neuropeptide vasopressin is an important modulator of social behavior and is predicted to impact brain circuits involved in motivated behaviors and emotional state making it an important target for study. Proposed projects combine new models with modern tools in behavioral neuroscience, cellular physiology, and neuroanatomy to discover the link between vasopressin-responsive brain regions and motivational and emotional processing during social behavior and to identify cellular mechanisms that could be targeted therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will develop new tools for real-time sensing of absolute concentrations of multiple neuromodulatory signals in the brain, using advanced one-photon and two-photon imaging. A detailed understanding of the levels of many neuromodulators and how this neuromodulatory signature changes across behavioral states is sorely lacking. Improved understanding and technology will allow testing of more sophisticated brain neuromodulation methods for improving cognitive and correction of chemical imbalances in the brain across neurologic and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Responsible for fast synaptic transmission throughout the nervous system, pentameric ligand-gated ion channels (pLGICs) are the targets of many drugs essential to the modern practice of anesthesiology and critical care medicine, but drug development in this field has been stagnant for many years. In this proposal, I will use advanced computational techniques to understand the structural determinants of pLGIC modulation via lipids, which have been suggested to have molecular mechanisms that overlap with anesthetics. The outcome of this work will be a detailed molecular model of how lipophilic species allosterically modulate pLGICs, opening new avenues for drug discovery in anesthesia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall UCSF Older Americans Independence Center (OAIC) The UCSF OAIC provides investigators a comprehensive suite of resources, mentorship, and support to advance science in our theme area, which is focused on predictors, outcomes, and amelioration of late-life disability in medically and socially vulnerable older adults. We seek to continue our superb track record of developing an interdisciplinary cadre of investigators whose research yields major, clinically impactful advances in our theme area and is ultimately translated to improving care and quality of life for vulnerable older adults with or at risk for disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory viral infections can lead to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which is characterized by detrimental hyperinflammation that damages the pulmonary vascular endothelium, causing impaired gas exchange and a patient mortality rate as high as 45%. The fundamental vascular progenitor cell(s) that restore the capillary network after influenza injury is unknown. This proposal will therefore investigate the origin and molecular regulation of a putative vascular progenitor population derived from the venous endothelium, providing a groundwork for future studies aimed at enhancing vascular repair after pulmonary injury.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many important problems in child health and development may result from a mother’s environment during pregnancy. We are a coalition of scientists in Michigan who plan to 1) continue collecting information from the 1,600 families we have already enrolled in the Environmental influences on Child Health Outcomes (ECHO) study; and 2) enroll another 540 families from diverse populations. Working together with other study groups who are part of the national ECHO program, we hope to learn what changes might be made during a woman’s pregnancy that could prevent later problems in child health and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophin lack dystrophin expression and die of dilated cardiomyopathy in the second or third decade of life. This proposal seeks to investigate whether gene therapy strategies to deliver full-length dystrophin can prevent the pathogenic progression of diseased cardiomyocytes. This innovative platform capitalizes on bioengineered hydrogels and patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells to assess gene therapy strategies that address the root cause of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Three new proteasome-targeting chemotherapeutic drugs reached the market in the past decade. Although these peptide-based proteasome inhibitors are effective against multiple myeloma, unfortunately they have not proven useful to treat solid tumors (e.g. Ovarian Cancer). Up Therapeutics is developing novel small molecule inhibitors that are not peptide-based and target a different component of the proteasome (RPN13) as drug candidates for the treatment of solid tumors, notably ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Public Health Significance Medication harm is a leading cause of injury and avoidable harm in health care systems across the world. This Patient-Driven Medication Safety Learning Laboratory in Care Transitions project will ultimately lead to the design of interventions that are highly targeted to older adults and their caregivers who are residing in some of the most marginalized communities. The interventions created through this research, from the patient perspective, will further address health equity, and will make all communities, regardless of what zip code a person lives in, healthier.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Parents of infants hospitalized in a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) experience significant trauma and chronic stress which can impair parental mental health and functioning as well as parent-infant interactions and infant development. Since NICUs are not equipped to routinely screen parents for depression, trauma and anxiety, most parents do not receive the mental health support and treatment they need to cope effectively with this experience. EmBRACE (Empower NICU – A Bridge to Resources for Adjusting and Coping with Emotions) is a novel mobile health (mHealth) application that will be developed and tested for screening and monitoring all NICU parents for psychological symptoms, and connecting them with customized referral information, support and coping strategies to optimize parent mental health and infant outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Empower NICU - A Bridge to Resources for Adjusting and Coping with Emotions (EmBRACE)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative More than one-half of patients with life-threatening infections (sepsis) have evidence of injury to the heart muscle called ‘myocardial injury’. Myocardial injury increases the risk of death, but there is currently little information to inform the best approach to evaluate or treat patients with myocardial injury during sepsis. We propose the “Informing best practices for evaluation and treatment of myocardial injury during sepsis” study to better understand and guide the care provided to the millions of patients per year with myocardial injury during sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will evaluate whether targeted respiratory muscle exercises preserve breathing function, reduce shortness of breath, and accelerate mobility after total joint replacement surgery. The proposal is relevant to public health because the knowledge learned it will increase our understanding of the impacts of surgery on breathing and could lead to improved approaches to prepare and recover from total joint replacement surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: During drug development, it is crucial to understand the clearance mechanisms, clearance rate, and any potential drug-drug interactions of small molecule drugs to ensure safety; however, the rat models currently used for this purpose are sub-optimal in terms of time, cost, and applicability to humans. Our solution to this unmet need is an integrated platform that merges a human liver tissue chip and translational software that will reduce the cost and risk associated with drug development. Successful completion of this proposal by optimizing the chip design to enhance usability, evaluating and validating different drug clearance mechanisms, and comparing Javelin’s clinical predictions to known human clearance profiles, will advance the commercial readiness and accelerate commercial adoption of Javelin’s Hepatic Clearance platform, delivering improved R&D productivity to industry and better drugs to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perception reflects a combination of sensory drive from the periphery and inputs from central brain regions. This proposal will use electrical brain stimulation to control inputs from cognitive brain areas that project to the ventral visual pathway in the human brain, and measure and model how these projections influence the representation and perception of complex visual stimuli. These studies will provide the basis for future research to design perturbation based strategies that mimic human attentional conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heterotopic ossification (HO) represents significant functional impairment, not only in genetic disorders like fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva (FOP), but also in nongenetic conditions caused by invasive musculoskeletal procedures or trauma related to burns or major blast injuries as unfortunately occurs in modern conflicts. This project will redefine FOP as a cilia-mediated disease, put forth a new paradigm of cilia- mediated HO formation, and develop potential interventional targets based on this new mechanism. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular models of biomolecular structures have led to a revolution in the way we understand and manipulate the molecules of life. However, due to limitations of current technology, large gaps remain in our understanding of the three-dimensional structure and dynamics of biomolecules and biomolecular complexes, including many critical to human health. Here, we propose to develop powerful and flexible technologies that allow researchers to measure biomolecular structures that change over time, as well as measure protein structures and complexes within mammalian whole blood.

This entails continued interagency collaboration, cooperation, and communication; maintenance and sustainment of conformance with the Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS); along with maintenance and sustainment of California’s Food Emergency Response Team. These activities are intended to further enhance California’s food safety program and its ability to respond to food and feed emergencies and better align it with a National Integrated Food Safety System.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: MI RRT Project Narrative RFA-FD-23-019 The RRT Maintenance funding support will allow Michigan the opportunity to continue enhancing the MI RRT’s integrated strategy for a sustained, multidisciplinary, multi-agency approach to protect human and animal health through food and feed safety efforts. The Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (MDARD) has, given the diversity and scope the food and agricultural infrastructure, demonstrated that rapid response capacities for food and feed emergencies are best developed through the active engagement of individuals and task forces with a wide range of expertise to protect public health, the environment, and the economy. MDARD’s compliance and conformance with the Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS) and the Animal Food Regulatory Program Standards (AFRPS) provides a solid foundation for the MI RRT and help advance Michigan’s efforts to improve consistency and uniformity with federal standards and other state RRT programs; maintain the highest-quality investigation work; establish a basis for measuring and improving performance; share data and investigational findings with partners and industry; and develop and share best practices and other resources to support state and national response capacity and capability development to improve and influence the nationally integrated food safety system protection efforts.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Rapid Response Team (RRT) Maintenance TrackMichigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (MDARD)

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Kentucky Department for Public Health-Division of Public Health Protection & Safety  Food Safety Branch  Project Narrative/Intended Outcomes RE: Development and Maintenance of Human and Animal Food Rapid Response Teams (U2F) Clinical Trials Not Allowed (Funding Opportunity Announcement (FOA) Number RFA-FD-23- 019). The primary goal of the Kentucky Rapid Response Team is to minimize exposure to foodborne illnesses in the population. To meet this goal, the KY RRT will maintain and expand the current multiagency, interdisciplinary team to assist in all hazard responses including continued upkeep and development of our state Food Complaint System. This team will continue supporting the framework by providing training to state and local partners to increase their proficiency in event response.

PHR: Project Narrative: The Indiana Rapid Response Team (IN RRT) is dedicated to protecting the health of the public through efficient and effective response to human and animal food related emergencies. The mission is to improve and strengthen interagency communication, capacity, and capabilities through continual process improvements. Through enhanced training, collaboration, relationship building, and data sharing, our goals can be accomplished, and our contribution can lead to a more robust nationally integrated food safety system.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Maintenance of Human and Animal Food Rapid Response Teams for the State of Indiana

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Over the previous project periods the Georgia Food & Feed Rapid Response Team (GA RRT) has built upon the foundation and nationally demonstrated the effectiveness, success, and impact a RRT can have on contributing toward an integrated food safety system. This project continuation opportunity will allow Georgia to continually improve, maintain, and sustain the mission and resources of the GA RRT while building mutual reliance between partner agencies and established relationships. The team will continue to operate within the RRT Capacity Building Process and Mentorship Framework while innovating new ideas, tools, and resources to improve response outcomes and prevention efforts. To meet the goals and objectives the project will focus on developing metrics, measuring success and impact of RRT projects and operations as well as communicating impact with both internal and external stakeholders.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human food and animal feed emergencies, such as foodborne outbreaks or contamination events, can result in severe illness, long-term health effects, and even death. State, local, and federal food safety agencies all have an important role in identifying outbreaks and other emergencies, and rapidly responding with the goal of protecting public health. Rapid Response Teams (RRTs) are the current best practice to ensure states have trained staff who can work as coordinated multi-agency, multi- disciplinary teams to rapidly respond to and investigate foodborne outbreaks or other human food/animal feed emergencies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RRT Maintenance Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture (PDA)

ORG_NAME: TEXAS STATE DEPT OF HEALTH SERVICES
PHR: TEXAS RAPID RESPONSE TEAM PROJECT NARRATIVE - RFA-FD-23-019 The Texas Rapid Response Team (TRRT) seeks to protect the citizens of Texas by prioritizing the safety of food, which may be compromised by various circumstances. The TRRT partners possess multi-disciplinary expertise and inter- jurisdictional authority to respond to complex foodborne illness investigations and emergency situations. The TRRT uses collaboration, information exchange, resource sharing, and relevant training to limit the adverse effects of contaminated and unsafe foods.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: TX RRT

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Narrative: Tennessee Rapid Response Team Application 2023 The Tennessee Department of Health strongly desires to continue work with the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA’s) Rapid Response Team (RRT) consortium. Since 2018 we have been a voluntary RRT member and recognize our mission is aligned with the stated purposes and objectives in the Development and Maintenance of Human and Animal Food Rapid Response Teams funding opportunity. We believe that becoming a funded RRT will improve our ability to fully develop the RRT structure, cultivating our existing outbreak response metrics. We have proposed a plan that we feel can enhance our ability to respond to human and animal food emergencies by completely enacting the FDA RRT framework in Tennessee. Our activities will foster a collaborative network between a range of programs in Tennessee and nationally.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Maintenance of Human and Animal Food Rapid Response Teams

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Minnesota RRT Project Narrative Funding provided through this Cooperative Agreement will ensure the continued development of a sustainable Rapid Response Team (RRT) that consists of expanding knowledge through data sharing, training, and exercises; strengthening the link between epidemiology, laboratory, and environmental health components of emergency response; and seeking out projects to enhance response capabilities. During this project period, the MDA RRT will conduct exercises with non- traditional response partners, complete RRT training with three FFSD inspection programs, and share project outcomes related to live animal market outbreaks, pesticide misuse data, and shopper history use impact. Continued funding will allow the MDA RRT to provide valuable input at a national level to the RRT Manual, CAT revisions, response-related procedures, and other national workgroups supporting RRT work.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Expanding Minnesota's Rapid Response Team through Outreach, Engagement, and Enhancements

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Severe and disabling abdominal pain is common in individuals with chronic pancreatitis. Although pain is associated with reduced quality of life and high economic and societal costs, there are limited effective options for pain management in this population. This study proposes an evidence-based psychological intervention approach using an internet-delivered cognitive-behavioral program to minimize the impact of pain and improve quality of life. The ultimate goal is to maximize the public health impact of the intervention with successful implementation and dissemination to pancreas clinics and to the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Among ethnic groups in the US, African Americans continue to display some of the most disparate health outcomes. This proposal will interrogate the functional effects and druggablity of under-studied gene variants related to immune and drug response within the genome of individuals of African ancestry (AAs). This project has the potential to strengthen our understanding of ancestry-related host immunity as a contributor to the biology of health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The correlation between numerous EEG features and Alzheimer’s Disease progression and fundamental biomarkers makes the EEG a compelling candidate for an early “digital biomarker” of AD. Over the past few years, our lab has made significant strides in developing advanced neural signal processing methods to enhance the precision of EEG-derived measures, facilitate more precise, individualized EEG biomarkers. Through this project, we aim to provide the AD research community with a suite of powerful, accessible signal processing software tools that will dramatically enhance the precision and quality of EEG-derived biomarkers designed to provide early detection and tracking of AD progression.

Key milestones are indicated for each objective. Each year the AZDA intends to achieve target goals to bring us closer to the overarching mission of developing a multi-agency, multi-disciplinary team that will operate utilizing Incident Command System (ICS) and National Incident Management System (NIMS) principles and a Unified Command structure to respond to HAF emergencies. We expect to effectively minimize the time between agency notification of HAF incident and implementation of effective control measures.
