IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: VA ST DEPT/ AGRICULTURE & CONSUMER SRVS
PHR: Virginia Rapid Response Team Project Narrative:  Virginia Rapid Response Team (VA RRT) was created to ensure investigators are trained and work as a multi-agency, multi-disciplinary team to promptly respond to and investigate foodborne outbreaks or other events involving contamination of human or animal food. The VA RRT is composed of a core team with members representing the Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services (VDACS): Food Safety Program (FSP), Dairy Program, and the Agriculture Commodities Program (Animal Feed), the Virginia Department of Health (VDH): Epidemiology and Surveillance (EPI), Environmental Health (EH), and Shellfish Program, the Department of General Services (DGS) state lab Division of Consolidated Laboratories (DCLS), the United States Department of Agriculture Food Safety Inspection Services (USDA FSIS) and the United States Food and Drug Administration Baltimore District /Human and Animal Food 2East (FDA HAF 2E). Membership in the VA RRT core team has been updated to include members of the VDACS Produce Safety Program and VDH Water Safety Program. VA RRT core team members meet through a weekly scheduled conference call which provides updates form each agency and program. The VA RRT core team decides how to response to each update by providing resources (sampling supplies and equipment, Personal Protective Equipment) or to activate using modified Incident Command System (ICS)/National Incident Management System (NIMS) principles and a Unified Command structure to provide a rapid and unified all hazards response to human and animal food emergencies.  The VA RRT uses the resources and partnerships developed through the cooperative agreement to continuously improve interagency communication, develop and implement established procedures for operations including joint investigations to minimize the social, economic, and public health impacts of human and animal food. Continued support of the cooperative agreement provides resources and regularly held joint training and exercises to ensure the multiagency all hazards team is properly trained and ready to complete a variety of essential task during an VA RRT activation response.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Progress of Strategies Developed and Implemented to Maintain a Human and Animal Food Rapid Response Team

The mission of the Kansas RRT is to effectively respond to foodborne outbreaks and identify potential preventative practices to protect the food supply and consumer health nationally and globally.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Kansas Department of Agriculture's Maintenance of Human and Animal Food Rapid Response Team

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Rural Americans experiencing a heart attack, called an ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI), are less likely to receive timely treatment than their urban counterparts, which exposes them to excess morbidity and mortality. Based on our team’s foundational work that identified critical gaps in STEMI emergency care, this proposal will develop, implement, and refine a smart-device application to support clinical decisions for rural STEMI care by EMS providers, which in turn will improve care timeliness and quality. Through a two-phase implementation strategy in a total of 8 rural EMS agencies, we will build and then evaluate the Rural STEMI App’s ease of use and ability to improve outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Digital EMS Point of Care Innovation to Improve Rural STEMI Outcomes

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: MASSACHUSETTS STATE DEPT OF PUB HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Through this cooperative agreement, the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, Bureau of Environmental Health/Food Protection Program will maintain conformance with the most current version of the Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS) and will support continuation of its Rapid Response Team’s (RRT) capacity to respond to food/feed incidents. The Massachusetts MFRPS Program will continue to ensure and maintain best public health practices for a high-quality regulatory program to reduce foodborne illness hazards in plants that manufacture, process, pack, or hold foods. The Massachusetts RRT Program will support and facilitate long-term improvements and innovation to the national integrated food safety system by unifying and coordinating federal/state/local human and animal food (HAF) emergency response efforts through the following: strong linkages between epidemiology, laboratory, and environmental health/regulatory programs and staff; implementation of Incident Command System (ICS)/National Incident Management System (NIMS) principles and a Unified Command structure to conduct integrated responses to all-hazards HAF emergencies; and the incorporation of training, data sharing, data analysis, communications, and development of best practices and other resources to support national capacity/capability development.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Maintenance of Human and Animal Food Rapid Response Teams (U2F) Massachusetts FPP

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The oncogenic transcription factor MYCN drives a subset of neuroblastoma tumors which is deadly in half the cases despite protracted and intense therapy including polychemotherapy and immunotherapy (anti-GD2 therapy). As MYCN remains undruggable, finding synthetic lethal relationships that may result in new treatments is one of the “holy grails” of pediatric cancer therapy. In this grant proposal, we provide evidence that amplified MYCN orchestrates a complex and intricate re-wiring of the neuroblastoma cell to 1) increase iron metabolism, 2) increase cysteine and selenocysteine biosynthesis to counteract reactive oxygen species created from iron metabolism-related Fenton reactions and 3) increase synthesis of pantothenate kinase 3 (PANK3) to subsequently increase coA levels; the result of which is the creation of a synthetic lethality and therapeutic vulnerability to ferroptosis induction which we aim to explore, clarify and translate to new therapeutic options for this recalcitrant pediatric tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OVERALL COMPONENT Alzheimer’s disease is a major cause of death and disability in the United States and the National Alzheimer’s Project Act seeks to identify a treatment or prevention for Alzheimer’s disease (AD). In order to meet this ambitious goal, the interdisciplinary Indiana University/Jackson Laboratory/University of Pittsburgh (IU/JAX/PITT) MODEL-AD Center seeks to continue generating and characterizing novel animal models of AD, assessing the relevance of these to model to human disease, and developing a precision preclinical testing pipeline through which novel therapies can be tested to greatly accelerate the process by which therapies are successfully moved forward to human AD clinical trials. Importantly, the IU/JAX/PITT Center will generate new AD modeling processes and pipelines, data resources, research results and models that will be swiftly shared via existing infrastructure at the participating institutions and through the AD Knowledge Portal, academic medical centers, research institutions and the pharmaceutical industry worldwide.

PHR: URRT- Project Narrative- 2023-RFA-FD-23-019- Development and Maintenance of Human and Animal Food Rapid Response Teams (U2F) Project Narrative The overarching goals of the Utah Rapid Response Team for this three-year project are to: Goal 1- Increase outreach,education, and training  a. Objective 1.1- participate in conference presentations  b. Objective 1.2- provide training opportunities  c. Objective 1.3- remain active through committee participation Goal 2- Coordinate outbreak response in human and animal food  a. Objective 1.1- maintain relationships with subject matter experts  b. Objective 1.2- refine and use the URRT activation criteria  c. Objective 1.3- continue to update the emergency response list Goal 3- Maintain a readiness status for emergency response  a. Objective 1.1- ensure all equipment is up to date and in good working order, including  supplies to run an Incident Command Post as needed  b. Objective 1.2- maintain proper equipment logs  c. Objective 1.3- open lines of communication with partners Goal 4- Continue long term sustainability through the Utah Rapid Response Steering Committee  a. Objective 1.1- continue monthly meetings  b. Objective 1.2- maintain steering committee members including epidemiology,  environmental health, laboratory, feed, local, state, federal, and tribal food safety experts  c. Objective 1.3- track in kind contributions to show the depth of membership involvement Goal 5- Continue to work with local, state, federal, and tribal partnerships to maintain and  improve food safety culture throughout the state of Utah  a. Objective 1.1- continue to sponsor an annual food safety conference  b. Objective 1.2- continue to be actively engaged with our state Emergency Operations Center  c. Objective 1.3- continue to support national RRT committees to improve food safety practices Goal 6- Keep our standards current and support the Manufacture Food Program, Produce, Local Health Departments, Animal Feed, and others  a. Objective 1.1- maintain Standard 3- Inspection Program (Recalls)  b. Objective 1.2- maintain Standard 5- Food-related Illness, Outbreaks and Emergency Response  c. Objective 1.3- maintain Standard 7- Industry and Community Relations

The Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services (MDHSS) proposes to not only maintain its Rapid Response Team (RRT) for food and feed to respond to large emergencies, but also to move ahead with improvements from lessons learned along with new innovations and initiatives. The Missouri RRT will add to its outreach in collaboration with local jurisdictions and other states, test and continue to apply new ideas to improve response capabilities, prevention and integration of the food safety system.

PHR: Project Narrative Environmental health professionals are responsible for expertise in a variety of subject matter areas ranging from food safety and retail program standards to emergency preparedness and response and water quality. The AEC aims to provide the most relevant in-person education and the means to connect and engage with peers to build capacity for their organizations and meet the changing needs of the communities they serve. Each AEC highlights how local agencies, industries, and levels of government work to ensure the safety of the public and environment, and how they contribute to the advancement of the environmental health profession.

ORG_NAME: CT STATE DEPT OF CONSUMER PROTECTION
PHR: Narrative The State of Connecticut has achieved project milestones for the Connecticut RRT for the period of last grant. The purpose of this grant is to maintain progress in CT’s Rapid Response Teams (RRTs) to facilitate long-term improvements and innovation to the national Integrated Food Safety Aystem by unifying and coordinating federal/state/local human and animal food (HAF) emergency response efforts including: 1) Strengthening the link among epidemiology, lab and environmental health/regulatory components. 2) Improving States' regulatory and surveillance HAF protection programs to include using Incident Command System (ICS)/National Incident Management System (NIMS) principles and a Unified Command structure to conduct integrated responses to all-hazards HAF emergencies, rapidly identifying and removing tainted food from commerce, and conducting root cause investigations to inform future prevention efforts; and 3) Addressing supporting components, such as training, data sharing, data analysis, communications, continuous process improvement, and development of best practices and other resources to support national response capacity/capability development.

The WSDA’s key performance areas will be strengthening the link among public health data and regulatory components, improving the state’s regulatory and surveillance human and animal food (HAF) protection programs to include the use of the Incident Command System (ICS), and developing best practices to support national response capacity.

The purpose of the program is to continue to provide a multiagency, multidisciplinary team to manage and respond to intrastate and interstate food emergencies that impact Maryland. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increased use and misuse of opioids during pregnancy and resulting Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (NOWS) are critical public health concerns in the United States. We will collaborate as a member of the proposed research group to design and conduct a multicenter clinical trial to directly compare the effectiveness of pharmacologic treatments for infants with NOWS. We anticipate that our studies will identify the optimal treatment for NOWS to improve the care and overall health and neurodevelopmental outcomes of infants with NOWS throughout the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Melanoma is the most serious type of skin cancer with a low survival rate at advanced stages. Here, we propose 1) developing a melanoma peptide vaccine delivery system for effective antitumor immunomodulation, and 2) testing such delivered vaccines to elicit potent, broad, and long-lasting immune responses to promote the efficacy of melanoma combination immunotherapy. The results may improve the clinical practice and outcomes of melanoma treatment. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental disorders such as Fragile X Syndrome (FXS) represent a devastating array of diseases sharing common feature, notably social dysfunction. Using a mouse model of FXS, our goal is to demonstrate how the meningeal lymphatic system is dysfunctional in FXS and contributes to alteration of neuronal circuitry and social behavior. Successful completion of this proposal will enhance our understanding of the pathophysiology of FXS (and potential other neurodevelopmental diseases) and offer new therapeutic avenues targeting the meningeal lymphatic system to restore behavioral impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Reactive oxygen species (ROS) play pivotal roles in both signaling and stress, but their transient nature makes them challenging to study in living systems. Traditionally, small-molecule fluorescent probes are used to detect and visualize ROS through fluorescence imaging; however, these probes diffuse after ROS detection leading to inaccurate measurements of ROS localization and poor signal-to-noise responses. This proposal aims to develop cell-trappable tandem activity- based-sensing and labeling fluorescent probes as a platform study redox homeostasis in biological systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Although most of the 23% of incarcerated people in South Africa who are also living with HIV initiate antiretroviral therapy (ART) during incarceration, only one third remain on ART following release. We pilot tested an intervention that succeeded in retaining 61% of individuals in care compared to 36% with usual services: Structured Peer-delivered ART and Reentry Strategy (SPARCS). We are seeking to conduct a randomized control trial that addresses the tension between effectiveness and scalability by: (1) testing each of the SPARCS components independently in a randomized controlled trial with a 2x2 factorial design trial to maximize statistical power, (2) identifying key elements of implementation including reach, adoption, adaptations, and fidelity, and (3) provide cost and cost-effectiveness results to guide scale-up decisions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative In this study, we will develop a comprehensive mHealth-community health worker (CHW) tool for cesarean section (c-section) follow-up that is usable and acceptable to CHWs in rural Rwanda. We will then assess the validity of this tool during a prospective pilot, the impact of this tool on time-to-diagnosis in a randomized trial, as well as the acceptability of the tool to mothers delivering via c-section. This research will support the ability of CHWs to provide safe, accessible, and affordable in-home c-section follow-up care to women in rural Africa, thus decreasing the physical and financial burden of facility-based follow-up for new mothers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Profound disparities in birth outcomes persist in the United States at a huge cost to individuals and society. Nevertheless, the root social environmental determinants of poor birth outcomes remain elusive, particularly for immigrant populations. By using data science, spatial techniques, and qualitative methods to examine the experiences of immigrant women, the proposed research will advance understanding of the pathways between contextual social factors and pregnancy and birth outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is an important contraceptive option for the prevention of unintended pregnancy for millions of women globally. However, the well-established side effect of increased bone turnover and bone loss with DMPA use may mobilize toxic metal lead stored in bone to plasma, exposing DMPA users to increased circulating lead levels. Given that chronic exposure to lead from water, air, food, and dust is common, no safe levels of circulating lead exist, and strong evidence that lead negatively affects health, the information gleaned from the proposed project will inform the provision of safer contraception in adolescent, adult, and lactating women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Lay Summary This project aims to spearhead the role of imaging in the personalized management of early-stage lung cancer treated with neoadjuvant immunotherapy. The proposed studies will lead to the development of computational tools to extract quantitative imaging biomarkers from serial PET and CT scans and to the evaluation of the biological and clinical relevance of these imaging biomarkers. The new imaging biomarkers will close the unmet clinical need in immunotherapy for early-stage lung cancer by identifying those patients most likely to benefit from treatment, maximizing the clinical effectiveness of immunotherapies, and thus promoting a major paradigm shift of the role of radiographic imaging to serve as an important approach in precision cancer management.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (NOWS) Treatment Trial will assess the optimal pharmacological treatment for NOWS through a multicenter, comparative effectiveness trial of three commonly used medications. The CHOP/Penn Neonatal Clinical Trials Network team will contribute expertise in clinical trial methodology, substance abuse, and neonatal follow-up, providing rigorous scientific input into design and implementation of the multicenter NOWS Treatment Trial. We will then execute all aspects of the trial to the highest standard, including robust participant recruitment, rigorous adherence to all aspects of the study protocol, and neurodevelopmental follow-up to two years with minimal attrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The application of modeling, computation, and experimental approaches for technology development is in high demand in both industry and academic Biophotonics research and development with an estimated economic impact of $90 billion annually. Our proposed program is designed principally for graduate student, post-doctoral, and early-career faculty researchers eager to advance their technical proficiency in Multiscale Biophotonics and access mentoring support for professional development to establish a successful career in support of the Biomedical workforce. The combination of our onsite 12-day intensive short course in combination with a subsequent year-long capstone problem-based learning module and sustained technical and professional mentorship collectively provides an evidence-based approach by which trainees will acquire both technical proficiency and confidence to pursue a successful biomedical careers in this important area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Proper control over the cell cycle is essential to development, homeostasis, and regeneration. The regulation of differentiation and the specification of cell fates has been extensively studied, as have the fundamental mechanisms of cell cycle control, but ubiquitous correlations observed between cell fate and the cell cycle have not been studied in detail. To understand how cell fate regulates the duration of the cell cycle and how changes in the duration of the cell cycle influence cell fate, we will employ a combination of cell lineage tracing, spatial transcriptomics, and an evolutionary approach to studying the structure of developmental lineages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Current drugs used to treat Alzheimer’s disease ameliorate the symptoms of the disease but do not slow or reverse disease progression. We propose to discover small molecules that selectively activate PLC-2 to reproduce the highly robust neuroprotective effects of PLC-2 (P522R). These compounds will be unique tools to dissect the roles of PLC-2 in neuroprotection and serve as the initial leads for further work to develop novel therapeutics to treat Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) Bereavement support is a public health priority and integral to comprehensive palliative care, yet accessible, evidence-based interventions remain limited, particularly for bereaved parents. The loss of a child is arguably one of the most devastating experiences one can endure, leaving bereaved parents at risk for a number of detrimental mental and physical health outcomes and significantly reduced quality of life. The proposed multisite, mixed methods randomized controlled trial aims to improve continuity and accessibility of care through evaluation of a promising, conceptually sound, telehealth-delivered grief intervention – Meaning-Centered Grief Therapy – which has the potential to reduce the measurable burden of suffering for bereaved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Aggressive periodontitis, now named Grade C periodontitis (C/MIP), is a group of less frequently, often severe and rapidly progressive form of periodontitis, affecting young individuals at an early age, usually aggregating in families of lower social economic background. The factors that render affected individuals to C/MIP disease are yet to be clearly identified, which affects the proper control of this aggressive disease. This multi-center study will gather clearly-defined cases of C/MIP from different regions of the globe and within families, to evaluate genetic susceptibility variants using whole exome sequencing, host response via epithelial cell transcriptome to pinpoint mechanistic pathways associated with C/MIP and with genetic variants, and microbial community profile via metagenomics as well as specific species strains associated with this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The mental health of adolescents in the United States has seen a steep decline since 2011, roughly coinciding with the increasing popularity of social media and smartphones. But does social media have a causal impact on the mental health of adolescents or are concerns about the effect of social media on kids a form of public hysteria? In this study, we will conduct the first field experiment in 11–14-year-olds to examine whether, how, and for whom social media harms mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Polysubstance use such as commonly used gateway drugs - alcohol, tobacco and cannabis (ATC) is associated with numerous and deleterious consequences for college-attending emerging adults, however they are often unmotivated to quit or reduce drug use. Recent research has shown that mindfulness intervention is effective for craving and ATC reduction but the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. The proposed study will examine brain mechanisms of a brief mindfulness intervention - IBMT that targets at self-control networks in the brain, and test whether combing with EEG Neurofeedback (NF) could optimize IBMT effects on ATC reduction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research directly addresses a long-acknowledged scientific gap: the absence of rigorously conceptualized and evaluated psychometric instruments to measure women’s desires, feelings, and preferences around a potential future pregnancy. The novel, validated Desire to Avoid Pregnancy (DAP) scale represents a leap forward in measurement that will generate new knowledge with its application in newly available longitudinal, population-based surveys, which we will use to investigate the role of pregnancy intentions on the causal pathway to unintended pregnancy, short IPIs, and adverse maternal and birth outcomes. The insights gained and development of innovative extensions of the DAP instrument will facilitate the use of rigorous, meaningful measures in future research, and guide us to public health and clinical interventions that can more successfully prevent unintended pregnancy and short interpregnancy intervals and mitigate their health effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The objective of this project is to investigate cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate synovial joint development. In particular, this study provides novel insights into mechanisms underlying joint progenitor cell function and cavitation. Understanding dynamics of hyaluronic acid (HA) metabolism regulating joint formation during embryonic development will provide novel insights into creation of superior therapeutic tools to treat degenerative joint conditions such as osteoarthritis (OA) in a clinically-relevant manner (i.e., HA injection).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research is to identify neurobehavioral makers of cigarette smoking initiation and tobacco use escalation among users of Electronic Nicotine Delivery Systems (ENDS). Findings are expected to advance mechanistic understanding, more accurate prediction, and more effective prevention of the typical escalation in tobacco products use among vulnerable YA ENDS users, including a five-fold risk of transition to cigarette smoking. Results are also expected to inform regulatory policy on ENDS, particularly flavored ENDS products, and to improve YA responsiveness to public health campaign communications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Project Narrative Recent technological advances in neuroscience have presented new approaches for vision researchers, in addition to challenges in terms of available access and expertise. The Harvard Vision Core plays a central role in vision research in the Harvard community by providing services, equipment, and training to over 20 vision research laboratories. The Core also brings vision scientists together by providing a collaborative environment for research and for training the next generation of vision scientists, and, in this way, the Vision Core at Harvard Medical School accelerates the pace of our understanding and treatment of dysfunctions of the visual system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project narrative The normal cell of origin (COO) from which a tumor arises is central to the treatment of blood cancers but does not factor into the standard of care for lung adenocarcinoma, a leading cause of world cancer death. We will explore a novel approach to map COOs in lung cancer, where COOs are not precisely known, by using the patterns of passenger mutations in their genome. This work may provide a new way to identify COOs for individual tumor samples and build a much needed bridge between human lung cancer biology and mouse models of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Liver disease is a top cause of morbidity and mortality in people living with HIV, with emerging data indicating high risk for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) development. The goal of this proposal is to develop a novel artificial intelligence-based approach for rapid and high-quality clinical chemical exchange saturation transfer (CEST), a molecular MRI technique used to assess metabolic brain dysfunction. CEST imaging as well as other MRI metrics of neuroinflammation, and their associations with blood markers and cognitive performance will help us to better understand and monitor potential interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Innovative and transformational training schemes that motivate the next generation of scientists are needed to increase the numbers of highly trained PhD investigators and MD physician-researchers in kidney, urology, or non-malignant hematology (KUH) research. The University of Alabama at Birmingham KUH Undergraduate Research Experience (UAB KURE) program builds confidence and understanding in hands-on research skills and knowledge of physiological systems as well as enhances critical thinking, communication, and leadership skills in a thriving KUH research environment at UAB. The mission of the UAB KURE program is to inspire, motivate, and develop future KUH researchers from diverse backgrounds (racial/ethnic, rural/urban hometowns, scientific experience, undergraduate institutions) through an immersive short-term KUH research and professional development experiences.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with cancer are at high risk of developing both cachexia, a muscle wasting disorder due to chronic disease, and age-related sarcopenia. However, current tools for diagnosing muscle wasting are inadequate or have not been thoroughly tested in the cancer population. In this study, we will determine the utility of D3- Creatine, an emerging biomarker of muscle wasting, using pre-clinical models of cancer and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The Direct to Phase II SBIR goal is to optimize, validate, and commercialize Active-H2O, a sensor driven smart faucet to empower independent living for individuals impacted by Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and dementia. While dementia impacts many activities of daily living (ADLs), many key ADL’s require water access including hydration, bathing, grooming, & medication management. Therefore, commercialization of a smart faucet, to remind users of tasks & automatically deliver water in target temperature, force, & nozzle setting for specific ADLs, will empower individuals impacted by AD to age in place, while reducing caregiver burden & costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Bacterial infection of burn wounds is common and increases both the morbidity and mortality of burn injuries. Furthermore, current burn dressings adhere to the wound surface and make each change of dressing excruci- atingly painful for the patient as well as cumbersome and time consuming for clinical personnel. This proposal develops a novel treatment that addresses difficult to treat infections (e.g., methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) wherein a new drug that prevents bacteria from communicating and coordinating attacks against the host/patient is delivered via a novel wound dressing that alleviates patient pain during dressing changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a prevalent and progressive obstructive lung disease caused by cigarette smoke exposure with few effective therapies. The role of mitochondrial dysfunction and cellular senescence, a state of cell arrest, in COPD pathogenesis remain unknown and an area of high scientific interest. The work under this Diversity supplement and R01 will define how adenine nucleotide translocase (ANT2), a mitochondrial ADP/ATP translocase, influences mitochondrial dysfunction that drives cellular senescence and abnormal repair of the lung epithelium, thus opening the potential for ANT as a therapeutic target for COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Lay Summary The current proposal seeks to fund 14 undergraduate students annually to work with Mayo Clinic researchers in Nephrology or Urology. This 10-week summer program will pair undergraduates with Mayo Clinic researchers to carry out specific research projects. Students will participate in a research training course, take a cell and renal mini-course, organize their lab data into abstracts, oral research presentations and poster presentations. Talks will be given to Mayo faculty and posters will be presented at the NIDDK-KUH Summer Research Symposium held annually at the end of the Summer. In the past 10 years, >75% of students received professional degrees, 25 federal grants were received and ~10% of students have entered Nephrology or Urology-related fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This application to RFA-AI-23-024 (Sex-Difference in Radiation Research) will evaluate if sex-based differences in the regulation of renin-angiotensin enzyme ACE2 contribute to observed sex-differences in radiation sensitivity to gastrointestinal (GI) injury. We hypothesize ACE2 activity within the intestinal endothelium protects against radiation induced GI damage by increasing Ang1-7 signaling through MasR. The three Aims are designed to interrogate the role of biological sex in this pathway using a combination of novel pharmacologic, genetic, and imaging tools.

PHR: Project Narrative The FASEB Virus Structure and Assembly Conference is a one-of-a-kind event that attracts scientists worldwide to showcase the latest research data on virus structure, assembly, and function, including biomedical and nanotechnological applications of viruses. The Conference is highly interactive, inclusive, and training-focused, encouraging communication and cross-disciplinary cooperation and promoting exchange and interaction between senior- and early-stage researchers and graduate students. A focus on RNA virus pathogens such as HIV-1, SARS-CoV-2, and Influenza characterizes the 2024 FASEB Virus Structure and Assembly Conference that will be held in Southbridge, MA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sex differences are present in glioblastoma (GBM), with males presenting with GBM more frequently than females and with a more aggressive disease. Many mouse models recapitulate these sex differences and have been leveraged for key observations of how the immune response contributes to GBM sex bias; however, many of these mouse models do not reflect key mutations observed in the human condition, and tumor models are often devoid of a complete set of sex chromosomes. The objective of this revision application is to integrate a more representative mouse model generated through the NCI IMAT Program into an ongoing P01 on sex differences in brain tumors with the goal of assessing the interaction between the immune response and changes in the tumor microenvironment using models that contain human mutations and intact sex chromosomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative As HIV-infected individuals age, they experience non-AIDS, inflammation-related illnesses, such as cardiovascular disease (CVD), even when the virus is suppressed with antiretroviral therapy. This proposal will yield novel integrated and innovative approaches in the emerging field of extracellular vesicles (EVs) and HIV- associated atherosclerosis to reveal a novel measure of immune/inflammatory responses for discovering potential predictor biomarkers and will make unique contributions to the deeper understanding of how EVs and their cargo impact the resolution of inflammation to influence CVD risk in HIV in a mechanistic manner. The idea is that, if extracellular vesicles are altered, then by understanding exactly how they are altered, we will lay the groundwork for developing novel therapeutic strategies to reduce HIV-associated chronic inflammation, and lifelong co-morbidities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Lung cancer kills more Veterans than any other cancer. Veterans are more likely than civilians to present with lung cancer that is unresectable and spread to the lymph nodes (Stage III). Immune checkpoint blockade can cure a subset of Veterans with locally advanced Stage III or metastatic Stage IV cancer. At present, the standard of care for Stage III NSCLC is six weeks of chemotherapy and radiation followed by one year of maintenance immune checkpoint blockade. This is challenging for many patients and may not be needed in all cases. We have found Veterans whose lung cancer expresses immune checkpoints most benefit from immune checkpoint blockade. In this clinical trial, we are trying to see if by using the immunotherapy upfront, overall tolerability of the three treatments can be improved. If this is true, we may be able to help more Veterans with lung cancer live longer lives with less treatment toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cancer is a leading cause of death around the world. An immune-based, non-toxic approach that attacks the cancer as well as the supporting deficiencies that facilitate its progression would be a great boon to the field. This project aims to improve public health by developing a successful tumor immunology model, which can be applied to study immunological reactions to the immunotherapy and eliminate long-term cancer reappearance without disrupting normal immune function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Individuals with Down syndrome are at increased risk of recurrent respiratory infections, including SARS-CoV- 2 infections. The implementation of non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) such as hand washing, social distancing, and face masking during the pandemic has resulted a dramatic global reduction in the incidence of common respiratory virus infections. Through determining the burden of all-cause respiratory morbidity during the pandemic time, the proposed study will provide important information to inform the usage of subsequent vaccines, protection products, and therapeutic strategies to reduce respiratory morbidity in individuals with Down syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Currently many clinical trials use frozen NK cells for cell therapy to treat a variety of cancers. Unfortunately, however, the cryopreservation process results in a substantial loss of cell viability and function due to the activation of complex molecular based cell stress response to the freeze/thaw process. Further, today the far majority, if not all, cryopreservation processes rely on DMSO (a toxic and mutagenetic agent) as the primary cryoprotective agent. This Phase I project is designed to develop a unique cryoprotective agent cocktail for NK cells that doesn’t contain toxic compounds such as DMSO. Additionally, we will develop a unique post-thaw cell stress molecular modulation reagent designed to increase recovery of NK cells post-thaw regardless of the cryopreservation media utilized. A unique hypothesis to be tested is whether the delayed onset cell death that occurs following thawing is due (in part or whole) to accelerated stress-based cell aging triggered by the cryopreservation process. Together these technologies will yield enhanced NK cell survival thereby improving NK cell therapy outcome for patients worldwide.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Global progress to eliminate mother-to-child transmission of HIV (eMTCT) has stagnated in recent years, highlighting the need for a multifaceted approach that complements the existing focus on treatment initiation among pregnant women living with HIV. This project aims to use simulation-based modeling to evaluate the cost- effectiveness of a wide range of eMTCT interventions and identify optimal intervention portfolios tailored to Kenya, Nigeria, and Botswana, three diverse country contexts that will serve as highly translatable case studies for other African settings. Our findings from this comprehensive eMTCT intervention analysis will provide urgently needed support for eMTCT policymaking and pave the way for a new frontier in eMTCT progress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Populations of sexual and gender minorities (SGM) are disproportionally impacted by higher rates of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Effective biomedical prevention, such as same day preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) and doxycycline postexposure prophylaxis (DoxyPEP), are effective strategies to reduce rates of both HIV and other STIs; however, their use in the primary care setting have not been widely explored. This study aims to leverage key stakeholder (e.g., SGM client and primary care clinicians) perspectives to identify factors influencing awareness, uptake, and persistence of same day PrEP and DoxyPEP in the primary care setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The proposed Phase III multi-site randomized-controlled trial will use highly rigorous methodology to determine whether suvorexant is an effective treatment for insomnia in persons maintained on buprenorphine or methadone. The results will also identify key opioid use disorder treatment outcomes that might be targeted for future medication development. The ultimate goal of this study is to update the prescribing guidelines in the label of suvorexant to include the treatment of “Insomnia in persons with opioid use disorder”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The Harvard Summer Research Program in Kidney Medicine (HSRPKM) will recruit and develop the next generation of kidney medicine and urology leaders of diverse backgrounds. The Program is structured around each student’s summer 9-week research experience at one of four Harvard teaching hospitals (Brigham and Women’s Hospital, Massachusetts General Hospital, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, or Boston Children’s Hospital), which is complemented by a core curriculum that teaches kidney physiology and exposes students to the perspectives of people with kidney disease in the community. To provide longer term career development interactions, HSRPKM will keep these talented young scientists engaged with kidney medicine after their summer experience by developing year-round career development and networking events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the foundational importance of early brain development for subsequent psychopathology, it is imperative to capture children’s everyday experiences with their caregivers in relation to changes in infant brain development. Addressing the need for more ecologically-valid approaches to our understanding of children’s early experiences, this study uses a newly developed wearable device that can dynamically, unobtrusively, and continuously measure patterns of physical proximity between children and caregivers, regardless of location. The proposed project will yield extraordinary insight into the early environment from a child-centered perspective during the first 18 months of life, with relevance to NIMH’s mission to determine the biological and psychological mechanisms by which the environments affect neural and behavioral development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Currently, there are no accurate nonanimal tests to identify consumer products and chemicals that require labeling to advise users to wear protective eyewear and avoid eye contact due to the threat of serious eye damage. The purpose of this application is to further develop and commercialize a new nonanimal test — the in vitro depth of injury eye irritation test (IVD EIT) — to identify this class of ocular irritants and thereby allow for adequate labeling that will advise and inform users about product safety as well as comply with new laws preventing or limiting the use of animals that have been historically used for this type of routine safety testing. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Patients affected by opioid use disorder (OUD) face numerous challenges, ranging from stigma to policy barriers that impede their access to care. Innovative and FDA-cleared opioid use testing methods that can be performed outside of laboratory environments address these issues and hold the promise of increasing retention rates and improving clinical outcomes. A machine learning-based solution that can identify opioid use by analyzing human voice will not only improve clinical outcomes in the outpatient OUD treatment setting but can be adopted in many other settings due to its convenience and can, potentially, unlock new workflows that were not feasible before.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a genetic disease that affects millions of people worldwide. Although multiple SCD gene therapies are undergoing clinical trials, significant challenges concerning the safety and efficacy of CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing remain to be addressed, including the unintended small and large gene modifications at the Cas9 on-target cut-sites. This Diversity Supplement will provide the support to an underrepresented minority PhD student to determine the biological consequences of gene editing induced small in-frame mutations and investigate the impact of modulating DNA repair pathways in gene-editing based treatment of SCD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This proposal will investigate the role of neuroinflammation as a driver of neuropathology following repeat traumatic brain injury (TBI) – which affects over 2.8 million people in the U.S. each year – as we will measure inflammation-related genomic, cellular, and behavioral changes and correlate these to neuropathological consequences using a unique swine model of clinically relevant TBI. First, we will ascertain the underlying genetic and molecular factors contributing to post-TBI neuroinflammation following mild or moderate TBI, followed by a study correlating the extent of behavioral and cognitive deficits with these genetic and molecular changes. Finally, we will test the effect of repeat TBI on genomic, cellular, and behavioral changes during and after a period of neuroinflammation triggered by an initial TBI. This work will guide future studies by comprehensively characterizing genomic, pathological, and cognitive changes after clinically relevant TBI and establish susceptibility to deficiencies in neuronal and neurocognitive health following repeat TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than three out of four new HIV infections among young adults in the United States occur among young men who have sex with men (YMSM). Although pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is highly effective in preventing HIV, evidence indicates that many YMSM who initiate PrEP stop taking it and continue to engage in HIV risk behaviors. We will use implementation science to facilitate delivery of the CDC-recommended evidence-based practices motivational interviewing and personalized health education in two clinics providing PrEP services to increase retention in care and use of PrEP and other HIV prevention methods among YMSM.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Opioid use disorder is characterized by a problematic pattern of opioid use causing significant personal impairment or distress and too frequently leads to overdose and death. In 2021, there were 106,699 Americans who died from an opioid related overdose. 5-MeO-DMT is a psychoplastogenic compound that has shown some promise in several psychopathological disorders, including substance use disorders, but little is known about the effect on opioid use disorder and dose delivery remains a concern with current technologies. There is evidence that a highly targeted pharmaceutical aerosol formulation can overcome current drug delivery limitations, therefore, we will develop a novel inhaled 5-MeO-DMT formulation and test in an animal model of opioid use disorder to improve the lives of persons living with this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the parent PPG is to define the molecular mechanisms that regulate local calcium (Ca2+) signaling in normal and failing hearts with unprecedented precision. There are three goals shared by the four projects: 1) explore the precise role of adrenergic signaling in modulating calcium in normal and failing hearts; 2) define novel mechanisms of interactions between T-tubule and sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) calcium channels; 3) develop new understandings of genetic based mechanisms of inherited forms of CV disease involving calcium. Project four provides the essential link to SR calcium release by studying the structure- function relationships of the type 2 ryanodine receptor (RyR2)/calcium release channel present on the sarcoplasmic and endoplasmic reticula (SR/ER) of many cell types in the context of heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of new signaling pathways that regulate blood pressure at the level of contractility of smooth muscle that makes up the walls of blood vessels will contribute to the development of improved therapies for treatments of diseases associated with SM contractile dysfunction such as hypertension and asthma. New drug targets are important as a sizable cohort of patients with hypertension do not respond well to current drugs. Drugs targeting this pathway will be tested in a hypertensive animal model. Such findings are relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to protect and improve health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will introduce and validate wastewater surveillance for HIV and TB in Eswatini, a high burden setting for both diseases. First, we will introduce and validate techniques for wastewater surveillance of HIV and TB; second, correlate wastewater detection of HIV and TB with public health epidemiological data; and third, evaluate the impact of proven public health prevention and case-finding strategies on levels of TB and HIV in wastewater. The candidate’s approach blends innovative science with strong long-term partnerships with multiple stakeholders in Eswatini, and if successful will help catalyze the drive to end HIV and TB in high burden settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks external funding for a recently launched internship program for Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander (NHPI) undergraduate students interested in a biomedical career related to improving kidney health. The lack of NHPI representation in health professions contributes, in part, to health disparities observed in these communities (including drastically elevated risk for kidney disease). Our program, named the Haumana 'O Pasifika Program by our inaugural class of 8 Haumana (Hawaiian for "student") Scholars, aims to help outstanding NHPI undergraduates achieve their goals of becoming the next generation of nurses, physician assistants, physicians, and scientists by provide research experience, clinical exposure, career development, and community outreach over the course of a 12-week summer program.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is serious and debilitating, with a particularly negative impact on veterans. Current treatments are inadequate, and there is a need to identify new, more effective approaches. Behavioral therapies, including exposure therapy, can be effective, but little is known of their mechanisms, and efficacy is limited. To address this need, we established extinction learning as a valid model of exposure therapy in rats, then developed a partial, sub-effective extinction procedure to investigate potential adjunct treatments that may enhance the efficacy of exposure therapy. Using this model, the primary purpose of this proposal is to test transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS), a non-invasive neuromodulatory treatment, as a potential adjunct approach to enhance the efficacy of extinction. Secondly, we will test TB21007, a pharmacological candidate that we believe shares mechanisms with tDCS. The potential impact of this research is to make exposure therapy better and faster, improving treatment outcomes for PTSD, and enhancing quality of life for veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The relevance of this research to public health: Cryptococcal meningoencephalitis poses a serious threat to public health, causing hundreds of thousands of deaths each year. Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal pathogen of the top critical priority listed by WHO. There is no clinically available vaccine against Cryptococcus neoformans, and the long-term goal of this project is to identify cryptococcal factors that can induce protective host responses and use these immunogens to develop mRNA-LNP vaccines or recombinant protein vaccines against cryptococcosis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to Veterans health, because although cognitive dysfunction is a frequent and persistent symptom of traumatic brain injury (TBI), there are currently no effective treatments available for this persistent deficit. In addition, the neurophysiological basis of these deficits remains unknown, making rational treatment design difficult. This project will therefore define for the first time the underlying functional basis for cognitive dysfunction in biomechanically relevant TBI models with complex behavioral metrics. In addition, advanced neuroimaging that is clinically relevant will be evaluated as a tool for identifying white matter (axonal) disruption relevant to these functional and behavioral deficits. The project is relevant to the VA BLR&D mission because knowledge of why TBI induced cognitive disorders persist, and how neuromodulation alleviates them in relevant animal TBI models of different types of injury, will allow for clinical treatment development that will reduce the burden of these deficits in our Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Building human resource and infrastructure capacity to enhance sustainability of HIV research discovery and the implementation of findings by a diverse and multidisciplinary workforce is a major goal of the National Institutes of Health’s strategic research plan for HIV and HIV-related research. The proposed five-year program aims to address this public health need by providing research education and mentoring to early- career social and behavioral HIV researchers who have demonstrated cultural expertise, a commitment to improving the health of communities disproportionately affected by HIV, and who are initiating innovative programs of research to advance the program priorities of the NIMH Division of AIDS Research. The core of the program is: an innovative, intensive six-week summer in-residence program of seminars and peer reviews; one-on-one consultations with mentors; research experience funding; ongoing support from mentors and webinars during the academic year; and one-on-one consultations and peer reviews for VP alumni to support them in submitting new NIH grant proposals and remaining in the research pipeline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The adult brain shows limited plasticity, which poses a challenge for learning new tasks in health, and for repairing neuronal connections after injury such as stroke, or in neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease. Most current approaches to increase plasticity cause permanent alteration of neuronal state, with potential for detrimental outcomes, therefore new approaches are needed to transiently alter neuronal plasticity state to enable controlled synaptic remodeling and repair. This is achieved by developing Targeted Degradation of Extracellular Proteins (TDEP), a toolkit of genetic reagents to enable precise control of the neuronal environment to promote brain health and repair that can be applied to multiple neurological disorders where enhancing synaptic plasticity would be beneficial.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Dysmenorrhea is a painful condition affecting up to 90% of women and people with uteruses and is defined by cramping-associated pain during menstruation. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and hormonal contraception (HC) are first-line options for treating dysmenorrhea, but with 20-25% of people not responding to NSAIDs and many finding the side effects of NSAID and HC use to be unacceptable, the overall impact of these therapies is limited. This Phase I SBIR project proposes the clinical evaluation of a non-invasive transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation device to provide an at-home treatment for dysmenorrhea.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative TRPV1 antagonist-based pharmaceuticals represent a completely new approach to treating pain associated with endometriosis. Based on the published literature supporting this target in the pathophysiology of pain and the preclinical and clinical work completed thus far by Serentrix, we are confident that we will be able to demonstrate that SER-014 is a highly efficacious and safe treatment for pain associated with endometriosis. Together, the package of aforementioned studies will demonstrate the pharmacology and safety of selective antagonism of the TRPV1 receptor. These studies will also lay the groundwork for the future clinical development of this compound for pain associated with endometriosis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will support the expansion of long-acting injectable antiretroviral therapy (LAI-ART) in non-clinical settings by developing, implementing, and evaluating a comprehensive, theory-informed training intervention to support the administration of LAI-ART by a trained layperson injector (e.g., friend, family, partner identified by a person living with HIV). This study will address barriers to LAI-ART uptake and persistence, enhance real- world effectiveness, and help close critical HIV care gaps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD AND TB PREVENTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efforts to curb the HIV epidemic in the United States (US) are impeded by suboptimal access and adherence to antiretroviral therapy (ART), particularly among cis-gender Black women with HIV (CgBWH) in the US South who face intersectional constraints that limit their progression along the HIV care continuum. Long-acting (LA) ART has the potential to transform the landscape of HIV treatment and serve as a tool to help end the epidemic, but to maximize its potential we must develop innovative and tailored approaches to facilitate care linkage and adherence strategies for marginalized populations across rural and urban settings, including CgBWH. In this proposed U01, our multidisciplinary team will leverage existing academic-community partnerships to conduct a mixed methods study that integrates CgBWH LA ART preferences, barriers, and facilitators with qualitative data from HIV service providers on implementation strategies to co-create tailored prototype tools for LA ART education, linkage and referral that will support CgBWH access and uptake across delivery sites.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: PS23-003 - A Community-based Assessment of Preferences for Long-Acting Antiretroviral Therapy Options Among Cis-gender Black Women across Six Ending the HIV Epidemic Jurisdictions in the South

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polysubstance use (PSU) and concomitant overdose are substantial public health issues, with over half of overdose deaths nationally involving multiple substances. The proposed research aims to address two key facets of overdose prevention centers (OPCs), a novel harm reduction intervention, as they relate to overdose risk and mental health in PSU-involved populations: (1) the capacity for OPCs to reduce overdose mortality and morbidity for this high-risk population and (2) the potential role of OPCs as a venue to address mental health needs of PSU-involved populations. This K01 will uncover evidence to support the optimization of an emerging public health intervention as it scales nationally in the context of an ongoing polysubstance overdose epidemic and support a new investigator in developing an independent research career dedicated to building equitable and integrated access to substance use and mental health services to prevent overdose.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE23-002 - Assessing the Impact of Overdose Prevention Centers as a Polysubstance Use and Behavioral Health Intervention in New York City

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: Component A: Project Narrative Conducting year-round, prospective surveillance for well-established and newly emergent gastrointestinal and respiratory diseases will provide vital information about the burden of these illnesses in pediatric patients seeking care in the emergency room and who are hospitalized. With with information, CDC will have the information needed to determine the impact of current vaccines, new vaccines, antiviral treatments, and maternal vaccination on these pediatric infectious diseases. CDC will also be able to correlate the incidence of these infections in children and the development of new clinical diseases such as acute flaccid myelitis.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: IP21-002, Surveillance for Vaccine Preventable Disease in Children

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This pragmatic randomized controlled trial will assess the efficacy of medically tailored meals and medical nutrition therapy via telehealth on clinical outcomes for patients with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes. The goal of these interventions is to improve outcomes for patients with diabetes by impacting self-care behaviors and diet self-efficacy in the short and long term. This study leverages a unique health system and community group partnership to inform the utility of reimbursement for medically tailored meal programs and medical nutrition therapy, which would ultimately facilitate their scalability and sustainability within the healthcare system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: RELEVANCE AND NARRATIVE (Overall) Overall Relevance The actions of abused drugs on the brain lead directly to many of the nation’s and the world’s greatest public health problems, yet the nature of the drug-altered brain is very poorly understood. We believe that this fact is relevant to the present situation in which available treatments and preventions are inadequately effective for most people and that an effective path to developing treatments and cures is opened up via deeper understanding of underlying circuit dynamics, which will be addressed here. Narrative In this project, the Center will 1) Bring together a diverse set of investigators for the important goal of understanding, both brainwide and at cellular resolution, the causal circuit dynamics of abused drug action; 2) Develop a broad range of new approaches for studying the actions of drugs of abuse on the brain; 3) Apply these approaches, collaboratively under the Center, to circuit dynamics of both acute and chronic abused- drug action; 4) Disseminate the resulting technologies to the drug abuse and supporting scientific communities through a unique and innovative training/educational program.

PHR: We hypothesize that local inflammatory events in the respiratory system from influenza virus infection  leads to systemic changes in normal cardiovascular physiology that can be altered with bodyweight and  timely admission of antiviral therapeutics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inborn errors of immunity (IEI) are genetic disorders of the immune system affecting over 400 genes, with new defects discovered at a rapid rate. As the IEI gene panels, WES, and WGS sequencing are increasingly used, about 75% of IEI sequencing yields no diagnostic variants, but do yield variants of unknown significance (VUSs) in one of there 400 genes or novel candidate genes, which require functional characterization for definitive genetic diagnosis. We propose to build a regional resource which will lead to an increase in diagnostic rate and an expansion of research enterprises with clinically significant biological questions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Narrative (Overall) The overarching hypothesis of this SPORE proposal is that combining RT with systemic therapy that targets the molecular drivers of locally advanced cancers will improve the outcome of treatment. We do not know of another group that can carry out integrated preclinical and clinical studies which have a significant chance of decreasing the morbidity and mortality of breast, brain, and pancreas cancer by increasing the RT sensitivity and immunogenicity of tumors through targeting their molecular drivers using clinically available agents.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (ADMINISTRATIVE CORE) Through its interactive organizational structure including clearly defined leadership and advisory capabilities the Administrative Core of the University of Michigan Radiosensitization SPORE supports all projects, cores, and developmental programs of the SPORE. The Administrative Core fosters in-depth communication among all SPORE components to enhance research integration, provide critical scientific feedback, evaluate scientific progress, plan for future opportunities, and assert translational focus. The Core communicates with the National Cancer Institute staff and helps its scientists disseminate their findings rapidly to the public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE (PROJECT 1) Pancreatic cancer is the third leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States and is associated with a grim 10% 5-year survival rate. The overall goal of this application is to develop a therapeutic strategy using the combination of radiation with the FDA approved agent olaparib to sensitize the majority of otherwise resistant pancreatic cancers to immunotherapy. The preclinical and clinical studies in this proposal will lead to urgently needed advances in the clinical management of locally advanced pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to conduct a randomized controlled trial comparing treat to target serum urate with treat to avoid symptoms among patients with gout and hyperuricemia. We anticipate that a treat to target serum urate strategy results in significantly fewer gout flares (primary outcome) over a two-year follow-up. We will also test the effects of lowering serum urate on kidney disease endpoints, glycemic status, and blood pressure among relevant subgroups of patients with gout enrolled in the randomized controlled trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE (Project 2) Radiation is a cornerstone treatment for glioblastoma but tumors inevitably recur due to radiation resistance. We have found that non-malignant cells in the glioblastoma microenvironment mediate radiation resistance by stimulating purine metabolism in cancer cells. This research proposal will define how metabolites from non-malignant cells promote glioblastoma purine metabolism and how interrupting this regulation could improve outcomes for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The primary goal of this study is to assess real-world effectiveness and implementation of an evidence-based multi-component strategy to achieve equity in the allocation rate of advanced heart failure therapies, heart transplants and ventricular assist devices. This study proposes to implement evidence-based strategies that reduce bias, replace subjective evaluations with objective criteria, and improve group dynamics in a randomized cluster trial. Our rigorously designed trial will inform national guidelines for advanced heart failure therapy allocation, and data are likely to be generalizable to other organ replacement treatments and advanced chronic disease decision-making processes.

PHR: Project Narrative This project explores the intersection of two fundamental areas, namely the cellular (mal)adaptation to primary mitochondrial dysfunction and the biology of the mitochondrial Ca2 + uniporter complex (MCUC). Here we propose to test the hypothesis that the MCUC serves a protective role during early stage mitochondrial myopathy, by augmenting energy production and mitigating stress signaling that could lead to muscle atrophy, and a detrimental role during later phases of mitochondrial dysfunction in skeletal muscle. These studies are expected to uncover novel regulation of the (mal)adaptive response to mitochondrial dysfunction and of muscle mass in myopathy, representing new roles for the MCUC in a post- mitotic cell environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE (Project 3) Locoregional control for women with locally advanced ER-positive (ER+) and triple-negative (TN) breast cancer (BC) remains a significant clinical challenge despite standard radiation therapy, which could be addressed by radiosensitization. This study will determine the mechanism of CDK 4/6 inhibitor-mediated radiosensitization, the efficacy of this combination in vivo in ER+ and TNBC models and will allow for a first-in-human phase I trial establishing the safety and efficacy of such an approach in women with locally advanced breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The fate and function of cells, tissues, organs, and organisms are determined by the expression of specific set of genes in the genome. This project aims to pinpoint the mechanism controlling DNA demethylation which is the principal means of gene expression regulation and genome stability. The outcome of this project will shed light on DNA methylation-specific regulation of gene expression and DNA damage repair in human cells and may have broader impacts on a variety of human diseases including cancer and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Rates of suicide continue to increase37 due to the lack of causal evidence necessary to develop effective interventions for suicidal behavior.38 This study will provide causal evidence for two modifiable mechanisms linking social pain and suicidal behavior: impaired decision-making and physiological arousal. This study will directly inform the assessment and prediction of suicidal behaviors and will aid in the development of novel interventions that target key mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: MCGILL UNIVERSITY HEALTH CTR RES INST
PHR: Project narrative Our novel approach for improving type 1 diabetes treatment involves using an automated insulin delivery (AID) system with an ultra-rapid insulin analogue, Lyumjev, and adjunctive glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist (GLP1-RA), Semaglutide, to simplify mealtime diabetes management by alleviating the need of carbohydrate counting. The data from our study may demonstrate that an AID system with meal announcement and weekly injections of Semaglutide can achieve clinically non-inferior daytime glycemic control to a conventional insulin-alone AID system that requires carbohydrate counting. We hope the results of our clinical trial will prompt new studies with GLP1-RA to further explore the benefits of this drug in type 1 population, as well as encourage more studies that aim to reduce the burden of mealtime management in people with type 1 diabetes. PHR: Narrative: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of tuberculosis disease, remains a global public health challenge, and development of new interventions and identification of drug resistance are among the objectives of the World Health Organization End TB Strategy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Black Americans have worse hospital outcomes and the hospitals that serve a high proportion of Black Americans are more likely be lower quality; however, little is known about what modifiable aspects of these Black-serving hospitals underlie their poorer quality. In this proposal, we bring a new perspective to the long- standing challenge of achieving health equity in hospital care and patient outcomes, by evaluating whether the differences in hospital nurse resources explain poorer outcomes among those cared for in Black-serving hospitals.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young children’s social-emotional-behavioral health and school success are inextricably linked, and both have been adversely affected by racial and economic inequities exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. This study will 1) test the effects of a universal group-based parenting intervention in prekindergarten on a range of parent, child, and school outcomes associated with children’s wellbeing and later academic success and 2) evaluate its cost, acceptability, implementation, and sustainability when offered in different formats (virtual vs in-person) in urban and rural public schools serving low-income students. This study seeks to improve children’s social-emotional-behavioral wellbeing, kindergarten readiness skills, and school outcomes by building on parents’ strengths and promoting engagement in their children’s education during the early years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is the biggest risk factor for cardiovascular disease. The long-term goal and clinical significance of this F30 grant application is to determine how surgically taking away the nerves from the kidneys to the brain can be used to lower blood pressure in patients with hypertension. The results from these studies will serve as an important platform for therapeutic initiatives focused on utilizing the nervous system to treat cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to address two important Healthy People 2030 goals: 1) Improve the health, function, and quality of life of older adults, and 2) Prevent unintentional injuries and violence, and reduce their consequences. Trainees will collaborate with experienced research faculty and research teams on injury-related projects relevant to aging, including falls prevention, cognitive function, vision loss, depression/ suicide, toxicology and polypharmacy, patient safety, and quality of life after trauma. It is critical to examine the risks and mechanisms of injury and response to trauma and trauma care from a life-stages perspective, and to look at the unique needs of the elderly in injury prevention, acute treatment and rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRI & TECH ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorders are a major public health concern afflicting approximately 17 million Americans, often beginning with binge drinking during adolescence. The proposed studies will determine how adolescent ethanol exposure and ethanol re-exposure in adulthood influences (1) sex-specific neuronal activation of steroid receptor containing neurons within mesocorticolimbic structures and (2) circulating steroid and metabolomic profiles. Completion of this work will elucidate short- and long-term impacts of adolescent ethanol exposure on critical brain structures and their circuits that underlie long-lasting changes in alcohol drinking in males and females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative: The proposed research aims to determine the health outcomes of different deprescribing strategies of antipsychotics used for behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia in a skilled nursing facility. Our study will generate direct evidence that facilitates timely deprescribing of potentially inappropriate medications in people living with dementia. It will also yield a novel analytical framework specializing in comparative safety and effectiveness analyses of discontinuing psychotropic treatments with detailed subgroup analyses informative for individualized deprescribing decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative: In severe traumatic brain injury intracranial pressure (ICP) is monitored to treat raises in ICP with the goal of maintaining adequate cerebral blood flow (CBF) and critical closing pressure (CrCP) and prevent secondary brain injury. ICP alone cannot separate benign ICP elevations from flow-limiting pressure spikes. By combining superconducting nanowire single photon detectors (SNSPD) with diffuse correlation spectroscopy (DCS) operating at 1064 nm, we propose to develop a bedside CBF, CrCP and ICP monitor that offers a leap forward in performances when compared to existing DCS technology and demonstrate feasibility and utility in the ICU environment. If successful, this device will enable better guided management of a larger number of brain injury patients resulting in improved neurological outcomes.
