IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because defects in mitochondria are at the heart of many diseases including heart disease, neurodegeneration, and cancer. Therefore, the proposed research plan to elucidate the fundamental principles underlying mitochondrial network morphology and dynamics is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that seeks to mitigate the burden of human disease by developing fundamental knowledge of the processes driving disease. In addition, the proposed work seeks to develop methodologies that make mitochondria research more accessible to other researchers, thereby accelerating the advent of new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The financial and societal burden of gut disorders and visceral pain is a major problem in the US, especially for women. Irritable bowel syndrome is a highly prevalent functional disorder without clear pathology that degrades the quality of life. Our team seeks to understand the mechanistic underpinnings of the gut-brain axis in order to shed light on this prevalent intestinal disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The Hillock is a newly discovered cellular structure within the mammalian airway. While it is injury resistant and is able to regenerate the airway post-injury, it also has some similarities to squamous metaplasia, which is thought to be a precancerous lesion. This work will define the relationship of the hillock with squamous metaplasia as well as provide critical information on the molecular pathways that regulate hillocks’ differentiation and expansion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: In response to severe respiratory infections like influenza and SARS-CoV-2, a mediator of inflammation called HMGB1 is released from dying cells and leads to the “cytokine storm” associated with disease progression. Our novel inducible platform produces an inhibitor of HMGB1 in response to inflammation that is expected to counteract disease and be broadly applicable against many different inflammatory agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors can result in long-lasting clinical responses in a variety of advanced or metastatic malignancies, but approximately half of patients receiving these drugs develop autoimmune endocrinopathies. Our proposal brings together expertise in three complementary areas such as endocrinology, autoimmunity, and oncology. The outcome of this investigation will provide mechanistic insights into immunotherapy-related adverse events and may provide the groundwork for understanding how to limit the toxicity of immunotherapy as well as improving treatments of autoimmune endocrine diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A low nicotine product standard could improve public health by reducing the prevalence of smoking. The current proposal aims to examine the real-world impact of a low nicotine product standard for smoked tobacco in New Zealand to inform the US nicotine reduction policy agenda recently announced by the Biden Administration. We propose to follow a cohort of New Zealanders who smoke daily or near daily, with an emphasis on enrolling priority smoking populations, before and after policy implementation to understand the impact of a low nicotine product standard on tobacco use behavior, health, and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 60% of adolescents diagnosed with depression do not receive mental health care and treatment engagement is low among those who do access care. This mixed-methods study will build a fully functional Asynchronous Remote Communities (ARC) platform to supplement behavioral activation (BA+ARC) therapy for depressed adolescents and test its feasibility, usability, and effect on adolescent outcomes. BA+ARC is an innovative, scalable tool that utilizes a private online platform to provide peer and therapist coaching, chatbot supported therapy tools, and real-time mood and behavior tracking to improve access, engagement, and usability of adolescent depression treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: By integrating new technological and conceptual approaches; this proposed project will help discovering how cortical oxygenation, metabolic rate, and blood flow responses at the microvascular scales change during healthy aging and how they vary across different regions and depths of awake mouse brain. Moreover, this work will support better interpretation of the signal from oxygen-sensitive clinical neuroimaging methods, by quantifying these responses under common calibration procedures, including breathing challenges such as increased oxygen and/or carbon dioxide concentration, and intake of pharmaceuticals such as caffeine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aberrant activation of the transcription factor NRF2, a key regulator of the cellular oxidative stress response, is frequently seen in HPV negative head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and is associated with a poor prognosis. Functionally validated somatic mutations of this pathway can only account for 30% of the observed activation. The objective of this proposal is to identify and characterize novel genomic and proteomic mechanisms of NRF2 activation in order to advance strategies for the diagnosis and targeted treatment of patients with NRF2 active tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to elucidate the regulation of protein kinase C (PKC) theta () by phosphorylation and how this impacts function and biology. I have selected several critical phosphorylation residues (T538, S662, S676, S685, and S695) for further analysis with the goal of determining how each of these regulate PKC function and signaling. These fundamental studies will offer novel insights into the regulation of PKC in T cells and platelets, with application in immune and blood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scientists have developed the ability to coax cells from human donors to grow into miniature pieces of neural tissue known as “brain organoids”. These organoids express genes and recapitulate aspects of neurodevelopment that are shared with their human donors, allowing insight into individual-specific disease processes and potential treatments. This project seeks to understand how human donors feel and think about brain organoids grown from their cells, with the ultimate goal to ensure that future brain organoid research is conducted in accordance with donor values.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of older adults who are 60 years and older undergoing hematopoietic cell transplantation as part of cancer treatment has more than doubled in the past decade. Older adults undergoing these transplants are at high risk of experiencing a decline in cognitive function afterwards that can affect day-to-day function and quality of life. Our project seeks to develop and test an exercise-based intervention to preserve cognitive function and improve quality of life among transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance Heavy drinking, sexual assault, and psychological distress are significant, co-occurring problems for young adult bisexual women. Psychological distress is a common aftereffect of trauma and intersects with minority stress and drinking to cope with psychological distress can increase risk for sexual revictimization. This study will involve developing and piloting an integrated intervention that designed to reduce alcohol use, sexual revictimization, and psychological distress among a particularly high-risk group – young adult bisexual women with a history of sexual victimization and who report heavy episodic drinking.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The human cerebral cortex is greatly expanded compared to other primates, which is ultimately caused by genetic changes that affect gene expression regulation and how the human cerebral cortex develops. My goal is to reveal how a specific region of human-specific genetic change and human innovations in gene regulation shape cortical development and evolution, by using novel mouse models. This knowledge of how uniquely human genetic and developmental change affect growth of the cerebral cortex, an important structure for higher-order cognition, is crucial for understanding the etiology of disorders affecting humans, such as neurodevelopmental disorders and cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cellular state changes generally require the simultaneous action of a handful of master regulators, substantially limiting the robust, durable, stable engineering of cell state for therapeutic application that can be achieved with current methods for modulating the expression of individual genes. We plan to move beyond the standard one- perturbation-per-gene paradigm for linking genes to phenotypes by engineering a platform for highly combinatorial cell state perturbation. We anticipate this platform, which combines both novel wetlab approaches for engineering highly combinatorial libraries producing a high multiplicity of perturbation with computational approaches to deconvolve these signals and iteratively engineer maximally informative libraries, will provide a match between the inherent polygenic complexity of cellular systems and our ability to rationally perturb these systems to elicit ideal therapeutically-relevant phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Ammonia solution (20%) (AMM) is highly toxic and of interest to the CCRP, and the cornea is a major target for acute ammonia exposure. Corneal ammonia exposure results in an alkali burn wound, which can lead to a host of potentially blinding pathologic features and often times loss of the eye. The long-term objectives of this project are several fold, with the overall goals being to gain a better understanding of the mechanisms behind injuries created by corneal AMM exposure, and to develop potential therapeutics to treat AMM-induced wounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Blood clots that form in the arms and legs and travel to the lungs, or venous thromboembolism (VTE), are serious yet preventable. Tools are available to help clinicians in the hospital decide together with their patients whether to initiate VTE prevention, but these tools are too burdensome and cumbersome to be used reliably in daily clinical practice, and their use has not been shown to improve patient outcomes. Therefore, we will refine, implement, and test a highly accurate real-time prognostic model for VTEs among hospitalized adults that helps clinicians to initiate appropriate and timely VTE prevention, thereby reducing rates of VTE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Cytochrome filaments with closely stacked hemes were just recently discovered by us to be responsible for long- range electron transfer. These novel conductive nanowires have great potential as biomedical materials, yet much is still unknown about their mechanism of action and biophysical properties. This proposal aims to identify novel cytochrome filaments in respiring prokaryotes, elucidating their conduction mechanism by biophysical approaches, and designing self-assembled nanowires for biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, approximately 350,000 people suffer out-of-hospital cardiac arrest per year, and there is an urgent need to generate evidence on how to integrate effective treatments into a coordinated system of care at the community and state levels. Our study will test a customized strategic intervention program that focuses on community interventions to improve key process of care measures in the critical minutes after cardiac arrest. If successful, our intervention would provide a roadmap for communities throughout the United States to save lives and improve patient outcomes after cardiac arrest. 1

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. I propose to evaluate the role of lipotoxic ceramides in the tubular epithelium as mediators of metabolic dysfunction driving kidney injury. Successful completion of this work will uncover novel kidney-specific mechanisms driving kidney injury pathogenesis and progression. Additionally, we intend for these studies to inform future investigations into novel therapeutic targets for acute kidney injury and disease in order to improve patient care, decrease risk of morbidity and mortality, and lessen the substantial economic burden of acute kidney injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identification of intervention strategies to minimize dietary weight loss associated bone loss among older adults is needed. This R01 will compare the independent and combined effects of progressive resistance training plus bone loading exercises and bisphosphonate use on measures of bone density, quality, and turnover in 392 older adults who are undergoing a dietary weight loss intervention. If confirmed to be effective, evidence has the potential to shift current geriatric obesity treatment guidelines and enhance scientific understanding of mechanisms governing treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There are millions of people who suffer from different rare diseases worldwide, and many of those diseases lack treatment options that are safe, effective, and convenient for patients. The proposed research will explore a path towards a treatment that meets those requirements using adenovirus as a vessel to deliver gene therapy for a rare disease called mucopolysaccharidoses type I (MPS I). This work will therefore attempt to deliver the corrective gene to cells within the mouse model for MPS I and provide critical information on the feasibility and future possibilities of the use of adenovirus for treatment of rare diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Frailty is a syndrome of reduced physiologic reserve associated with higher postoperative death and complications. While there is global consensus on identifying frail or high-risk patients prior to surgery, less is known on how to intervene in their clinical care to improve outcomes while respecting their goals and expectations. The PAUSE trial is a cluster randomized clinical trial to explore the overall effectiveness (Aim 1), and effectiveness by specialty, frailty and risk status (Aim 2) of implementing a multidisciplinary care model (surgery, anesthesia, geriatrics, palliative care, case management, rehabilitation and nutrition) for surgical decision-making and optimization of postoperative outcomes. We will study the fidelity, adaptation, and implementation of the PAUSE intervention (Aim 3) to develop an implementation guide. Our overall goal is to disseminate the PAUSE intervention for future implementation in the VA as a new model for care of high-risk Veterans being evaluated for surgery.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The development of feasible, effective and scalable interventions to improve the safety of patients at risk for or with central line-related bloodstream infections, is urgently needed. The proposed Johns Hopkins Center for Immersive Learning and Digital Innovation (CILDI) will advance the science of patient safety through a sustainable infrastructure that will test innovative interprofessional interventions co-designed with individuals and families experiencing these conditions. CILDI will utilize a framework comprising a systems engineering initiative for patient safety model and the AHRQ systems engineering project life cycle, to measure patient safety and process efficiency in order to increase the relevance, uptake and sustainability of the interventions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The growing prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and its preliminary stage, mild cognitive impairment (MCI), among U.S. Veterans has stimulated efforts to identify therapeutic targets to modify the progression of these debilitating, neurodegenerative diseases. Recent evidence suggests that dysfunction of the vascular endothelium and decreased abundance of its product, nitric oxide (NO), may contribute to the production and accumulation of neurotoxins thought to cause AD, making endothelial NO bioavailability a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of AD. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to determine if endothelial function and cerebral NO bioavailability are related to the severity and longitudinal progression of AD. Ultimately, these findings will help determine if endothelial function may serve as a prognostic indicator, as well as a potential therapeutic target, in the fight against AD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL CORE To advance the field of child abuse and neglect, a diverse and transdisciplinary team comprised of researchers, staff, consultants, and National Advisory Board with leaders from the Universities of Rochester and Minnesota will partner with the NICHD to enhance and expand the TRANSFORM Center (Translational Research that Adapts New Science FOR Maltreatment Prevention). Building on current state-of-the-art research methodologies and clinical practices that address the personal and societal burden associated with child abuse and neglect, TRANSFORM will continue to leverage theoretically-grounded evidence-based research and interventions to optimize outcomes in children. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: INTER TRIBAL COUNCIL OF ARIZONA, INC.
PHR: NARCH XI - American Indian Research Center for Health Overall Narrative The ITCA American Indian Research for Health (AIRCH) was established in 2000 to reduce health disparities among American Indians and Alaska Natives by engaging tribes in research that is scientifically sound. ITCA works to improve the capacity of tribes in Arizona, including areas related to health. With over 70 staff and 30 projects, ITCA provides on-going technical assistance and over 100 annual trainings to Tribes in program planning and development, research and data collection, and resource development. The AIRCH XII overall goal is to support health research projects that benefit Tribal communities of the ITCA Member Tribes, develop relationships to enhance tribal governance and partnerships in health research, conduct research that honors Tribal Sovereignty, and promote a cadre of AI/AN researchers in health disparities research. Along with the proposal, the AIRCH supports research capacity building and the development of research infrastructure to enhance the biomedical research capabilities of the 21 Member Tribes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: INTER TRIBAL COUNCIL OF ARIZONA, INC.
PHR: NARCH XII Administrative Core Narrative The Inter Tribal Council of Arizona, Inc. (ITCA), is a tribally controlled non-profit organization established in 1975. ITCA has the goal of promoting American Indian self-reliance through public policy development, and to provide Member Tribes with the means for action on matters that affect them collectively and individually. The Member Tribes of ITCA are 21 federally-recognized Tribes located in the State of Arizona. The highest elected official of each Member Tribe serves on the council. These leaders have a comprehensive view of the conditions and needs of the tribal communities they represent. ITCA provides an independent capacity to obtain, analyze, and disseminate information vital to tribal community self-development. To build upon the ethical approach of research among the tribal communities, and continue a long- standing relationship with The University of Arizona and Arizona State University in creating a space for developing AI/AN science focused students and faculty. ITCA proposes to provide the infrastructure for the Native American Research Centers for Health (NARCH) projects as the Administrative Core ensuring all rules and regulations of the award are delivered, along with efficient communication providing accountability of NARCH oversight.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite the initial responses to molecular-targeted therapies, many cancer patients experience disease recurrence, because cancer stem cells (CSCs) are refractory to these treatments with largely unknown mechanisms. This project will identify new genes/pathways (i.e., FTO-m6A-lncRNAs) regulating CSC persistence, and test novel strategies (i.e., inhibiting FTO-m6A-lncRNAs to restore drug sensitivity) to eliminate CSCs. The findings will propel the design of new treatment options to achieve treatment-free remission improving cure rates and survival.

PHR: NARCH XII Capacity Building Project: Building Our Tribes’ Capacity to Initiate Community-Based  Research   Project Narrative  Tribal research sovereignty will not be realized until Tribes are self-empowered to fully manage the research  process ranging from problem identification to implementation, analysis, and dissemination. Tribally-initiated  projects are more likely to address the structural causes of disparities and Tribal solutions are more likely to be  sustained within the community. The ITCA Capacity Building project aims to provide Tribe-specific and  culturally-relevant mentorship to support Tribal projects as they are conceived within the Tribal community  through mentorship and technical assistance of the American Indian Research Center for Health (AIRCH) and  collaborative partners with expertise in Tribal research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of this R50 project are to support ongoing NCI-funded research projects to 1) to use immunogenomic analyses of spatially mapped brain tumor samples spanning maximal tumor volume to discover tumor-wide neoantigens that elicit immune responses, and which can be used to develop a platform for personalized immunotherapies for brain tumor patients; and 2) to understand the mechanism by which tumor cells with the TERT promoter mutation acquire the ability to proliferate indefinitely (cellular immortality) in order to develop targeted therapies for the large number of human tumors with this mutation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Vaccines are emerging as novel strategies for treating OUD and preventing fatal overdose. To accelerate the clinical utility of conjugate vaccines, we are developing next-generation anti-opioid vaccines using cutting-edge nanotechnology-based platforms. Exploiting the modular nature of nanoparticle platforms, this proposal focuses on characterizing the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying vaccine efficacy to provide a blueprint for vaccine development and rational design of most effective formulation to a given antigen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Stanford Genome Training Program trains PhD students and postdoctoral fellows to advance to productive technical and high-level leadership positions in the biomedical sciences, in academia and in the private sector. Specifically, we train the next generation of scientists in the field of genomics and related areas, which has become a centerpiece in understanding basic biology as well as disease diagnosis and prevention, due to tremendous technical advances and a confluence of computer science with biomedicine. Many of those advances were catalyzed and driven by our former trainees and those of similar institutions.

PROJECT_TITLE: Institutional Training Grant in Genome Science

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Diffuse midline glioma (DMG) and recurrent malignant brain tumors represent a high unmet need with essentially no long-term survivors. This project includes a phase 0/1 clinical trial assessing for the first time the mitochondrial targeting agent ONC206 in children with newly diagnosed and recurrent disease, alone and in combination with radiotherapy. For each trial participant we will collect tumor tissue, blood and CSF for pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic and genomic profiling with the hypothesis that ONC206 is safe, crosses the blood brain and blood tumor barrier, and targets mitochondrial ClpP protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasma cell-free hemoglobin (CFH) is increased in sepsis patients and damages the endothelial glycocalyx, a regulator of vascular permeability, but the mechanisms that underlie CFH-mediated glycocalyx injury remain unclear. This proposal will determine the molecular processes through which CFH promotes degradation of the endothelial glycocalyx. The insights gained will aid in the identification of specific targets to guide the development of improved treatments for patients with sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Neural signaling is a key regulator of cardiac proliferation, and disrupted neuron to heart signaling is implicated in cardiac disorders. I propose to illuminate the role of neural signaling during cardiac development by focusing on the role of a conserved neuropeptide known to be implicated in cardiac disease. This proposal will reveal fundamental mechanisms of heart development and result in a better understanding of cardiomyocyte proliferation and the functions of neuropeptides during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative We study the mTORC1 pathway, which is one of the most commonly dysregulated pathways in many cancers with low survival rates. Although inhibiting the key player mTORC1 has decreased tumor size in several models of cancer, our understanding of how different pools of mTORC1 contribute to cancer is limited. Our proposed study should lead to a better understanding of tumor growth and drug resistance in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The limited fundamental understanding of cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying complex behaviors poses a major barrier for development of effective clinical applications to treat mental disorders. If successful, our research will significantly advance our fundamental understanding of epigenetic regulation of neuronal circuits controlling stress responses, and ultimately help pave the way for improving mental health in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate a novel mechanism of the YAP signaling activation facilitated by the PR55α-regulated PP2A and define the contribution of this cascade to pancreatic cancer (PC) development and progression driven by oncogenic Kras and loss of p53 tumor suppressor. The project will use a multidisciplinary approach, including in vitro cell-based models of PC progression, clinical specimens of primary/metastatic PC, and spontaneous mouse models of PC, to comprehensively delineate this novel PC-promoting mechanism based on the PR55α/YAP axis. Successful completion of the proposed project not only will improve our understanding of the role of PP2A in cancer but also will contribute to identifying novel therapeutic targets for improving the treatment of PC and possibly other Kras-driving malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypertension is one of the leading contributors of excess risk of heart attacks and strokes among the 36 million people living with HIV (PLWHIV) globally. The hypertension care cascade among PLWHIV has major deficits when compared to the HIV care cascade of 90:90:90. Our proposed study, to be conducted Botswana, will leverage a successful national ART program and infrastructure of a recently completed CDC/NIH funded HIV prevention trial to first develop an implementation strategy, and then use the new implementation strategy to conduct a type 2 hybrid multi-component cluster randomized trial to optimize evidence based implementation (EBI) uptake and improvement in the hypertension cascade among adults with dual diagnosis of HIV and Hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension remains a major public health issue in the United States and contributes to the development of cardiovascular diseases (CVD) and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). Women older than 60 are at a particularly greater risk for the development of hypertension yet have a proportionally lower rate of blood pressure control, drastically increasing the likelihood for complications related to CVD and ADRD. Accordingly, the proposed work will investigate the impact of a home-based, lower leg heat therapy on blood pressure control in older, hypertensive women, while simultaneously assessing the autonomic cardiovascular mechanisms related to blood pressure regulation and their impact on cerebrovascular function and cognitive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will investigate the role of contractile pericyte KATP hyperactivity in a well- established genetic mouse model of cerebral small vessel disease (SVD). The results from this project will provide mechanistic insights in the field involving pericyte participation during cerebral blood flow regulation. Furthermore, the proposed experiments will help to introduce new therapeutic targets focusing on early disease manifestations as SVDs currently have no cure and limited treatment options.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. This study challenges the current explanation for ERV-triggered sterility by exploring a previously uncharacterized mechanism centered on immune response activation. On a greater scale, these findings may provide insight into areas of human health where ERVs may be active, such as in instances of aging and cancer as well as at specific stages of development. Despite making up 8% of the human genome, much is still to be learned about how ERVs function and impact human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There is an urgent need to reduce the high prevalence and unequal distribution of weight-related problems, including obesity, poor dietary intake, inadequate physical activity, body dissatisfaction, and disordered eating behaviors. It is essential to train the next generation of scientists in how to conduct innovative and impactful research to ensure positive weight-related health among youth and families from diverse communities. There is a clear need for the proposed training program, which will utilize a health equity lens to address a broad spectrum of weight-related problems across critical periods of the life course and ensure that future scientists are trained in both observational and intervention research and in translating research into action.

PROJECT_TITLE: Research on Eating and Activity for Community Health (REACH): An Applied Epidemiology Training Program to Improve Weight-Related Health in Youth and Families from Diverse Communities
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(JA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The retina is a highly organized tissue specialized for receiving and processing external stimuli from the visual scene. Efforts to treat retinopathy through regenerative procedures have been largely limited due to a lack of precise understanding about how retina formation is regulated during embryonic development. Here, I propose to combine novel experimental and computational approaches to comprehensively determine the cell fate decision programs that drive regular patterning during retina development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: || Project Narrative Lifesaving surgeries in blood vessels of the heart often fail due to poor or delayed healing of cells lining the blood vessel wall, putting patients at risk for stroke, heart attack, and death. My proposal aims to understand what controls the cells during healing and to identify ways to improve blood vessel repair. In the long term, my research aims to provide information that could be used to create therapies to reduce disease burden and increase patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social interactions between individuals are the hallmark of human society, defined to be a dynamical process shaped by the neural and behavioral processes of all participating individuals — yet traditional approaches to investigate social behaviors mainly focus on the neural processes within a single individual. Through a multi- brain approach that integrates a novel machine-learning approach with state-of-the-art calcium imaging, this project aims to characterize inter-brain synchrony (inter-brain neural correlation) at higher dimensions, thus capturing the dynamical inter-animal properties during social interaction. Through the proposed approach, this research will uncover novel and impactful insights on how inter-brain synchrony emerges across genetically- defined neuronal subpopulations in the medial prefrontal cortex during social interaction, and how this property is altered in Autism Spectrum Disorder — a neurodevelopmental disorder strongly marked by impaired social interaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many consider proton beam radiotherapy (PBRT) to be a promising treatment for children with brain tumors as it may preserve cognitive functioning without sacrificing disease control. This will be the first large-scale study to prospectively compare symptom burden, treatment toxicity, and neurocognitive change between patients treated with PBRT vs. conventional photon radiotherapy on comparable treatment protocols and to assess important measures of daily functioning that will quantify the clinical significance of any differences identified between groups in survivorship. Ultimately, this line of research is intended to: (1) help physicians and families better understand the relative effect of PBRT on symptoms and neurocognitive functioning to inform treatment decisions, and (2) provide functional outcome data to be used toward justifying or reconciling the high cost and access limitations currently associated with PBRT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This renewal application seeks support for the infrastructure maintenance of the Multiethnic Cohort (MEC) Study, established in 1993-1996, to continue a well-integrated program of research testing innovative hypotheses aimed at ensuring that racial/ethnic disparities are investigated and progress in disease prevention applies to major US racial/ethnic minorities. By including 215,251 men and women mostly of 5 racial/ethnic populations (African Americans, Japanese Americans, Latinos, Native Hawaiians and Whites), the MEC is the most racially and ethnically diverse cancer cohort, and its value for etiologic research on chronic diseases is widely recognized. Leadership of the MEC entails a highly interactive, team-science approach; investigators have amply demonstrated willingness to share data and samples.

PHR: NARRATIVE We propose a 12-week Buffalo Research Innovation in Genomic and Healthcare Technology (BRIGHT) short-term training and education program at the University at Buffalo’s Jacobs School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences in the Department of Biomedical Informatics. Every year this program will host 12 top undergraduate and master’s candidates for intensive training in Biomedical Informatics and Data Science involving didactics, hands-on research, and career development activities. Our overall objective is to recruit and train diverse undergraduate and masters’ students to prepare them for future careers in Biomedical Informatics and Data Science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Roughly one-third of the 500,000 patients who undergo cardiac surgery in the U.S. annually will develop postoperative delirium, and another 25% develop acute kidney injury. Each of these organ dysfunctions is associated with worse clinical outcomes. Impaired vascular reactivity may be an important underlying mechanism to the development of perioperative brain and kidney injury that is currently not routinely addressed in clinical care. This study will randomize cardiac surgery patients to a soluble guanylyl cyclase stimulator which may enhance vascular reactivity, and measure effects on vascular reactivity and cellular markers of neuronal and renal tubule injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Project Narrative) Alcohol Use Disorder is a complex spectrum disorder that presents significant unmet clinical treatment challenges. Accumulating evidence indicates that the action of ethanol on the innate immune system leads to chronification of risky drinking, potential physical dependence, and often dangerous withdrawal symptoms. The proposed project is a collaboration with NIAAA’s Division of Medications Development and addresses creation of manufacturing standards for two lead compounds and IND enabling studies for FDA approval for a Phase I clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Multiracial discrimination may be driving alcohol-related risks and disparities among Multiracial young adults; however, fragmented knowledge about Multiracial discrimination and measurement concerns disallows alcohol researchers to test the Multiracial discrimination-alcohol misuse pathway. Using a sequential mixed methods approach, the proposed project will develop and psychometrically validate a Multiracial Discrimination Scale as informed by Multiracial young adults’ experiences of Multiracial discrimination, and test concurrent associations of Multiracial discrimination with alcohol misuse. The findings of this project will provide a psychometrically sound scale for alcohol researchers to investigate Multiracial discrimination as a sociocultural determinant of alcohol misuse, which in turn may further inform culturally sensitive intervention research to reduce and prevent alcohol misuse among Multiracial young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Atrial fibrillation is the most common heart rhythm disorder in older adults, and it substantially increases the risk of disabling strokes. Anticoagulant treatment reduces the risk of stroke but increases the likelihood of disabling bleeding events. We lack a way to individualize treatment decisions for older adults—this proposal will use multiple studies to better define the individual risk and benefits of anticoagulants in older adults with atrial fibrillation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Platelet activation due to cold temperatures has important implications for public health. Platelets for transfusion are currently stored at room temperature, which maximizes circulation time, but reduces function, limits storage time, facilitates bacterial growth and thereby increases the risk for sepsis. By investigating the underlying mechanism for the response of platelets to cold temperatures and by examining the role of TRPM8 for platelet cold‐storage and platelet function after transfusion in humans we will open up avenues for increasing the availability, safety, and quality of platelet transfusions in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative As the senior research scientist, I am leading the research in Dr. Binghui Shen’s NCI-sponsored research programs to define the function of structure-specific nucleases in maintaining genome integrity for cancer suppression. My research will define etiological mechanisms by which human mutations that cause functional deficiency of these nucleases promote cancer development. Such important new knowledge will inform future development of personalized chemoprevention or chemotherapy drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The androgen receptor is a type I nuclear hormone receptor and master transcription factor responsible for differentiation and development of the male phenotype. Its hyperactivation is associated with multiple diseases, including metastatic prostate cancer, androgenetic alopecia, androgen insensitivity syndrome, and Kennedy’s disease. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanism of androgen receptor regulation and determinants of its aberrant activity using biochemical, structural, and cellular methods, which can facilitate the development of novel androgen receptor inhibitors and lend mechanistic insight towards other related nuclear hormone receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative Over 20 million people suffer from bilateral cataracts in the U.S., which is projected to double by 2050 (NEI); age-related cataract represents 48%, while diabetes, smoking, alcohol consumption, etc., add to the risk and related healthcare costs. The studies outlined in this research proposal will provide novel insights into the molecular mechanisms by which lens membrane channels AQP0, AQP1 and AQP5, and cytosolic GPX1 enzyme protect the lens from oxidative damage to maintain lens transparency, refractive index gradient, microcirculation and homeostasis, and how aging causes abnormal optical aberrations and cataract. The molecular understanding envisaged and the data that will be collected will have the potential to aid in developing therapeutic strategies to delay, treat or prevent age-related cataracts to improve the quality of life for millions and reduce healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low statin adherence and early discontinuation is too common, and it results in substantially increase risks of experiencing atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) events. Statin-associated muscle symptoms (SAMS), a spectrum of muscle symptoms the patient perceives as intolerable enough to impair daily activities and quality of life, is a major, yet manageable cause of low statin adherence and early discontinuation. We propose to evaluate a novel, multicomponent technology embedded within a team-based health service to empower patients with SAMS to self-manage their statin therapy to ultimately increase statin adherence and persistence and, thereby, ultimately reduce ASCVD risk among patients with SAMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional dyspepsia (FD) is a chronic gastrointestinal functional/motility disorder which frequently poses detrimental and problematic eating-related medical consequences (e.g., significant weight loss, malnutrition) with avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID) present in up to 40% of adults with FD. While treatment options for FD are limited, presence of problematic avoidant/restrictive food intake has not yet been explored to inform treatment approaches and our team’s uncontrolled pilot data suggest that an exposure-based cognitive-behavioral treatment can improve FD outcomes. The proposed multi-disciplinary study aims to determine the role of problematic avoidant/restrictive food intake by (1) comparing gastric sensorimotor functions and satiety hormones among adults with FD and ARFID, FD without ARFID, and healthy controls, and (2) testing the proof-of-concept of an exposure-based cognitive-behavioral treatment in a pilot randomized controlled trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulation of gene expression and cell differentiation by pioneer transcription factors and epigenetic factors is a major focus in cancer epigenetics because of the master regulator function of pioneer factors and the reversible nature of epigenetic alterations. Recent advances in understanding epigenetic factors have led to the emergence of epigenetic therapy and the recent FDA approval of multiple epigenetic drugs. This proposal uses a combination of in vitro biochemical, biophysical and single molecule methods, combined with in vivo genetic and cell biology approaches to reveal the molecular mechanisms behind the function of pioneer factors and these chromatin epigenetic regulators. Our studies will provide molecular information for understanding drug resistance, tumorigenesis and will help designing new drugs and therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The work in this proposal will characterize the novel signaling activity through Dock7 that maintains low, but sustained AKT activity that is essential for transformation and cell survival under stressful conditions. The mechanistic insights into the assembly, function, and location of the Dock7/AKT/mTOR signaling complex from this work will provide a better understanding of the signaling activity and metabolism of cancer cells that drive tumorigenesis. Characterization of this novel signaling activity will aid in the treatment and management of cancer by supporting the identification of new potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reducing the global disparities in cervical cancer – which is an entirely preventable disease – requires scale- up of available preventive interventions such as HPV vaccination and screening. Biomedical research has successfully developed technologies required to meet this demand; now we must complement this success with development of processes and tools to help countries adopt and integrate these prevention strategies into their routine public health services. Our project builds on a successful application of stakeholder-engaged systems thinking by developing the ASSIST (Adaptation, ScaleUp, Sustainability: Implementation by Systems Thinking) implementation strategy and toolkit, designed to enable countries to adapt and plan for HPV-based screening according to their own context, resources, preferences, and values.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE I have led many of the genetic studies of breast cancer predisposition with the goal of providing improved hereditary cancer genetic testing and personalized risk assessment for the population. Here I outline my vision for advancing the field of breast cancer predisposition through a series of translational studies that will result in improved risk estimation and determination of the value of directed therapy for many of these individuals. These studies represent a significant step towards eliminating many of the issues faced by patients receiving clinical genetic testing for breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This community-engaged study seeks to improve research results dissemination for American Indian and Alaska Native communities through co-designing collaborative technology systems. American Indian & Alaska Native people have experienced a history of distrustful health research such as being exposed to procedures without informed consent and having research results disseminated without community input or approval making community research collaboration critical from project conceptualization to results dissemination. Results from this study will inform future development of culturally responsive collaborative technology systems for health research results dissemination for use with marginalized communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Several anemias, are caused in part by pathologic iron sequestration. In these conditions, chronic immune activation or genetic mutations upregulate the Fe regulating hormone hepcidin, which inhibits the mechanism by which bioavailable iron is mobilized to the extracellular iron-carrier protein transferrin for distribution. Anemia correction in the presence of hepcidin excess can be challenging, as hepcidin-driven iron sequestration also limits the efficacy of iron administered through replacement therapy or nutritional supplementation. This proposal is to develop a new class of direct-to-transferrin iron replacement therapy to efficiently and safely replace iron in anemias with hepcidin excess.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent obesity is a major medical and public health concern. Daily self-weighing for weight management has been shown to be effective and safe for weight loss in adults, with no negative psychologic effects, but has not been assessed for weight loss and safety in adolescents with obesity seeking obesity treatment. This proposal will assess patient, parent, and provider perspectives on daily self-weighing on scales connected to clinic adolescents seeking obesity treatment, and use these perspectives to design and conduct a pilot study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will assess barriers to guideline-concordant breast cancer care in Nigeria, and methodically develop and evaluate implementation strategies to promote guideline adoption. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to improve the evidence-based treatment of breast cancer, the leading cause of cancer-related death for women in Nigeria. The results of this work will generate fundamental knowledge and strategies to inform healthcare leaders and policymakers about effective methods to facilitate adoption of evidence-based cancer care in resource-limited settings, thereby promoting treatment that improves survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hundreds of thousands of American adults survive Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) each year, but at least half have persistent muscle weakness that results in increased disability, healthcare costs, and mortality. The project aims to improve long-term physical function in ARDS survivors by elucidating pathobiological processes that differ between ARDS survivors who recovery physically and those who do not as novel treatment targets for post-ICU clinic based trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alaska Native and American Indian (ANAI) people in the state of Alaska are twice as likely as the general population to contract SARS-CoV-2, are at elevated risk for hospitalization and death from COVID-19, and vaccination remains low. To increase COVID-19 vaccine uptake among ANAI people in Alaska we will train and support ANAI community members to serve as community vaccine advocates by providing information, motivational strategies, and Web-based tools to help them talk with vaccine-hesitant friends and family about COVID-19 vaccines. Broader applicability includes the development of new approaches to vaccine outreach and engagement in ANAI communities, one that leverages peer relationships, social networks, and eHealth to promote health education and behavior change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Proper regulation of inflammation within bone is critical for preventing disease and healing from injury. A dysregulated immune response becomes more prevalent in elderly populations and results in a susceptibility to numerous conditions, including periodontal disease. The goal of this project is to understand the age-related perturbations that occur to the cellular and molecular regulators of the innate immune response in bone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have systematically investigated how visual perception –discriminability– varies across the visual field, along eccentricity and across polar angle. Here, we propose to investigate how and why these differences come about; i.e., the neural and computational mechanisms underlying the differential effects across eccentricity and polar angle. These results will establish normative data sets on adults’ perception and neuroimaging as a function of stimulus location in the visual field, enabling comparison with patient populations (e.g., ADHD and autism), and advance our knowledge of neural and computational mechanisms responsible for visual perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tricuspid regurgitation is associated with a significant risk of morbidity and mortality in children with Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome (HLHS). However, the underlying mechanisms of tricuspid regurgitation remain unclear given the limitations in obtaining appropriate tricuspid valve tissue properties and morphologies. The proposed study will leverage physics-informed machine learning and 3D echocardiography- derived finite element modeling to develop patient-specific tricuspid valve models that will be used to delineate the cause of tricuspid valve regurgitation in a small cohort of HLHS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulating the amount of water inside a cell is critical for all cells, and mutations water transporting channels cause severe diseases. However, there are currently no precise and non-invasive methods to measure the water content of single cells, and we are proposing solve this lack of research tools by developing a non-invasive method for directly measuring the absolute and fractional (v/v) water content of a single cell or an organoid. This method will enable novel basic and biomedical research that will increase our understanding of water content regulation in health and disease, and provide a new platform for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Only some people are tempted to experiment with drugs of abuse, and only a portion of them become true addicts. To understand the genetic and environmental reasons behind a person's vulnerability to addiction, we used selective breeding to generate two lines of rats that differ significantly in their tendency to experiment with drugs and become addicted.  In this project, we use state of the art genetic and genomic techniques to discover the genetic and brain causes of their differences and provide insights into the biology of addiction in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Project Narrative Maintaining normal lung function and inducing repair of damaged lung can be markedly improved if we better understand the cellular and molecular complexities of the organ. It is the goal of HuBMAP and of this Lung Tissue Mapping Center to generate findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable, interactive, and annotated maps of structure, cell type and cell subtype, integrated into a reference atlas of healthy lung to which diseased lung can be compared, ultimately to identify mechanisms of disease and therapeutic interventions for a major public health concern, the ability to breathe.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Genomic mapping of chromatin features including histone post-translational modifications, chromatin- associated proteins, and DNA methylation is a powerful approach for biomedical research and drug development. Current genomics assays rely on second generation short-read sequencing, wherein short reads limit the ability to analyze concordance of epigenomic features on a single molecule and preclude analysis of repetitive genomic regions. Here, EpiCypher is developing the first commercial genomic mapping approach that leverages long-read sequencing, a multiomic platform that will enable deconvolution of heterogeneity from mixed samples and mapping into challenging genomic regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This application describes the development of a novel mouse model that allows the visualization of cancer formation at its earliest stages, as well as the visual monitoring of immune evasion by cancer cells. This model will be used to test the possibility of activating the immune system to eliminate cancers at an early stage before they progress to overt tumors. This model may also allow the discovery of novel immunotherapy targets for treating patients who do not respond to current generation immunotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal outlines a plan to develop the technology for measuring the Optoretinogram, or ORG: the all- optical recording of functional activity of retinal neurons and their connections in a living eye. We employ a unique combination of technologies (OCT, adaptive optics, interferometry, eye-tracking) that together enable in vivo access to the early visual processing elements in the retina in humans. In the end, we envision powerful, clinically deployable tools suited to test and accelerate the new generation of treatments aimed at regenerating neurons and neural connections in the eye and visual system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will provide novel Bayesian statistical models for complex clinical trials data analysis. The aims are to select and verify personalized treatment using patient-derived organoids (PDO) and the paired clinical outcome, identify subgroup-speciﬁc optimal doses for biotherapies by synthesizing information across multi-dimensional heterogeneous data, assess treatment effects of master protocol trials by integrating the con- current and non-concurrent control response outcomes, and provide freely available user-friendly R Shiny apps for both trial design and data analysis to facilitate the broad application of the proposed methods. The overarch- ing goal is to provide efﬁcient and ﬂexible statistical tools to tackle critical and practical data integration problems identiﬁed during the development and conduct of complex clinical trials with heterogeneous health-related data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Nicotine level is a key product characteristic of modern e-cigarette products. The proposed study seeks to examine the effects of e-liquid nicotine concentration levels and vaping devices on between- subjects differences in biomarkers of exposure to tobacco-related toxicants and within-subjects transitions in ENDS-Cigarette and nicotine dependence. Findings from this study can have important implications for future tobacco regulatory sciences of vaping products at the population level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current observational evidence of the association between vaping and smoking cessation using national longitudinal data sources (e.g., the PATH study) may provide insufficient temporal precision due to the long inter- survey intervals (e.g., 12-month) in which many smokers may make multiple quit attempts and vacillate between abstinence and smoking. Leveraging the nationally-representative longitudinal panel survey of US adults with 26 bi-weekly survey waves (April 2020 - July 2021) and nine additional monthly follow-up surveys (October 2021 - June 2022), this study aims to investigate short- and long-term prospective associations of time-varying nicotine vaping with time-lagged smoking abstinences in follow-up extending up to 110 weeks after baseline as well as mediational effects of anxiety/depression symptoms on vaping-related smoking cessation. The proposed study will address the fundamental questions of whether vaping encourages smokers to initiate and sustain smoking cessation in the real world, and if they experience cessation-related mental health benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: P50 Narrative PD: Pascual, V. The Weill Cornell/JAX-GM Cooperative Center of Research Translation entitled “Center for Lupus Research” (CRL) aims i) to advance the knowledge of pathways that contribute to the establishment and amplification of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), ii) to identify molecular mechanisms responsible for the failure to respond to standard of care (SOC) therapies, and iii) to develop assays and tools to monitor these dysfunctional pathways. Novel genomic technologies and bioinformatic resources will be used towards these goals, which will advance clinical trial design and ultimately personalized patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) is a serious clinical problem that affects ~20% of hospitalized patients and 60% of critically ill patients while increasing risk of developing chronic kidney disease. The overall goal of this project is to understand cellular and molecular mechanisms that govern how kidney resident macrophages (KRMs) maintain and restore renal function after injury. Understanding the involvement of the various KRM subpopulations and of C1q, one of the most abundant proteins produced by KRMs, will have a significant impact on our understanding of mechanisms that can be targeted for the treatment of AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In recent years, neuroscientists have increasingly come to appreciate the importance of understanding how the spatiotemporal organization of large-scale neural activity patterns influences perception, cognition, and motor control. Our project focuses on intrinsic traveling voltage waves (iTWs) in the mouse and marmoset sensory neocortex, how these waves may influence perceptual sensitivity and mammalian visual behavior, and the contributions of specific cortical neuron-types to these phenomena. To examine these issues, our research team comprises experts in visual neurophysiology and behavior, inventors of novel optical voltage-imaging and electrophysiological recording techniques, data scientists innovating advanced statistical analysis methods, and computational neuroscientists whose models of iTWs provide specific predictions that we will test empirically in mice and marmosets performing a visual detection task.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the leading cause of central vision loss in individuals 60 and older. Yet, the disease mechanisms underlying loss of lipid homeostasis and inflammation in the RPE/choroid remain elusive. In this proposal, we will define key molecular mechanisms by which choroidal macrophages influence lipid metabolism, immunomodulation, and neovascularization in the RPE/choroid during AMD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is an increasingly common cardiovascular disease that significantly impairs physical abilities and has a poor long-term survival. As HFpEF is challenging to diagnose non-invasively and has no effective treatment strategies, this study seeks to use a novel cardiopulmonary exercise MRI protocol, involving supine ergometry, to accurately diagnose early stages of HFpEF and identify specific markers to better understand HFpEF progression and predict adverse cardiovascular health outcomes. The information gained from this study will improve diagnosis and prognosis for patients with HFpEF and eliminate the need for invasive hemodynamic cardiopulmonary exercise testing (iCPET), which is the current more costly, risky, and invasive diagnostic testing method.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: This proposal will address a pressing public health concern, namely, the epidemic of ‘youth’ vaping. The studies described in this proposal will investigate the largely unknown health consequences of youth vaping by measuring molecular changes linked to risk of disease in tissues and cells of healthy youth who are regular users of electronic cigarettes (e-cigs). The findings of this project are expected to be of immediate use for the regulatory agencies who are in urgent need of scientific evidence informing the regulation of the manufacture, distribution, and marketing of e-cigs to protect youth and promote public health.

PHR: Project Narrative This program will prepare the next generation of scientists, medical doctors, and future leaders to solve the most pressing health issues within our diverse community. In this program, 10 young scholars will receive two years of in-depth training and guidance from experienced scientists, physicians and community mentors who will help them become outstanding independent researchers. This program is designed to meet the national need of increasing the number of scientists from diverse backgrounds to better reflect and serve our communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a common optic nerve disease for which clinical risk factors (such as high intraocular pressure) and therapies (such as pressure lowering drugs) have been evaluated by NIH- funded studies, such as the Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study (OHTS). In this research project, we will analyze clinical and genome-wide-association study data from the OHTS cohort to create a risk calculator for incident POAG as well as to identify genetic risk factors for rapidly progressing POAG. We will also investigate the function of top POAG genetic risk factors to identify how they specifically promote disease, which will reveal disease mechanisms; identify relevant biological pathways; and inform development of future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  FSU aims to develop, implement, and evaluate a program, Fostering Institutional Resources for Science Transformation: The FLORIDA-FIRST Health-Science Brigade (aka The FLORIDA-FIRST Brigade), to transform culture at FSU to generate a self-sustaining scientific community dedicated to diversity, equity, and inclusive excellence. We propose leveraging institutional resources to recruit a FIRST Cohort of 6 early-career, URM biomedical researchers who demonstrate a commitment to diversity and inclusive excellence and who contribute to clusters of research excellence in chronic disease prevention and management (Cluster 1) or mental health (Cluster 2) and to implement a systems-level approach and generate evidence of its effectiveness for supporting individual faculty research and career development (micro), within their cohort and collaborative networks (meso), that can be replicated through sustainable changes to university culture (macro).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: OVERVIEW: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite a strong evidence base for diabetes prevention and care, significant gaps remain in equitably translating these research findings into real life policy and practice; the overall burdens and costs continue to grow rapidly, with the minorities and socioeconomically disadvantaged groups in the Southeastern U.S. disproportionately affected. To address these gaps, we propose the Georgia Center for Diabetes Translation Research (GCDTR) with the vision of promoting equity through high-quality translation research and a culture of evidence based decision-making across academic, health system, community, and local government partners in Georgia, Florida, and Tennessee. GCDTR will serve as a platform to increase investigator capacity, share expertise, and generate and disseminate knowledge to influence practice and policy to improve diabetes outcomes and health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Neuroligins are specialized neural cell adhesion molecules that are found in synapses, the functional interfaces between neurons in the brain. Mutations in these proteins and their binding partners cause neuropsychiatric diseases, including autism spectrum disorders and schizophrenia. Here, we propose to investigate the how Neuroligins regulate synaptic function in mice and human neurons.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Teleneonatology is an innovative program that uses real-time audio-video telemedicine to connect doctors with expertise in newborn resuscitation with teams caring for at-risk babies born in small, community hospitals. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will contribute new knowledge about the impact teleneonatology has on early newborn death and disability, and the quality of delivery room care – which are relevant, important patient and family measures for the 10,000-15,000 at-risk newborns each year who experience poorer outcomes because of the current problem. Thus, the project is relevant to the NICHD mission to enhance the lives of newborns and optimize abilities for all, while also addressing the cross-cutting topic of health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Visual experience during the critical period is crucial for the proper development and wiring of the visual cortex. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate how astrocytes -- a glial cell type that acts as a regulator of neuronal homeostasis, physiology, and plasticity-- regulate the visual critical period. This has important implications for identifying key therapeutic targets to create an environment favorable to remodeling and plasticity after synapse loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal focuses on elucidating the genetic determinants and mechanisms underlying immune checkpoint blockade therapy efficacy and resistance. We propose to use a combination of systematic large-scale genomics, preclinical animal modeling, integrated immunogenomics profiling, and mechanism-directed immunologic analyses to establish a robust understanding of sensitivity and resistance to immune checkpoint blockade. Our studies will build the foundation for the precise and individual application on immunotherapy for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and deadliest primary brain tumor, and current standard-of-care has demonstrated limited success. We propose to develop a novel peptide-platinum(IV) drug conjugate that can selectively recognize and target GBM tumors. Findings from this proposal could ultimately benefit GBM patients in the clinic through extending survival and improving quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism and ADHD often deal with sensory processing issues that disrupt their daily lives, likely due to a failure in the attentional mechanism that selectively prioritizes a subset of sensory information, but the underlying cause of these issues is poorly understood because of gaps in our understanding of basic attentional mechanisms. By elucidating fundamental neural mechanisms of attention in multisensory contexts, results from the proposed research will lead to a better understanding of sensory processing issues and, ultimately, could lead to treatments that help patients better manage sensory stimuli.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Jointly led by the University of Chicago and Northwestern University, the Chicago Center for Diabetes Translation Research (CCDTR) will provide core resources in Intervention Design and Implementation Science; Research Design, Data, and Analytics; Community Engagement and Health Equity; and Accelerating Health Equity And Eliminating Diabetes Disparities in Community Health Centers (AHEAD-CHC) that catalyze and support innovative and rigorous translational research to advance health equity for the prevention and management of diabetes. The CCDTR will increase the impact of rigorous diabetes translational research to reduce disparities in Chicago and the nation by organizing partnerships across academic institutions and stakeholder groups into working groups that include: Clinician-Patient Relationship and Shared Decision Making, Social Determinants of Health, Diabetes Prevention, Diabetes Modeling, Organization and Financing of Care (focusing in Community Health Centers and Medicaid), Diabetes and Aging. The CCDTR will attract and support diverse investigators who are new to the area of diabetes translational research by providing education, training, mentoring, support for community and stakeholder engagement, pilot and feasibility seed grants, and access to critical translational research core resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative. Cancer is a systemic disease and conventional treatment strategies that are administered systemically, ultimately fail due to an inability to achieve antitumor efficacy at tolerable doses for the patient. Cytonus has developed a first-in-class, precision delivery platform, called CargocytesTM, that is a safe and effective means to target therapeutic drugs to primary and secondary tumors. In this phase II study, we will evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of systemically-delivered, locally-active, membrane-tethered or secreted IL-12 to induce durable systemic antitumor and antimetastatic immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The mammalian brain is the most energy efficient, compact, adaptable, intelligent system that we know and understanding it will have a profound impact in our society, technology, economy and mental health. Critical to this understanding is the knowledge about the synaptic structure of neural circuits because it provides strong constraints on the nature of the computations the brain performs, as well as knowledge of gene expression because it provides constraints on how this structure is built and operates. The goal of the proposed research is to create the technologies to scale synapse mapping to a whole mouse brain and integrate this knowledge with gene expression data using as biological model and feasibility test the Cortico-Thalamic-Basal-Ganglia loop.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) plan an essential role in the tumor microenvironment for numerous tumor types and may be important in the development of aggressive thyroid cancers such as anaplastic thyroid carcinomas (ATCs). In this proposal, we will study the role of CAFs, as well as their paracrine Wnt signaling, in ATCs using single-cell sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, novel thyroid cancer organoids with corresponding CAF cultures, and a patient-derived xenograft mouse model to discover potential new therapy for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adipose tissue is a promising target for treating obesity and metabolic diseases. However, pharmacological agents usually fail to engage adipocytes due to their extraordinary size and insufficient vascularization in obese subjects. We propose connecting adipocytes via Connexin43 gap junctions improves the efficacy of pharmacological agents targeting adipose tissue, and we will use FGF21 as an example to test this hypothesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The sixth renewal of the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston (UTHealth) School of Public Health training program builds on a 29-year track-record preparing fellows (many from underrepresented minority groups) to become independent, skilled, and principled cancer control scientists. The training program is designed to prepare cancer prevention and control researchers to fill evidence gaps about multi- level causes of cancer-related inequities; to develop and evaluate cancer control multilevel interventions (MLIs); and develop and test strategies to increase the adoption, implementation, sustainment, and scale up of effective interventions in community and health care settings. Ultimately, the long-term goal of the proposed training program is to reduce cancer morbidity and mortality and decrease cancer-related health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRI & TECH ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The post genomic era requires interdisciplinary collaborative technology-driven research built upon computational genomics, data sciences, and cloud computing. A lack of organized resources such as faculty trained in these disciplines, adequate computing resources, and the instrumentation for conducting genomic research has contributed to the STEM Talent deficit particularly among historically marginalized communities. Through the creation of the Genomic Research and Data Science Center for Computational Cloud-Computing (GRaDS-4C) we seek to provide the educational and hands-on research training and resources in computational genomics, data sciences, and cloud computing for the future workforce particularly among underserved student populations at NCA&TSU and other target HBCU/MSI institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell division is an essential process by which replicated chromosomes are equally segregated to daughter cells, however this process is prone to errors, which can result in chromosomal instability and lead to cancer and developmental diseases. There are potential molecular mechanisms contributing towards faithful chromosome segregation that have not yet been adequately explored, one of which is the evolution and maintenance of chromosome organization throughout mitosis. Our proposed work of defining the spatial organization of mitotic chromosomes and kinetochores required for accurate chromosome segregation using innovative imaging methods is of fundamental importance to public health because a clear understanding of the mechanisms underlying faithful chromosome segregation will contribute towards developing better therapeutic and detection strategies for cancer and developmental diseases for improved patient outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroscience is a rapidly evolving discipline that requires rigorous fundamental training to broaden our understanding of the nervous system and the many incurable and debilitating disorders that impact it. The goal of the proposed program is to provide doctoral students a comprehensive, multidisciplinary training program buoyed by strong quantitative and analytical training to produce the next generation of neuroscientists to tackle these important problems.
