IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose tightly integrated theory and experimentation to elucidate neural mechanisms of visually guided control of steering. Deficits in perceiving self-motion are among the earliest consequences of Alzheimer's disease, and can substantially impact patients' lives, including their ability to drive a vehicle. By understanding how optic flow processing is integrated with motor and memory signals to control steering, our work will reveal neural mechanisms by which Alzheimer’s disease may influence driving and how these deficits might be mitigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All genetic diseases and cancers ultimately begin with genetic variation or mutations, but not all genetic variants are pathogenic. Understanding the effects of these genetic variants on proteins is critical for determining which variants cause disease and which are part of background variation. We are developing bioinformatic and analytical tools for measuring proteins with variants in disease and applying them to study the health effects of carrying specific variants on protein misfolding in amyloidosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents diagnosed with asthma have difficulties consistently completing disease self-management behaviors (e.g., taking medications as prescribed, monitoring symptoms), placing them at elevated risk for suboptimal asthma control and impaired quality of life. The proposed project will evaluate a mobile health intervention that provides personalized and adaptive support to improve asthma self-management in adolescents with suboptimal control. If successful, our smartphone-based intervention has potential to improve health outcomes for many adolescents diagnosed with asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bariatric surgery is the most effective obesity treatment available, producing large and durable weight losses for a majority of patients. Unfortunately, 20-30% of patients who undergo bariatric surgery experiencer significant weight regain and recurrence of weight-related comorbidities. The proposed study will test the efficacy of a novel psychotherapeutic intervention, delivered remotely, to reverse weight regain and maintain the health benefits of bariatric surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The charitable food system, largely comprised of food banks and pantries, is a regular food source for up to 53 million people a year. The overall objective of this proposal is to use multi-level behavioral economics strategies to promote implementation of evidence-based interventions that will improve the dietary quality of food offered by pantries and selected and consumed by pantry clients. Results of this research will inform national and local hunger-relief organizations about the implementation of evidence-based nutrition interventions that can improve the diet and health of marginalized families at highest risk for obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE GlycoMira is developing a simple, minimally invasive, point-of-care test that can provide accurate diagnostic and prognostic information to healthcare providers and patients with eosinophilic chronic rhinosinusitis, a disease with an under-recognized burden on patient quality of life, clinical resources, and the healthcare economy. Patients with eCRS typically fail the standard of care and turn to costly surgical intervention and eosinophil- targeting biologic therapy to manage their disease. GlycoMira’s diagnostic test represents a promising objective measure by which to diagnose eosinophilic chronic rhinosinusitis, as well as to monitor patient response to medical and surgical treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An imbalance between caloric intake and output leads to excessive adipose tissue expansion and obesity, a major risk factor for the development of metabolic disease. Brown and beige adipocytes burn calories and have been considered possible therapeutic targets to fight obesity and metabolic disease also in humans. Here we propose to uncover novel mechanisms that govern adipose tissue function to ultimately devise novel therapeutic approaches to decrease metabolic dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Mounting evidence suggests that circulating extracellular vesicles and particles (EVPs) carry a variety of biological molecules and can serve as a reservoir of biomarkers for early cancer detection. In combination with our recently improved EVP isolation procedure and asymmetric-flow field-flow fractionation (AF4), we will further develop and validate the application of novel analytic technologies, including timsTOF 4D proteomic mass spectrometry, super-resolution dSTORM imaging analysis of single EVPs, and photocatalytic proximity labeling (µMap) technology for mapping protein-protein interactions, to discover and validate novel circulating EVP-borne biomarkers for early detection of pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this work is to promote more comprehensive voice assessment in routine clinical practice through the introduction of accurate, low-cost respiratory and aerodynamic measures via a uniquely designed vortex whistle and accompanying signal analysis software. The vortex whistle system is optimized for measures of vital capacity and mean phonatory airflow from sustained phonation that are essential to the clinical evaluation of voice. An optimized vortex whistle system will be evaluated as a noninferior alternative to “gold” standard clinical instrumentation that is often inaccessible due to several constraints such as high cost and limited portability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In primates, including humans, the central retina, especially the fovea, relies on the choroidal blood supply for metabolic and thermoregulatory support, but we know very little about the neuroanatomy or function of the autonomic pathways controlling primate choroidal blood flow. The proposed experiments constitute the first extensive and systematic investigation of the anatomy and physiology of the neural circuitry controlling the parasympathetic pathways supplying the choroidal vasculature of a primate. These results will set the stage for future studies in which this circuitry is modulated in order to improve the survival of central vision in models of macular degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Rheumatoid arthritis (RA), one of the most common rheumatic conditions, is characterized by chronic inflammation. We will examine the role of lipid mediators (products of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids that are known to regulate inflammation) in the development of RA, focusing on the preclinical period prior to the onset of RA. Results from this work will provide the foundation for designing future prevention approaches and studies by identifying the combinations of lipid mediators that play a role in inflammation resolution in preclinical RA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Due to an expansion in pediatric drug development research, there is an increasing need to train researchers with expertise in pediatric clinical pharmacology. This new application seeks to establish a “National Career Development Program for Researchers in Pediatric Clinical Pharmacology,” combining faculty expertise and resources across leading academic institutions with programs in pediatric clinical pharmacology. Upon completion of the career development training, scholars will be exceptionally well positioned to pursue impactful careers focused on promoting the safe and effective use of medications in children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intimate partner violence includes assault to the head, neck, and face, with approximately 90% of survivors reporting symptoms concordant with persistent post-concussion symptoms, wherein pregnancy is associated with increased intensity and frequency of physical assault. Like stress, drugs, and inflammation, traumatic brain injury (TBI) during pregnancy can increase the environmental risk for neurodevelopmental disorders in the children. The proposal extends strong proof-of-principle results to explore the outcomes of gravida TBI in mice on the neurobehavioral, neurocircuitry, and molecular phenotypes of offspring to better inform science, education, and policy making.

PHR: OVERALL: NARRATIVE This is a new application for the DC-IDDRC, the District of Columbia Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities Research Center. The DC-IDDRC is dedicated to improving the lives of individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDDs) and their families by creating a strong translational research environment optimized for studying and defining the basic causes and mechanisms underlying IDDs, and designing new effective treatments and prevention strategies. To realize this mission, we provide a rich environment for performing fully translational IDD research in the four collaborating DC academic medical centers (Children’s National Hospital (lead), George Washington University, Howard University, and Georgetown University).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mechanical properties and forces the body are often modulated during disease initiation and progression. However, little is known about the response of immune cells to these mechanical cues, particularly at the tissue- length scale, and even in normal physiological settings. Establishing an omics-based understanding of functional immunological changes in response to mechanical perturbations will broaden our knowledge of “mechano- immunology” – a burgeoning subfield in basic biomedical sciences that in the near future will reveal new pathophysiological insights and targetable vulnerabilities for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has a highly detrimental impact on morbidity and mortality in surgical patients or following infections with pathogens, such as during the recent COVID-19 pandemic. Studies from our laboratory revealed that alveolar epithelial hypoxia-inducible factor HIF1A stabilization provides lung protection and is controlled by HIF-prolylhydroxylases (three isoforms exist, PHD1-3). We provide evidence that alveolar-epithelial PHD1 selectively controls HIF responses during ARDS and our proposed treatment approaches will enhance levels of HIF1A with concomitant lung protection during conventional ARDS or ARDS caused by SARS-CoV-2 infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of the mechanisms by which prematurity alters muscle growth and the identification of nutritional interventions to improve lean growth brings basic research closer to the translational level of improving the nutritional support of preterm infants. Thus, the proposed research that will use the preterm piglet as a model of the human preterm infant is relevant to the mission of the NIH as it will provide fundamental new knowledge on how the nutritional management of preterm infants can be optimized to improve their short- and long-term health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will identify dynamic risk factors for suicidal ideation and behaviors within individuals with anorexia nervosa. The proposed research has significant public health relevance, as it will lead to personalized, novel, preventative efforts that disrupt suicidal behaviors before they occur in an extremely high-risk population. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s precision medicine initiative, as it will identify within-person, risk factors, across multiple levels of analysis, leading to user-friendly personalized prevention programs and treatments, which incorporate dynamic interactions among core dimensions, symptoms, and physiology of individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The Flow and Image Cytometry Shared Resource is an integral part of the Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center (Roswell Park) Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG) program (P30CA016056, PI Johnson). As the Associate Director of the Flow and Image Cytometry Shared Resource with over 35 years of relevant experience, Dr Minderman’s efforts are solely dedicated to supporting all 5 CCSG research programs with regards to developing, validating and optimizing flow and image cytometry-based assays, consultation on experimental design, data analysis, interpretation, reporting, education and oversight of maintenance/QC of the equipment in the Resource. His insightful intellectual and practical contributions on how cutting edge flow and image cytometry applications can aid the many NCI-funded projects at the cancer center and that of the CCSG program members in particular are invaluable. Continued funding of Dr Minderman as NCI Core-based Research Specialist will ensure the stability of an essential resource to Roswell Park’s CCSG program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE APOLLO-CPCC (CC05) comprises 11 clinical centers in the Northeastern United States. To support the APOLLO Consortium’s goal of enrolling all US kidney transplant recipients who received kidneys from African American donors as well as all African American living donors, we will build upon the infrastructure and collaboration we created in Phase 1. In Phase 2 we will leverage these relationships and resources to ensure continued recruitment of African American living donors, clinical data capture, and collection of urine albumin- to-creatinine ratio, biopsy slides and biospecimens (blood and urine) in accordance with the goals of the Consortium during the proposed follow up period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative:Hypertension (HTN) accounts for the greatest portion of racial disparities in mortality between blacks and whites, and despite the proven benefits of optimal HTN treatment, too few Black patients achieve optimal blood pressure (BP) control due to barriers at the patient, physician, health systems, and community- levels of care. This application provides a unique opportunity to address this public health challenge by using practice facilitation as a practical and sustainable implementation strategy to support the implementation and evaluation of three multi-level evidence-based interventions (nurse case management, home BP monitoring, and use of Community Health Workers) delivered as an integrated community-clinic linkage model [Practice support And Community Engagement (PACE) across 20 primary practices within NYU Langone Health in NYC and, in partnership with an established Community-Clinic-Academic Advisory Board and HealthFirst (NYC's largest Medicaid payer). The study's findings will provide a practical and sustainable system of hypertension management that harnesses existing clinical and community resources to build capacity for primary care practices to effectively address poor hypertension control in vulnerable populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD) are a major public health problem particularly in older American adults. Current treatments are not effective at preventing AECOPD. I will utilize pulmonary rehabilitation, a safe and effective treatment for prevention of AECOPD, as a model to identify modifiable biologic targets to inform future therapeutic drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the high incidence of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), substance use disorders (SUD), and chronic physical health problems among transgender and gender diverse (TGD) populations, research that can inform the development of transdiagnostic, integrated PTSD-SUD interventions for this population is lacking. The proposed dissertation study will address this clinical science gap by utilizing ecological momentary assessment to identify transdiagnostic mechanisms of co-occurrence among gender minority stress (e.g., TGD-based discrimination), susbtance use, and PTSD symptoms in a sample of trauma-exposed TGD adults, and will be among the first to utilize measures of neuroendocrine stress reactivity to examine physiological and physical health consequences of PTSD-SUD co-occurrence in a high-risk population. This study is consistent with NIDA priorities for research on social determinants of health and will inform the development of patient-centered models of care for minoritized populations more broadly by identifying specific and modifiable clinical targets that cut across experiences of chronic stigma-related stress, PTSD, and SUD in a vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with inherited platelet disorders can have frequent and sometime lethal episodes of uncontrolled bleeding, and an early genetic diagnosis can benefit clinical management. However, genetic diagnosis is often not possible without studies that define how the genetic change affects platelets, which have been historically challenging. This project implements a new, faster, and more disease relevant approach to test how a panel of genetic changes affect a specific inherited platelet disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is the most common rheumatic disease of childhood and requires long-term treatment to prevent pain, physical limitations, and permanent impairment. Due to uncertainty around best medication choices and treatment options, shared decision making (SDM) is recommended for treatment decisions, but a tool to assess patient preferences and incorporate SDM into routine clinical care does not exist. Through this project and training plan, I will gain expertise in medical decision methodology by comparing preference priorities between adolescents with JIA and their parents, developing a decision aid, and then pilot test the decision aid to facilitate shared decision making between adolescents, parents, and providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Persons with HIV (PWH) on anti-retroviral therapy can have near-normal lifespan, but many suffer greatly from HIV-related non-aids conditions (HANA) that manifest themselves as accentuated aging and limited evidence suggests that this happens only in those PHW infected with cytomegalovirus (CMV). We have discovered new biomarkers of CMV infection and propose to use them to test whether and how CMV may be driving accentuated aging in PWH. Results should help to set future CMV-specific treatments to achieve successful aging with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Specific variants in the gene encoding apolipoprotein L1 (APOL1), which are generally restricted to persons with recent African ancestry, have been associated in retrospective analyses with an increased risk of end- stage native-kidney disease and shorter survival of kidney transplants. The proposed study will increase the number of living kidney donors and extend the follow-up of recipients of kidneys from deceased or living donors enrolled in the prospective APOLLO study that is examining the impact of APOL1 variants on kidney function while considering various environmental or comorbid conditions that can damage kidneys. The findings from this study have the potential to transform allocation of kidneys for transplantation, improve survival of transplanted kidneys, better inform potential kidney donors with recent African ancestry of the risks of donation, and provide a better understanding of the mechanisms whereby these genetic variants produce kidney disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liquid biopsy is a useful clinical diagnostic in cancers where known simple mutations can be identified and monitored, but current liquid biopsy techniques are less effective in cancers with few recurrent simple mutations, such as osteosarcoma (OS) and rhabdomyosarcoma. The studies in this proposal will comprehensively interrogate a mutation independent cell-free DNA and RNA (cfDNA/cfRNA) multi-parameter liquid biopsy approach in a spontaneous canine cancer model. This methodology aims to improve the sensitivity of cancer detection using liquid biopsy and enable rapid detection of early drug resistance across a wide range of genomically complex sarcomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will contribute to public health by determining if the apolipoprotein L1 (called APOL1) genotype of kidney donors impacts the function and survival of transplanted kidneys. Results of this study may also allow the quality of kidneys from deceased organ donors to be more accurately assessed which in turn will aid transplant professionals and patients in making decisions about whether or not to accept a given kidney. This study will also determine whether the APOL1 genotype of otherwise healthy African Americans influences their future health and kidney function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Children’s exposure to intimate partner violence (IPV), often perpetrated by fathers, poses serious risk to children, including child maltreatment and mental health impairment. Lacking are interventions that address the complex nature of IPV, including fatherhood and coparenting. The proposed project will compare Fathers for Change, a novel intervention for fathers with IPV, to an active control with a randomized sample of child welfare referred fathers of 4- to 7-year-olds to grow the F4C evidence-base, and advance knowledge of therapeutic mechanisms through which F4C exerts its effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease (PTLD) is a group of rare malignant complications of solid organ transplant that include Hodgkin disease and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. About 50-80% are associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, yet the T cell and Natural Killer cell immune responses in primary EBV infection in children or during progression to PTLD are not well characterized. By performing detailed prospective immunological phenotyping through the first year after 278 pediatric organ transplants, we will unearth pathways that may inform EBV oncogenesis progression in immunocompromised populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Defects affecting tissues of the anterior segment lead to a group of highly debilitating eye disorders referred to as anterior segment dysgenesis (ASD), which represents one of the leading causes of congenital corneal opacity and congenital glaucoma. This study will elucidate signaling pathways required for proper anterior segment development in a complex group of diseases called ciliopathies. This knowledge could help identify and rationalize novel therapeutic targets for cilia-related disorders of the anterior segment, including ASD, congenital glaucoma, and myopia, and may also have wider implications for understanding complex morphogenetic events in other tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) dominate the ecological and human health risk associated with contaminated sediments in the United States and is a frequent cause of fish consumption advisories worldwide. Effective in situ treatments that can be rapidly deployed with minimal disruption in environmentally sensitive sites such as tidal marshes is a sustainable, minimally invasive and relatively low cost technology that is critically needed to help reduce the vast inventory of PCB contaminated sediments, particularly in former industrial areas that frequently impact underrepresented communities. The proposed research will advance towards commercialization a novel in-situ bioremediation technology that employs microbes and activated carbon to treat PCB impacted sediments at the New Bedford Harbor Superfund Site.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: RHODE ISLAND STATE DEPT OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Title: Rhode Island’s Maintenance of Human Food Rapid Response Team Funding Opportunity Number (FOA) : RFA-FD-23-019 This grant will support the efforts to maintain the Rhode Island Rapid Response Teams (RI RRT) to facilitate long-term improvements and innovation to the national integrated food safety system by unifying and coordinating federal/state/local human and animal food (HAF) emergency response efforts including: 1) Strengthening the link among epidemiology, lab and environmental health/regulatory components; 2) Improving States' regulatory and surveillance HAF protection programs to include using Incident Command System (ICS)/National Incident Management System (NIMS) principles and a Unified Command structure to conduct integrated responses to all-hazards HAF emergencies, rapidly identifying and removing tainted food from commerce, and conducting root cause investigations to inform future prevention efforts; and 3) Addressing supporting components, such as training, data sharing, data analysis, communications, continuous process improvement, and development of best practices and other resources to support national response capacity/capability development.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to environmental chemicals, such as phthalates and organophosphate flame retardants (OPFRs), during pregnancy can impact the developing fetal brain. Existing studies focus on the effects of isolated exposure to these compounds rather than the multiple exposures common in real-world settings, and we know very little about potential protective factors that can help like mothers’ prenatal nutrition and cognitively stimulating interactions between parents and young children. This study will be the first to examine several child neurobehavioral outcomes associated with combined exposure to phthalates and OPFRs, and the potential for maternal nutrition and parental cognitive stimulation to improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance to Public Health  Prenatal stress is a known risk factor for negative child health outcomes, and disproportionately affects families facing racial and economic marginalization. We will examine the effects of preconception stress exposure on pregnancy health and neurodevelopmental outcomes in the child from birth to age 10, as well as the extent to which prenatal nutritional health and social support foster resilience in stressful environments. The findings from this study will advance knowledge on tailored approaches to optimize prenatal health and child development and reduce persistent health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of gene therapy is to precisely treat diseases by delivering nucleic acids that strike at the genetic root of the disease. However, a key bottleneck in the application of these technologies are appropriate delivery vehicles that do not initiate strong immune responses. Here we propose to utilize mammalian virus-like proteins to engineer fully endogenous vectors that have the potential for efficient, modular, and non-immunogenic nucleic acid delivery for eventual applications in neurological disease treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Renal risk variants in the gene APOL1 have been associated with increased risk of chronic kidney disease in individuals with African American (AA) ancestry. Within the APOLLO Consortium, APOLLO Clinical Center 12 will work collaboratively to study the impact of this gene on long-term outcomes in renal transplant recipients that receive a kidney from an AA donor and on renal function of AA living donors by leveraging the infrastructure and collaborations established in Phase I. In Phase 2, we will maximize clinical data capture, recruitment of AA living donors, measurement of urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio, and biospecimen collection according to the goals of the Consortium.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Continued media coverage of the potential long-term effects of contact sports, such as tackle football, has created significant public health concerns about the risk of childhood participation. This study will provide critical contributions to our scientific knowledge on the neurodevelopmental effects of youth tackle football across the first year of participation and has the potential to provide a key understanding of the risks and benefits of participation. Thus, the proposed research is consistent with the Pediatric Trauma and Critical Illness Branch of the NICHD scientific priority to prevent adverse health outcomes and developmental sequelae in children by improving early detection and by identifying optimal time periods for prevention and intervention efforts of repetitive brain injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Genetic variants in APOL1 commonly found in people of Western Sub-Saharan Africa ancestry are associated with kidney diseases such as Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis, Hypertension Attributed-End Stage Kidney Disease, and HIV-Associated Nephropathy, the presence of 2 APOL1-renal risk variants (RRV) in deceased donors is associated with 2-to-4-times higher risk of renal graft loss in the recipient, and living donors (LDs) withAPOL1 RRVs may be at risk for kidney disease. The NIH established the “APOL1 Long-term Kidney Transplantation Outcomes” (APOLLO) U01 Consortium in 2017 consisting of 13 clinical centers (CCs) with 4 paired core Centers to study the role of APOL1 in transplant outcomes. This application from CC3 (Johns Hopkins/Saint Louis University) seeks to build on and extend the findings of the APOLLO study to inform clinical practice by: a) providing data regarding the effects of APOL1 genotype on outcomes of the recipients of kidneys from AA donors, b) providing data regarding the effects of APOL1 genotype on long-term renal functional outcomes of AA LDs and their recipients, and c) establishing a resource of clinical information, genetic data and biological specimens for the APOLLO Consortium and other future researchers through the NIDDK Central Repository.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project will construct novel large-scale, multi-host mechanistic models of the Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome (HPS) and Valley Fever (coccidioidomycosis) diseases in the Phoenix, Arizona metro area to investigate the stability versus context-sensitivity of hosts as disease reservoirs and identify key future data sources required to improve forecasting and identify effective interventions aimed at reducing disease burden. Both diseases are endemic to the southwestern United States and are believed to be spread by rodent hosts, but they are caused by different types of pathogens (viruses and fungi, respectively) and show divergent case trends. For training and outreach, the project will implement and evaluate initiatives to (i) communicate results in public outreach events; (ii) construct a course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) focused on disease modeling; and (iii) build capacity for researching Valley Fever and mitigating outbreaks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Knowledge of critical interactions among various brain cells is central to understanding the underlying causes of age-related cognitive decline as well as Alzheimer’s dementia. However, accurate identification of molecular changes in  these cells is hard to accomplish using conventional methods. The current project will develop advanced deep learning  methods and techniques to elucidate pathological mechanisms leading to Alzheimer’s disease, which will enable the  identification of novel biomarkers and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex genetic disease that places substantial burden on the medical and public health systems. We have identified a set of genomic DNA sequence changes in people with T2D that we hypothesize contribute to this disease by changing gene expression patterns and reducing the ability of mitochondria to function in islet cells of the pancreas. In this project, we will complete innovative genomic and cellular analyses, including techniques to 'edit' these genomic DNA sequences, in human islet cells and preclinical mouse models of T2D to test our hypothesis and determine how a targeted subset of genes regulating mitochondrial function contribute to T2D genetic risk and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney transplantation has clear benefits to quality and duration of life over dialysis, yet many patients with end-stage kidney disease face difficulties getting through the transplant referral and evaluation process. The proposed studies will help improve understanding of healthcare system level practices that contribute to inequity in transplant candidate referrals, living donor evaluations and follow-up, and we will identify modifiable social determinants of health that contribute to delays in pediatric kidney transplant evaluation completion. This proposal also provides scientific training for the mentor applicant and her mentees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A growing number of advanced heart failure patients are supported by the contemporary HeartMate 3 (HM3) continuous-flow (CF) left ventricular assist device (LVAD) around the world, but the optimal blood pressure (BP) range for patients on CF-LVAD support has yet to be fully characterized. Previous studies of patients with older LVAD technology have suggested that elevated BP is associated with stroke and mortality, but minimal data exist regarding the thresholds for maximal and minimal BP for patients supported by contemporary CF-LVADs and the BP goals for women, Blacks, and patients with right heart failure. We propose a prospective study of 200 newly implanted HM3 LVAD outpatients at four different LVAD implantation centers with a structured home and in-clinic BP monitoring protocol to evaluate the association of BP and stroke/death during mean follow-up of two years.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative: Informed consent templates aim to provide clear, transparent information; however, they often include legal jargon, technical wording, and confusing and repetitive sections. The complex consent process can increase disparities in study participation and thus disparities in study benefits. Fortunately, we and colleagues have developed tools and recommendations to improve understanding and adoption of evidence-informed practices for consent in clinical trials. This study will use mixed-methods to adapt, implement and test revised evidence- based consent templates and processes in three different institutions in the U.S.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Sustainable Solutions to Translating Best Practices for Informed Consent

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CC7 APOLLO Clinical Center Network comprises of all major active kidney transplant centers in Ohio, Michigan, as well as the University of Buffalo, University of Pittsburgh, University of Chicago, and Cleveland Clinic in Florida. To support the APOLLO Consortium’s goal of enrolling all kidney transplant recipients across the United States who received a kidney from an African American donor, as well as all African American living donors, we will continue to leverage the infrastructure and collaboration we built in Phase 1 to ensure that we continue to obtain complete clinical data, urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio, and facilitate return of genetic test results to fulfill the mission of Phase 2. Additionally, we will also continue to enroll living kidney donors and obtain biospecimens for participants enrolled in Phase 1 at the Cleveland Clinic and University of Michigan, according to the goals of the Consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health, and in particular, the mission of the NEI to support research on visual disorders, mechanisms of visual function and preservation of sight, because a greater understanding of mechanisms related to perceptual learning can inform new therapies for treating low vision, which in turn has the potential to benefit millions of individuals suffering from low vision. Declines in vision are particularly common in older adults and thus increasing our understanding of how to create effective means of improving vision is also highly relevant to the mission of the NIA to support research on aging and the health and well-being of older people. In addition to strongly aligning with the missions of the NEI and NIA, the proposed re- search cuts across the bounds of numerous other NIH agencies, including the NCI, NIMH, NIAAA, NINCD, NIDA, NINDS, in that all of these agencies work with populations who could gain direct benefits from successful approaches to utilizing behavioral methods to enhance human well-being and performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tactile and multimodal vibrational/audio maps can be very useful for blind individuals who want to acquire spatial knowledge of the environment before or during a trip. While systems exist for the systematic production of outdoors tactile maps, indoor tactile maps are normally created by professionals using ad-hoc techniques. The proposed work will develop and experiment with new technology for the semi-automatic creation of indoor tactile maps, leading to a map production service for all interested stakeholders managed by our partner institution, the Vista Center for the Blind of Palo Alto, CA.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma is a complex condition with both genetic and environmental contributors to disease inception. Leveraging the large, diverse ECHO cohort, this proposal investigates how neighborhood (air pollution, nearby green space) and the individual (microbiome) level exposures alter DNA methylation and transcriptional responses at the epithelial barrier to promote asthma and asthma related disparities. These studies will help identify non-invasive biomarkers and define actionable exposures for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The goal of this proposal is to develop a better understanding of social, cultural, structural and other factors that drive health disparities for underserved racial/ethnic and marginalized populations at the intersection of HIV and substance use, particularly methamphetamine, cocaine/crack, and illicit opioid use. We work with community partners and other end-users to examine disparities in substance use patterns of use, treatment, overdoses, and HIV care and comorbidities among marginalized populations of people with HIV including not only racial/ethnic populations, but also transgender people, those with unstable housing, those recently incarcerated, and others. This study will inform future research, interventions, and assist end-users within our community partnerships in tailoring future substance use treatment programs to the unique needs of multidimensional identities in order to reduce disparities among populations severely affected by inequities at the intersection of HIV care and substance use treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Reducing the spread of infectious diseases through environmental media (air, water, soil, food, surfaces, etc.) requires contributions from clinicians, epidemiologists, microbiologists, engineers, public health professionals and other disciplines to perform rigorous risk analysis. However, quantitative microbial risk assessment methodology is not widely understood though it is recommended by the World Health Organization and various U.S. agencies for supporting intervention and prevention strategies as risk based decisions. The QMRA IV education and mentoring program will equip professionals across biomedical disciplines with sustained academic and instrumental mentoring to conduct research and make decisions to minimize risks from infectious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The proposed research aims to determine the behavioral mechanisms by which ovulatory surges in estradiol increase alcohol use in young women by increasing their sensitivity to the rewarding and disinhibiting effects of alcohol that promote patterns of binge drinking. The research will provide important new information on how certain hormonal phases, such as those linked with estradiol surges, can challenge relapse prevention and other alcohol treatment efforts in young women with alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Eye is the most sensitive organ to mustard vesicant nitrogen mustard (NM) and sulfur mustard (SM) exposure with devastating short- and long-term injuries; however, no effective treatments are available. Novel studies under this grant will investigate the time-dependent distribution of NM exposure scenarios in the eye tissues and demonstrate how localized concentrations in cornea are tied to injury mechanisms and toxic responses using in vivo and in silico rabbit ocular models. This study could serve as a more efficient and potentially more insightful novel approach to evaluate toxicity mechanisms underlying the mustard vesicant ocular pathology, and in the identification of therapeutic targets to counter acute and long-term ocular complications from their exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Darbepoetin Kindergarten Development Study (Darbe-KIDS) proposes to follow children who participated in the NHLBI-funded multicenter “Darbepoetin Trial to Improve Red Cell Mass and Neurodevelopment in Preterms” (Darbe Trial) at preschool and school age, with the goal of evaluating the effects of darbepoetin on neurodevelopment in children born preterm. Darbe-KIDS will be led by a highly collaborative, interdisciplinary multi-PI team with extensive relevant experience studying the impacts of erythropoiesis stimulating agents in preterm infants and a long history of successful collaborations in conducting high-quality developmental follow- up through school age in large cohorts of high-risk infants. The results of Darbe-KIDS will be essential for determining whether darbepoetin becomes a routine therapy for neuroprotection in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative A major challenge in the study of short-term memory is to determine how the interactions among functionally, genetically, and anatomically diverse classes of neurons give rise to the persistent patterns of neural activity underlying memory storage and function. We address this challenge by combining synapse resolution anatomy and circuit-wide, cellular resolution recordings and perturbations of neural activity into a biologically realistic model that enables us to infer the physiological interactions underlying short-term memory function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe respiratory viral infections, including influenza A viruses, are leading causes of lung inflammation and pathology. In severe cases of influenza, lung inflammation and pathology can persist after clearance of the virus and lead to long-term respiratory symptoms, referred to as post-viral lung disease (PVLD). This project seeks to define the role of lung fibroblasts in driving PVLD and determine if these cells are effective therapeutic targets to prevent or reverse this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most common cause of idiopathic and familial Parkinson’s disease, an adult onset movement neurodegenerative disorder, are mutations in leucine-rich repeat kinase 2 (LRRK2). The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand the underlying mechanisms of mitochondrial DNA damage, a shared phenotype between LRRK2-associated and idiopathic PD. It is hoped that cellular pathways involved in maintaining mitochondrial genome integrity will reveal potential new therapeutic strategies to treat this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposed development of vibrational sum frequency generation microscopy, in the short term, will spatially resolve collagen tissues with chemical structure and molecular interaction information in a complicated environment. Machine learning and simulation approaches will be employed to build a data base to convert hyperspectral images of collagen into a spatial map with microscopic structures and molecular interaction information. In the long term, the fundamental biochemical knowledge learned from this development will lay foundations for rationally design biomedical approaches to monitor and control pericellular spaces and its interaction with cells, and further advance treatment to diseases related to it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A high-consequence chemical emergency is a major public health concern demanding development of critical medical MCMs against chemical threats. The eyes are the most frequent route of toxic exposure. Results of our studies will provide new knowledge about mitochondrial mechanisms of OcS damage caused by exposure to mustard compounds and establish rationale for a potentially paradigm-shifting therapeutic that targets mitochondrial bioenergetics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will develop widely-applicable computational methods to make statistical inferences about migration of B cells between tissues and differentiation of B cells into cellular subtypes. These methods will significantly expand the ability of scientists to study these dynamic processes in humans. Working closely with experimental collaborators, we will validate and then apply these methods to several biological systems including vaccination and autoimmunity, in both human and murine model systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to enable precision nutrition by creating a wearable sweat bioanalytical technology— equipped with autonomous sweat secretion modulation, biofluid management, and analysis capabilities—that can be scaled across the general population to non-invasively track the diurnal profiles of a panel of putative circulating nutrients and biomarkers. By deploying this technology in clinical studies (with a particular focus on cystic fibrosis, the most common inherited multisystemic disorder), we will study and establish the correlation of the sweat readings to the circulating analytes and in response to nutritional interventions. This technology will provide a comprehensive and physiologically rich view of the individuals’ well-being/disease and nutritional status, rendering a personalized solution for effective treatment and nutritional support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common form of degenerative joint disease affecting millions of people worldwide. In this proposal, we will generate new mechanistic understanding of distinct signaling pathways and determine whether manipulation of these pathways can protect against OA progression in mouse models. Given the fact that there are currently no disease modifying therapies available for OA, this proposal will shed light on our understanding of chondroprotective mechanisms and accelerate the diagnosis and treatment of human OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We present an innovative strategy for overcoming dystrophin-specific T cell responses by predicting the “strongest” dystrophin epitopes (in register with clinical trial data as it becomes available), then computationally redesigning those epitopes (targeting exons 8-11) to dramatically reduce antigenicity. As a screening platform, novel dystrophin clones will be tested following viral vector transduction of human DMD-iPSC derived engineered muscle tissues and selected based on contractile performance via our high throughput magnetic tissue array platform (Mantarray), followed by in vivo validation within the DMDmdx rat model.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the impact of prenatal exposures to complex mixtures of chemical and non-chemical stressors on key child health outcomes. It will also explore whether a healthy maternal diet during pregnancy can lessen the impact of these stressors on the child. This solution-oriented approach takes into account the complexity of real-world exposures and has strong potential to influence programs designed to improve children’s health.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work will address innovative research questions regarding unresolved disparities in periconceptional folate status and associations with downstream child health, exposures to novel plasticizing chemicals and other environmental exposures in relation to later child neurodevelopmental outcomes, interactions between these prenatal exposures, and potential intermediary epigenetic and biologic pathways. This work will help us to understand how factors could be modified to improve health outcomes of children, as well as identify the sub-populations of expecting families that might benefit most from preventive measures that can move us towards reducing the burden of neurodevelopmental disorders and improve the quality of life for children, with direct implications for clinical guidelines and public health recommendations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance The study will test the effects of in utero exposures to a natural disaster (hurricane Superstorm Sandy) in an intact cohort, whom we have followed since pregnancy. The study will help us chart the course of behavioral and neurodevelopmental outcomes from in utero to early adolescence as potential risk together with postnatal stress for future psychiatric and substance use disorders and determine whether specific epigenetic signatures within the placenta relate to offspring outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin resistance is commonly associated with obesity and is a major contributor to the development of obesity-related metabolic diseases, including nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, the metabolic syndrome, and insulin resistance and the metabolic syndrome. However, a subset of people with obesity are metabolically healthy (MHO) and protected from the adverse metabolic effects of excess adiposity. The mechanisms that determine the differences in metabolic health between people with MUO and MHO are not unclear. This project will examine the effects of plasma and adipose tissue small extracellular vesicles (sEVs) on multi-organ insulin action. We will isolate sEVs from subcutaneous abdominal adipose tissue biopsies and blood samples obtained from human participants with MHO, MUO or who are metabolically healthy and lean (MHL) and examine the effects of these sEVs on insulin resistance in muscle, liver and fat cells in culture and on insulin multi-organ insulin sensitivity in lean and obese mice. We will also identify differences in the potential bioactive molecules, namely miRNA and bioactive lipids, that are carried by sEVs. The results from this study will help determine whether plasma or adipose tissue sEVs in people who are MHL, MHO, or MUO are involved in regulating liver, muscle and adipose tissue insulin sensitivity. These results could identify novel pathways that regulate metabolic health in people and provide the foundation for exploring the potential of sEVs as a therapeutic target to prevent and treat the metabolic complications of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Eliminating racial/ethnic cardiovascular health disparities in the U.S. cannot be achieved without addressing disparities in evidence-based treatment of hypertension. In the Los Angeles County Department of Health Services (LAC DHS), the second largest municipal health system in the US, patient, clinician, healthy system, and community factors contribute to substantial disparities in hypertension prevalence, control, and outcomes by race/ethnicity. In this study, we use innovative methods in implementation science, community engagement, and behavioral economics to develop and deploy culturally-tailored, multi-level, sustainable implementation strategies that improve blood pressure control and reduce hypertension-related health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: To date, no therapy exists to restore vision in the more than 64 million people worldwide who are legally blind as a result of diseases that damage the optic nerve, a nerve comprised of retinal ganglion cell (RGC) axons that relay visual information from the eye to the brain. The proposed research builds upon promising results by our group showing that electric fields direct regeneration of RGC axons in vitro and in vivo, even when applied after degeneration has started to set in. This project will lay the groundwork for the future development of a breakthrough electric field-based therapy to regenerate the optic nerve using novel waveforms and systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our overarching goal is to leverage the rich institutional environment at UCSF to develop a core curriculum to train a first generation of neurologists (primary learners: residents; other learners: medical students and clinical fellows) who are competent in providing sex and gender informed neurological care, and in understanding how to design and interpret studies informed by sex and gender. Deep exploration opportunities for interest learners include planning a mentored inquiry workshop, and participating in outpatient clinical selectives. A roadmap will be developed to support dissemination of the curriculum to other institutions and societies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is an important cause of human lymphomas such as Burkitt lymphomas (BLs) and diffuse large B cell lymphomas (DLBCLs) that have stringent forms of viral latency (types I and II) that cannot transform B cells in vitro. We have recently developed a new model system that allows us to obtain EBV-infected BL-like lymphomas with type I latency and EBV-infected DLBCLs with type II latency in naïve B cells. In this proposal, we will extend this model into primary human GC B cells, define the specific EBV genes and/or RNAs required to form each tumor type, and identify pathways that restore expression of the EBV LMP1 protein in BL- like tumors, thereby enhancing the T cell response to BL-like tumors in humanized mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE White matter circuitry is the basis for neuronal communication in the human brain and has been found to be abnormal in all major psychiatric, neurological, and developmental conditions. Our proposed work significantly extends the worldwide ENIGMA (Enhancing NeuroImaging Genetics through Meta Analysis) consortium by mapping novel white matter circuitry biomarkers and the variability that drives underlying risk for mental illness. We will coordinate global genome-wide investigations into the genomic architecture of white matter structural and microstructural metrics in over 100,000 individuals of all ages in a discovery/replication framework and further, construct and disseminate an integrated ENIGMA DSI Studio pipeline offering coordinated, high- throughput, tractography and fiber analytic methods to identify structural dysconnectivity in ENIGMA working groups on severe mental illnesses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gene APOL1 has been associated with increased risk of chronic kidney disease in African Americans. North East Consortium for Transplant Outcomes in APOL1 Kidney Recipients (NECTAR) Clinical Center, APOLLO CC6, will study the impact of this gene on long-term outcomes in renal transplant recipients that receive a kidney from an AA donor and on renal function of AA living donors by leveraging the infrastructure and collaborations established in Phase 1. In Phase 2, we will maximize long-term clinical data capture, recruitment of AA living donors and biospecimen collection according to the goals of the Consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CC11 APOLLO Clinical Center Network comprises of all major active kidney transplant centers in Florida and Puerto Rico, as well as the University of California-Irvine and California Institute of Renal Research. To support the APOLLO Consortium’s goal of enrolling all kidney transplant recipients across the United States who received a kidney from an African American donor, as well as all African American living donors, we will continue to leverage the infrastructure and collaboration we built in Phase 1 to ensure that we continue to obtain complete clinical data, urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio, and facilitate return of genetic test results to fulfill the mission of Phase 2. Additionally, we will also continue to enroll living kidney donors and obtain biospecimens for participants enrolled in Phase 1 at the Miami Transplant Institute, Jackson Memorial Hospital, according to the goals of the Consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over 20 million people living with HIV (PLHIV) are receiving antiretroviral therapy and require HIV viral load testing to identify cases of virological failure and provide actionable information to guide alternative clinical treatment. Current methods for HIV viral load measurement rely on quantitative PCR (qPCR) or digital PCR (dPCR), which are commonly restricted to highly resourced central laboratories and there is a need to decentralize HIV viral load monitoring to enable rapid, clinic-based or home self-testing viral load measurements. Here we develop a rapid POC HIV viral load test using digital isothermal amplification that leverages the characteristic viscous reaction buffer of recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA) isothermal amplification chemistry and commercially available porous membranes to accurately quantify HIV-1 RNA over clinically relevant HIV-1 subtypes and viral loads.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: DNA methylation is a critical epigenetic modification that is required for proper neuronal development, and improper DNA methylation is associated with autism-associated neurodevelopmental disease; but it is fundamentally unknown how the DNA methylation landscape is faithfully established across the neuronal genome. The proposed research will utilize genomic approaches to examine how the histone modification H3K36me2 functions to guide DNA methyltransferase 3A (DNMT3A) to establish the neuronal DNA methylation landscape and investigate how disruption of H3K36 methylation-mediated interactions with DNMT3A disturbs critical patterns of DNA methylation to disrupt neuronal transcription and brain function. Completing these goals will elucidate novel paradigms of H3K36 methylation function in the developing brain and provide insight into how mutations in H3K36 methyltransferases may lead to neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Currently most treatments for back of the eye diseases are based on frequent intravitreal injections, which are invasive, and could lead to serious complications such as endophthalmitis and retinal detachment. Here we propose to use novel engineered contact lenses to nonivasively deliver drugs capable of treating diabetic macular edema and posterior uveitis to the back of the eye. We have preliminary data showing feasibility of contact lens mediated delivery of drugs to the back of the eye and in this proposal, we focus on establishing the mechanisms and designing and testing novel contact lenses for delivery of small molecules and biologics to the back of the eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The regulation of body weight - and the impact of excess weight on clinical phenotypes such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease and cancer - is extremely complex necessitating special training in centers with broad basic and translational research portfolios for the scientists who will help to break this nexus of disease. This K26 is to support mentoring of early career investigators from underrepresented and diverse backgrounds through providing protected effort and resources to Dr. Gallagher who will deliver focused mentoring, academic course work, sophisticated research experiences, and career development and networking, enabling them to transition to research independence. This program has important national implications by virtue of adding to a critical group of diverse bioscientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The Mu and Kappa Opioid Receptor (MOR, KOR) systems are implicated in craving and mood, and thus important for the understanding of addiction. The MOR and KOR systems have never been probed in a single cohort of patients suffering from Alcohol Use Disorder. We will use PET imaging and various analyses, including kinetic modeling and machine learning, to explore the relationships between MOR and KOR status and patients' behaviors during a monitored attempt to abstain from drinking.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The psychosocial environment is known to be associated with the unfolding of child health outcomes beginning very early in development, yet questions remain about the specific mechanisms linking psychosocial exposures and child health outcomes, and the calibration of the timing linking an exposure with an outcome. The proposed study adds to and extends the ECHO program by conducting annual assessments of our current ECHO cohort children thru age 20. When combined with other ECHO cohort data, this study will enable an in depth look at how adolescence can be a pivotal period in development for studying the timing of the effects of early psychosocial exposures and testing outcome-specific models that determine whether early psychosocial exposures have longer-term effects, latent or delayed effects, and/or desisting effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because the results are expected to provide much- needed evidence on which to base decisions regarding donating and accepting kidneys for transplantation. The absolute and relative risks of accepting a kidney from a donor with high-risk variants of APOL1 are needed to allow a potential recipient to make a fully informed decision on whether to accept a donated organ and the risks associated with high-risk APOL1 variants for a living kidney donor are also necessary to make this important decision. Clinicians caring for transplant recipients and donors will use these findings to personalize monitoring and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Early-life exposure to per- and polyfluorinated alkyl substances has been linked to a number of adverse health effects; however, PFAS toxicity and exposure assessment studies largely focus on a small number of PFAS. This proposal will evaluate aggregate exposure to PFAS mixtures using untargeted, unbiased methodology in maternal serum, placenta, cord blood, infant serum, formula, and breastmilk. The information collected in this study can be used to guide selection of PFAS for future studies and to inform guidance on breastfeeding in PFAS exposed populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Macrophages are part of body’s immune system that play both a disease-fighting and an immune-suppressing role in cancer. We propose to develop a pair of PET imaging toolkits that are highly specific for human and mouse macrophages. This pair will allow us to study the role of macrophages in both clinical and preclinical applications.

PHR: NARRATIVE We are leveraging cutting edge technologies in CRISPR/Cas9-mediated genome editing to treat sickle cell disease (SCD), a painful, life-threatening genetic disorder that affects 100,000 Americans and millions worldwide. Our work has the potential to relieve suffering and extend the lifespan of patients with severe SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning is a leading cause of death from environmental poisoning worldwide and is associated with high morbidity and mortality. Among survivors, permanent neurological morbidity is common even with prompt treatment. The objectives of this grant proposal are as follows: 1) to evaluate the use of circulating blood cells as a biomarker of severity in CO poisoning along with novel noninvasive optical measuring devices; 2) Among animals surviving 24 hours and 7 days post-CO exposure, further define cardiac and cerebral mitochondrial dysfunction, cerebral and cardiac metabolism, and clinically-relevant outcomes with those treated with hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) and those untreated with HBO; and 3) to test a promising mitochondria-directed therapy to preserve cellular energy production compared to HBO therapy with promising in vitro and in vivo data.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic peripheral neuropathy is the most common complication in people living with diabetes, which causes limitations in functional mobility, decreased quality of life, and increased risk for ulceration and amputation. This career development award will evaluate the biomechanical and functional inter-relationships between plantar pressure and propulsion, surrogates of ulcer risk and walking function, and examine the feasibility and safety of using real-time biofeedback as a gait training intervention to break the cycle of disability in people with diabetic peripheral neuropathy. A thorough understanding of the underlying mechanisms contributing to walking dysfunction and evaluation of a preliminary gait training intervention can help develop improved gait rehabilitation approaches for individuals with diabetic peripheral neuropathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Necrotizing enterocolitis is a life-threatening intestinal disease in premature infants that is caused by immature intestine, aberrant bacterial colonization, and exaggerated inflammation. While no treatment options currently exist, our studies show that placental stem cell therapy is a multi-faceted approach that can ameliorate NEC damage through immunomodulation and epithelial regeneration. This proposal seeks to define the reparative cellular and molecular mechanisms and modes of actions involved in the immune modulation and epithelial resolution of NEC damage mediated by human placental stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Asexual reproduction has emerged many times across eukaryotes, but very little is known about the genetic mechanisms behind this major shift in biology. In addition to numerous pathogens that use asexual reproductive strategies, asexual reproduction serves as a key model for understanding the cell biology of meiosis and mitosis, and, processes such as cancer tumor evolution and fertility. The proposed research will leverage highly tractable insect systems in which microbial symbionts regulate reproductive mode to uncover the genetic basis of altered mitosis and meiosis and map the long-term evolutionary and genomic consequences of lost sex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: Project Narrative: The project team will develop a training program to teach skills and tools for rigor and reproducibility in biomedical data science, through a bootcamp with a flexible syllabus and collaborative projects, follow-on mentoring, and an online bilingual study guide that is interactive and self-paced. The trainees will be teams of faculty and technical personnel who will collaborate in the learning process and complement each other’s skills and perspectives. The program will strengthen trainees’ research and enable them to teach rigor and reproducibility at their institutions, which could be especially important for researchers from underrepresented groups and institutions with limited resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with diabetes and breast cancer have a 50% higher risk of death up to 10 years after cancer diagnosis compared to non-diabetic women with breast cancer, which may be partially due to suboptimal diabetes management during active cancer treatment. The goal of this study is to develop and pilot test a stakeholder- engaged intervention to manage diabetes for women receiving chemotherapy for incident, non-metastatic breast cancer. Findings from this innovative pilot study will lay the groundwork for a future, multi-site, randomized trial testing the intervention developed here.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current project aims to better understand the psychological processes that lead to alcohol use and its consequences during adolescence and early adulthood. Our goal is to compare the relative importance of four key factors thought to promote addiction, and to understand how their influence changes over time. Findings from such work can lead to new, targeted addiction interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the pre-analytical variables that influence tissue-based biomarker tests is of utmost importance for validity and precision of the measurements. This project will systematically and comprehensively evaluate patient factors and tissue specimen pre-analytics for their effects on the validity, sensitivity, and specificity of singleplexed and multiplexed immunohistochemical predictive PD-L1 biomarker assays. This project will define the best pre- analytical conditions for specimen acquisition and inform a biomarker testing paradigm for the next generation of clinical tissue-based immune checkpoint protein assays for the benefit of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will increase our understanding of how each individual's clinical measures and biomarkers would predict the time of progression to AD dementia from MCI. We will develop optimal deep survival models for early stage and late stage MCI patients. This project will greatly speed up the time it would take to identify potential MCI patients who are more likely to develop AD dementia in later years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Organophosphate (OP) pesticides, such as chlorpyrifos (CPF) are among the most toxic chemicals known to mankind and their use in Syria by terrorist on innocent civilians highlights the need to identify countermeasure approaches against these chemical threat agents. Many of the symptoms experienced by civilians intoxicated with OP chemicals resemble those associated with autoimmune disorders and, therefore, we will identify mechanisms associated with OP induced immune dysfunction. The proposed work will help identify mechanisms which could lead to future development of treatments that can improve the health of individuals who may suffer from chronic multisymptom illnesses after being exposed to such chemicals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE A key goal of “Healthy People 2030” is to improve health of adults through aerobic physical activity, and soccer, which is the most popular sport on earth, is an aerobic outlet for more than 25 million Americans of all ages that provides significant benefits for brain health. However, we and others have shown that repetitive subconcussive head impacts from soccer heading are associated with signs of subclinical brain injury among young adults, which impact function and may pose risk for neurodegeneration. Delineating the risk vs. benefit to cognitive performance from soccer, based upon a robust scientific foundation, can transform perception of risk by stakeholders and facilitate guidanceon soccer participation for young adult players with decades of future needs, and potential to impact their wellbeing, healthcare footprint and productivity for decades.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Genetic information in the apolipoprotein L1 gene (APOL1) from African American donors of kidneys and transplant recipients may provide more accurate assessments of the likelihood of long-term survival of transplanted kidneys and optimize matching of donors with recipients. This application is submitted in response to the National Institutes of Health request for renewal applications for the APOL1 Long-term Kidney Transplant Outcomes Network (APOLLO) Scientific and Data Research Center prospectively evaluating effects of donor and recipient APOL1 genotypes in kidney transplants from African American donors performed at US transplant programs. Results from the national APOLLO study have the potential to transform the processes of organ allocation and informed consent in kidney transplantation, optimize survival of patients after kidney transplantation, and determine the safety of living kidney donation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Kids First Data Resource Core (KFDRC) is composed of three core, the Administrative and Outreach Core (AOC), the Data Coordination Core (DCC) and the Data Resource Core (DRC), which together will facilitate making Kids First, and other relevant interoperable datasets, Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable (FAIR). In this phase, the KFDRC will expand and scale its efforts for continued data generation, new data modalities, emerging interoperability initiatives and wider range of users across computational and biological researchers, to clinicians to patients and patient advocates. These efforts will continue to maximize the potential for novel discovery and better understanding across a multitude of pediatric diseases and disorders for clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The Acquired Resistance to Therapy and Iron (ARTI) Center at The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center will establish a foundation for understanding the role of iron in cancer resistance to therapies and will focus on deciphering the mechanisms of acquired resistance to radiation therapy, which can be extrapolated to other types of cancer therapy. The overarching goals of the ARTI Center are: 1) to bridge the basic science mechanism of a novel type of iron-dependent cell death called ferroptosis in acquired resistance to radiation therapy with translational research in preclinical models and human patient samples; 2) to identify cohorts of patients who are at greatest risk to develop acquired radiation therapy resistance; and 3) to investigate the ability of novel therapeutic agents to re-sensitize cancer cells to radiation by inducing ferroptosis. The long-term outcomes from the ARTI Center will foster collaborations with other centers in the Acquired Resistance to Therapy Network (ARTNet), build upon and iteratively feedback into research projects focused on drug resistance and sensitivities, and ultimately lead to cancer treatment strategies tailored to the individual patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to public health because it addresses a fundamental gap in understanding how DNA damaging therapies such as radiotherapy and chemotherapy lead to epigenetic alterations and treatment resistance in cancer. Addressing this knowledge gap and developing strategies to study this process will open new therapeutic avenues for cancer treatment. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission of seeking fundamental knowledge that can lengthen life and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse midline glioma (DMG) is the leading cause of death among pediatric brain tumors yet disease outcomes have not improved due to the lack of effective treatments and limited diagnostic tools. This proposal uses an innovative, multimodal treatment approach, involving mitogen- activated protein kinase (MEK) inhibition and aminolevulinic acid-photodynamic therapy, that addresses the barriers to successful DMG clinical trials and exploits the molecular composition of DMG cells to reduce morbidity and mortality. If successful, this treatment can be applied to other inoperable central nervous system (CNS) tumors.
