IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many underrepresented high school students lack exposure to authentic laboratory science experiences that can profoundly influence their academic performance in school and their subsequent career trajectories. Since today’s students will determine our nation’s future scientific competitiveness and need to be intelligent evaluators of new science and health advances, CityLab will use well-matched comparison studies with a diverse pre-college student population to determine whether infusing socioscientific reasoning skill development into its new gene editing curriculum supplement can not only teach students important science concepts and practices but also promote continued engagement in the biomedical sciences/STEM. This project will test the hypothesis that teaching socioscientific reasoning skills, in conjunction with laboratory- based experiences and extended participation in a community of learners, will positively impact diverse populations of students, promote their continued engagement in STEM and raise all students’ awareness of attitudes and practices that promote equity, inclusion, and diversity in STEM, inspire them towards careers in the health professions and biomedical sciences, and ultimately improve the nation’s understanding of gene editing and its role in improving human health and eradicating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite intensive efforts to develop methods for analyzing fast-growing environmentally-sequenced microbiome data, many challenges remain, and there is substantial room for improvements. We will build several methods for building better reference datasets, increasing the accuracy of proﬁling contents of microbiome samples, and ﬁnding associations between changes in the proﬁle and phenotypes of interest. Our publicly available methods will use advanced algorithms, statistics, and state-of-the-art machine learning techniques, but will adopt these techniques to incorporate a deep understanding of the evolutionary processes that shape the microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Interpersonal violence is a leading cause of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), a debilitating syndrome characterized by sleep disturbances, flashbacks, dysregulated emotional reactivity, and increased potential for aggression. Understanding how stress affects the neural circuitry underlying aggression and violence is fundamental to developing effective therapies for treatment or prevention of pathological aggression. These experiments will examine the central amygdala – a brain region involved in both stress and fighting – in the generation of social trauma-induced and stress-related aggression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Overall) We and others have recently identified mutations in histone proteins, as well as proteins that mimic oncohistone sequences, in a range of human cancers including brain and mesenchymal tumors. We will determine the effects of newly discovered mutations on the chromatin landscape, the underlying mechanism, and the contexts in which they are relevant to tumorigenesis. Findings of our project will facilitate the development of therapeutics for tumors harboring histone mutations or aberrantly expressing oncohistone mimics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Discovery of mutations in histone genes (oncohistones) in deadly cancers has uncovered a novel mechanism of oncogenesis with deregulation of normal development at its core. We aim in this project to understand how the H3.3G34 mutations and the new oncohistone-mimic EZHIP act to promote oncogenesis, identify targets amenable to therapy, provide relevant pre-clinical models, and design strategies to optimally engage the immune system to improve survival and provide cure for patients with oncohistone-associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is an allergic disease of the esophagus and has a complex, genetic basis. Though recent research progress suggests that EoE is linked to genetic variants, testing single variants separately does not consider how these variants may be interacting nor how these interactions may bring about or impact disease. This study will evaluate how variants linked to EoE interact and what effects these interactions have on disease features and will develop risk scores based on the biological pathways to predict the chance of developing EoE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (ALLIS) Genome-wide sequencing technologies have allowed an unprecedented discovery of somatic mutations in “chromatin and epigenetic modifiers” in human cancers, including high-frequency mutations in histones, the proteins charged with packaging our genome. The proposed research will determine how newly identified cancer-associated histone mutations disrupt epigenetic landscapes and lead to cancer. These findings are expected to pave new avenues for the development of cancer therapeutics in tumors harboring histone mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In this project, we aim to define how misregulation of histone H3K36 methylation by oncohistones promotes tumorigenesis. Specifically, our study will provide new insights into the role of H3K36-directed methyltransferases and the H3.3 G34 and H3 K36M oncohistones in cancer biology. Results from our studies will provide new insights into molecular targets for disease diagnosis and advance therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the insights gained by the accomplishments of the proposed studies will help in elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying ethanol-induced birth defects and characterizing a novel, exosome-mediated intercellular interaction between neural crest cells and placodes during ethanol-induced teratogenesis. These studies are expected to establish the administration of edible plant-derived exosome-like nanoparticles as a novel strategy for the prevention of human FASD. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIAAA's mission that pertains to using the knowledge gained in uncovering target sites for alcohol's action on the embryonic and fetal stages of life to begin developing potential therapeutic or preventative interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: LAY SUMMARY Diet and nutrition have well-recognized significance in human development and health, and diseases, particularly the common chronic diseases, such as obesity, cancer, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes mellitus, but the underlying molecular and biochemical mechanisms are often unknown, which hinder the development of effective and specific interventions. Furthermore, these chronic and life-threatening diseases also show remarkable disparities in diverse populations, including the underrepresented and underserved groups, highlighting the urgent need for employing novel approaches such as precision nutrition analyses empowered by artificial intelligence and machine learning for growing data sources. This training program will produce doctoral scientists with cross-disciplinary breadth and knowledge in artificial intelligence for precision nutrition science research as the innovators and leaders to improve nutrition health and prevent and treat nutrition-related chronic diseases, with special attention to the unique populations found in Hawaii.
PROJECT_TERMS: Artificial Intelligence;Hawaii;Nutritional Science;precision nutrition;Research;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: The Hawaii Advanced Training in Artificial Intelligence for Precision Nutrition Science Research (AIPrN)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Evidence supports tailoring cancer screening to each individual’s risk. We propose to enhance and disseminate software that scans electronic health records of target patient populations to (i) automatically identify those who may benefit from genetic testing for hereditary cancers according to national cancer guidelines; and (ii) use automated “chatbots” for patient outreach offering patient education and the opportunity to receive at-home genetic testing for hereditary cancers. Through wide dissemination, our software platform has the potential to reduce cancer burden by enabling evidence-based cancer screening tailored to the individual.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative A comparative effectiveness study of buprenorphine vs. methadone vs. morphine for the pharmacological treatment of Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (NOWS). Outcome measures include: length of hospital stay, length of pharmacological treatment and neurodevelopmental outcomes up to 24 months of age. Identifying the optimal treatment can shorten the time of maternal-newborn separation, decrease the costs of treatment for NOWS and ensure that the chosen medication does not have adverse developmental outcomes compared to other medication options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Postpartum depression can be prevented by the Reach Out, Stay Strong, Essentials for mothers of newborns (ROSE) evidence-based program yet continues to affect nearly 600,000 women and their families annually. Our goal is to help reduce rates of PPD by finishing development of a full app-based ROSE program (e-ROSE), evaluate the app’s outcomes for depression and return on investment, and determine if satisfaction and perceived access mediate outcomes. At the end of the project, the e-ROSE product will be ready for commercialization nationwide, allowing for easy, low-cost distribution on a variety of platforms to end-users, and we will have laid the groundwork for further research on implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy arising from the temporal lobes is a major public health problem for which there is only symptomatic therapeutics. Developing preventive and disease modifying therapies for human epilepsy is a glaring unmet medical need. This proposed study is to identify novel small molecule inhibitors for inhibiting the signaling pathway required for development of temporal lobe epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A significant portion of adult patients with depression exhibit increased inflammation, which has been associated with impaired corticostriatal reward circuitry and symptoms of anhedonia. Preclinical and clinical evidence from our group and others demonstrates that inflammation impacts corticostriatal circuitry by decreasing the availability and release of dopamine. The current proposal builds upon our prior work and aims to develop potential new treatment interventions for adult patients with depression and high inflammation by targeting reward circuitry and anhedonia through the use of a dopaminergic therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE APOL1 genetic variations have been shown to explain in part the increased risk of African Americans compared to non-African American for end-stage kidney disease. However, the association of APOL1 high risk alleles with kidney transplant outcomes such as change of kidney function, acute rejection and graft failure is unclear. We propose to determine if the presence of APOL1 risk alleles in donor and recipients is associated with recipient kidney transplant outcomes as well as determine the impact of kidney donation for individuals with APOL1 risk alleles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Overall NARRATIVE The Houston Center for Acquired Resistance Research (H-CARR) will act as the organizing entity for a multi- institutional, multi-disciplinary effort to detect acquired cisplatin resistance early in development and generate molecular and metabolic strategies for overcoming it. Investigators from Baylor College of Medicine and the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center will investigate interactions between cancer cells, infiltrating immunocytes and neurons to both understand the critical drivers of cisplatin resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and develop precision oncology approaches to its clinical utilization in this deadly cancer and other similar solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are important human viral pathogens responsible for cervical cancer and more than 70% of head, neck, and throat cancers (HNT), which are on the rise, especially in a younger group of non- smoking men aged 40s and 50s. There are no effective treatments for HPV infection and the subsequent potential for malignant transformation has a serious effect on public health. This proposal is aimed at understanding HPV-host interactions that represents a significant gap in knowledge that is critical to drive research into improved health care of HPV-infected patients and improved vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Plasticity underlies learning, and can partially mitigate the impact of neurodegenerative conditions.  Studying changes of neural interactions in the healthy brain at the cellular-level in vivo is necessary to  understand how they become altered in disease (e.g., Stroke, Alzheimer's disease). Specifically, this  project will lead to theory-grounded experimental studies of reorganization of cortical networks in an animal  model of stroke, paving a path for therapeutic targeted enhancements of plasticity counteracting impacts of  stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Suicide is a major public health imperative in the US, and the rate of suicide is significantly higher among patients with head and neck cancer (HNC) compared with patients with cancer at other sites as well as the general US population. Screening for suicidal ideation and behavior is known to be an evidence-based suicide prevention strategy, and the Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) is considered the ideal suicide ideation screening tool. Our research will contribute to suicide prevention and mitigation by administering the C-SSRS in an HNC care setting, and evaluate the potential implementability of the tool in routine HNC care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Technology in current small animal radiation research (SARR) has significantly lagged behind that in human radiotherapy (RT), impairing SARR study relevance to human RT, impeding explorations in RT research, and hindering rapid conduction of SARR studies. This project will develop a next-generation SARR platform with novel imaging, planning, delivery, and computation techniques to fill this critical void between SARR and human RT. The developed system will become an essential component in preclinical research for the exploration of novel radiotherapeutic strategies with high relevance to human RT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative In order to continually grow, cancer cells need to maintain telomeres which if not maintained by some form of telomere maintenance mechanism (TMM) done by telomerase, an enzyme that adds telomeric repeats to the ends of chromosomes or by the alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) mechanism. This project will define parameters that impact on two assays needed to define cancer TMM as prognostic markers and companion diagnostics for novel drugs: TERT mRNA expression qPCR and the unique PCR assay for telomeric DNA C-circles, which provides a specific marker for ALT cancers. We will also develop an assay to detect C-circles in patient blood samples and complete regulatory steps needed for clinical implementation of these assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sickle cell anemia is an inherited blood disorder that affects millions of children across the world, mostly in sub- Saharan Africa, who will suffer from serious complications, including death, if treatment is not available. Hydroxyurea, a once daily oral medication has been shown to improve most symptoms and reduce mortality for children and adults with sickle cell anemia but is rarely used in many limited-resource settings due in part to concerns about appropriate dosing and monitoring. The primary objectives of this research study are to establish the feasibility and evaluate the clinical benefits of personalized hydroxyurea dosing and to evaluate the safety of hydroxyurea use with limited laboratory monitoring for children with sickle cell anemia living in Angola and Tanzania to provide evidence that will allow for expanded access to this lifesaving medication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with ischemic left ventricular (LV) dysfunction commonly undergo coronary revascularization as a strategy to improve contractile function, but response varies and is poorly predicted by conventional imaging approaches to identify salvageable (“viable”) myocardium. It is unknown if impact of revascularization on contractile recovery varies based on hypoperfusion, if non-ischemic substrate modifies revascularization response, and if contractile recovery parallels improved clinical prognosis. This study will leverage a new multicenter trial (STICH-3C) to test utility of multiparametric cardiac MRI - including perfusion, non-ischemic subtrate, and infarct imaging using a new black blood MRI approach - for prediction of LV response to revascularization, so as to enhance decision-making and improve clinical outcomes for millions of patients with ischemic heart disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Our understanding in human placenta and its abnormalities is limited, because we do not have a medical imaging device to non-invasively observe the blood flow in the small vessels of human placenta in vivo. To fill this gap, we propose to build a semi-real-time ultrasound vector flow velocity imaging system using deep learning models to provide detailed and quantitative imaging of the flow velocity magnitudes and flow directions in human placenta. The successful completion of the project will provide a novel ultrasound imaging technology for the scientific investigation and early clinical assessment of placental development and abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with diabetes are at increased risk of developing osteomyelitis or severe chronic bone infection, a debilitating condition characterized by bone loss often resulting in amputations, which poses a significant health burden. Current medical approaches for treating diabetic bone infection (osteomyelitis) are limited by (a) biofilm formation, (b) development of bacterial resistance, and (c) use of nondegradable antibiotic-delivering bone cements, which require additional removal surgery and show potential toxicity. To solve this important problem, we aim to develop an innovative drug-device combination based on rational engineering of the next-generation antibiotic that can retard resistance and an injectable nanostructured bone cement that can effectively deliver antibiotics, gradually degrade, and regenerate bone tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative AIDS 2024, the 25th International AIDS Conference, will be held from 22-26 July 2024 in Munich (Germany) and virtually. With an expected attendance of 15,000 participants, it will be an essential convening to bring together all stakeholders to review the evidence, debate course corrections, renew the global consensus that the AIDS crisis is not over and unite the global HIV response behind an evidence-based approach that puts people first, the theme chosen for AIDS 2024. Germany offers a compelling location as a center of scientific excellence and a leader of the HIV response in Europe. The special focus of the conference on the fast-growing HIV epidemic in Central and Eastern Europe will translate into implementation science and policy discussions on the challenges of sustaining HIV efforts in contexts of political neglect, armed conflict and displacement, and a strong involvement of scientists, policy makers and implementers from the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Transcription factors control gene expression by binding near target genes to regulate their expression. How transcription factors find their target sites remains poorly understood, yet dysregulation of gene expression is a major cause of disease. Here we propose to resolve this using a new microscope modality that allows tracking of single transcription factors at extremely high spatiotemporal resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Understanding how cancer cells reprogram their metabolism and interact with other biological processes to gain aggressiveness and/or resistance to a treatment is of paramount significance to advancing current diagnosis and treatment strategies. Bio-orthogonal mid-infrared photothermal imaging will be developed to quantitatively measure various metabolites at subcellular level. This technology will open exciting opportunities for molecule- based precision diagnosis and discovery of novel targets for precision treatment of cancers and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how dopamine neuronal circuits are affected by methamphetamine-induced mitochondrial oxidative damage will help to identify the cellular mechanism that leads to methamphetamine addiction. Here, we will use a cell to system integrative approach with transcriptomics, bioinformatics and viral neuronal tracing technologies to identify anatomical, metabolic, and molecular characteristics of dopamine microcircuits vulnerable or resistant to chronic methamphetamine self-administration. In the long-term, our research will contribute knowledge to develop novel therapeutics to offer a healthier life quality for those fighting addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Peptide macromolecules are an attractive therapeutic class for treating a variety of conditions, but their poor absorption in the GI tract has made oral delivery a significant challenge. Syntis Bio is developing an oral therapeutics platform, GSEL, that increases the GI residence time of peptide drugs to improve their systemic absorption. This project aims to identify GSEL-compatible formulations of model peptide drugs and create tablets for oral delivery.

IC_NAME: Center for Global Health
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed public health and academic research network (iPHAC-IDC) brings in-country partners in infectious diseases prevention and control in Thailand from the Department of Diseases Control, the Department of Medical Sciences, the Thai Red Cross Society, Chulalongkorn University, and world-class international partners to build a pandemic preparedness system by developing faster and wiser outbreak response using molecular, serologic, and data integration tools. In addition, this team will develop and implement a post- graduate GLLP curriculum at Chulalongkorn University for sustainable and long-term public health workforce development. The network will conduct HIV and STI prevention and detection research to reduce new HIV cases in Thailand by developing adolescent HIV prevention with pre-exposure prophylaxis using social network strategies and enhancing the gonorrhea antimicrobial resistance surveillance system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke injury and recovery are often made worse by comorbid metabolic conditions including obesity and diabetes yet there are few evidence-based stroke-treatments that address these interactions. Testing of experimental stroke here has identified a novel synaptic mechanism of the corticospinal motor pathway that may underpin comorbid metabolic conditions impeding stroke recovery. This proposal aims to fully understand this synaptic mechanism in order to guide its future targeted treatment as a novel therapy for stroke recovery in the context of clinically- relevant comorbid metabolic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HIV co-infection accelerates liver cirrhosis and liver cancer in chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) carriers. In addition, HIV is associated with more severe fatty liver disease. The use of unique primary cell culture models and humanized mice under conditions that maintain or disrupt the circadian rhythm of hepatocytes will determine the interaction of HIV co-infections and co-morbidities with the circadian rhythm. These studies will provide information for HIV pathogenesis in the liver and may help the development of novel antiviral strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rapid and effective diagnosis of Lyme Disease (LD) is an urgent and unmet clinical need. If diagnosed early and treated with appropriate antibiotics, outcomes for LD are typically excellent, but delays in treatment result in arthritis, carditis, or neuroborreliosis. The current standard of care for in-vitro diagnosis, relying on serological tests, lacks both specificity and sensitivity, and cannot distinguish among an active and previous infection. Molecular diagnostic methods for direct detection, while widely appreciated to be the path forward, have persistently demonstrated poor sensitivity. HelixBind has developed RaPID/LD, a best-in-class diagnostic test for the detection of early LD directly from blood with markedly improved performance attributes compared to any other commercially available test. In this CRP, HelixBind will complete the tasks necessary to launch RaPID/LD. The information provided would provide the clinician with objective information on how to identify patients with an active infection weeks before serological test results are useful.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Chronic wounds impose a significant and growing health care burden worldwide, and current therapeutic approaches show limited effectiveness. Topical application of the recombinant fibronectin protein, GST/FNIII1H,8,10 to full-thickness excisional wounds in genetically-diabetic mice enhances granulation tissue deposition, stimulates epithelial maturation, and promotes revascularization. The goal of this project is to advance a smaller, tagless version of this protein (FNIII1H,8,10) towards clinical application by characterizing its ability to promote healing of full thickness dermal wounds in both small (diabetic mice) and large (diabetic pigs) animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a leading cause of heart failure and death, and there is an urgent need to identify new molecular targets that could lead to the development of more effective treatment strategies. Our research is focused on a protein called ATF4, which acts as a switch that turns on genes essential for cardiac muscle function. By studying how ATF4 works, we hope to understand how mutations case DCM and identify new ways to treat patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The goal of this proposal is to develop an effective therapy for treatment of Chronic Heart Failure (CHF), especially focused on CHF patients that have progressed to acute decompensated heart failure. The therapeutic benefit afforded by the Selective Cytopheretic Device (SCD) for treatment of CHF is based on its ability to improve cardiac function by reducing the chronic inflamed state of CHF which diminishes the pumping action of the heart The relevance of the work in this proposal to the general public is to evaluate this form of therapy in CHF patients who are so severely ill that they are not eligible for heart transplantation or the artificial heart, hoping that this treatment will improve heart function in these patients in order to bridge them to life sustaining treatment with the artificial heart.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Oxytocin is a maternal hormone important for childbirth, parent-child bonding, and social cognition. However, it is unclear how, when, or where oxytocin acts in the brain to enable successful parenting and social behavior, especially if it might act in males to promote paternal behavior. The experiments to be performed in this proposal provide essential data on the action of oxytocin in the central nervous system, required for improvement of therapeutic strategies for treatment of parental neglect or other conditions relating to social interactions and childcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  The gold standard of malaria diagnosis is microscopic analysis of Giemsa‐stained blood smears. Highly trained microscopists can detect about 3 parasites per microliter of blood. A large number of molecular diagnostics are in use and in development with varying degrees of sensitivity and quality control. PCR‐based methods can be more sensitive but require the use of relatively expensive reagents and equipment. The ability to detected low levels of parasitemia (below 3 per l) and identify the species of parasite is key to early treatment and surveillance efforts. There is a great need for inexpensive and instrument‐free diagnostics that can detect low level parasitemia. In previous studies, we have developed a multi‐chambered FAST diagnostic device that is pre‐loaded with lysis, amplification, and CRISPR/Cas12a reagents for the detection of several pathogens. The diagnostic does not require electricity, instruments, or highly trained personnel and is designed for point‐of‐care or field diagnostics. We propose to adapt this novel device for sensitive detection of malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical trials of complementary and integrative health (CIH) interventions, along with their applications, have grown exponentially and there is an urgent need for rigorously conducted systematic reviews and meta-analyses to synthesize evidence to guide stakeholders and inform policy and decision making. We propose the Mindfulness and Integrative Health Data Network (MINDNET) to create a highly usable and accessible data repository, with advanced web interface and R programming for data analysis, as well as pilot awards and asynchronous and synchronous education and training. MINDNET will generate high quality systematic reviews, meta-analyses, and methodology papers from the investigative team and pilot awards to provide clear synthesis of evidence across populations, interventions, conditions, and outcomes (PICOs) for stakeholder use, as well as training and education to foster skills, collaboration, and innovation within the CIH scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: LASARRUS CLINIC AND RESEARCH CENTER, INC.
PHR: Narrative: This SBIR Fast-Track project proposes a groundbreaking mobile health system using a wearable multimodal sensor, WearME, to remotely monitor chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients, the third leading cause of death worldwide. Leveraging the expertise of our multidisciplinary team, the project aims to improve patient adherence to remote monitoring, enable early symptom detection, and reduce healthcare costs and COPD readmissions, particularly in underserved communities. By achieving FDA 510(k) clearance, we aspire to revolutionize COPD management, enhance health outcomes, and substantially impact the $117.1 billion remote patient monitoring market.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE On behalf of the NIH-DOD-VA Pain Management Collaboratory (PMC), the Pain Management Collaboratory Coordinating Center (PMC3) will continue to provide national leadership and serve as a national resource for development and refinement of innovative tools, best practices, and other resources in the conduct of high impact pragmatic clinical trials (PCTs) on nonpharmacological approaches for pain management and other comorbid conditions in Veteran or military healthcare systems. In the next six-year continuation phase of the PMC, we will support the successful completion and widespread dissemination and implementation activities of the originally funded PCTs, support the successful enactment of new PCTs, and continue to generate new knowledge and resources in the service of improving the design and conduct of future PCTs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Somatic mutations that alter the 3D proteome and molecular pathways drive the malignant transformation of single cells. Here, we develop a novel protein footprinting technology to determine aberrations in protein conformation and protein-protein interactions in single cancer cells. Understanding the heterogeneity of the 3D proteome in tumors at a single cell resolution might allow us to find out why anti-cancer drugs only partially inhibit cell growth in a tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement)  In the proposed project, we will use a novel nano formulation of small interfering siRNA to mitigate neuroinflammation and attenuate neurological diseases including Alzheimer's disease (AD). In our approach, siRNA of the key inflammation regulator, NFκB (siNFκB) is sequestered in exosomes (native nanoparticles) isolated from standardized bovine colostrum powder, the exosomes are attached to folic acid to target the brain sub tissues such as cortex and hippocampus, and the formulation is delivered trans-spinally by topical application for efficient brain targeting. The novel formulation will be optimized using mouse cell lines and the trans-spinal delivery system tested using mouse models for inflammation and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA is a central regulator of cell biology, canonically considered an intracellular regulator, unable to directly interface with the extracellular space. Bolstered by recent evidence of cell surface RNAs and glycosylated RNAs, as well as long-standing but poorly characterized examples of a small set of cell surface RNA binding proteins, we aim to define a new paradigm, one where RNA biology is a common and functional component of the cell surface. Our work will establish foundational tools, mechanisms, and functions for cell surface RNA biology, enabling others to build on our observations and update the molecular models of what molecules are present on the surface of cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We are developing two-photon excited fluorescence ophthalmoscopy as a non-invasive, cellular-scale imaging tool to assess in the living eye two functions important for retinal health: the visual cycle and cellular metabolism. Changes with TPEFO properties of excited retinal fluorophores will be measured in response to visual stimulation under normal conditions and, as an analogue to retinal disease, with systemic hypoxia. In future, this new imaging modality may help improve understanding of early disease processes, diagnosis of retinal disease, monitoring of disease progression, and evaluation of treatment efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE  Aging and neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD), are associated with alterations in nuclear structure, chromatin dysregulation, genome instability, and transcriptome changes. Chromatin associated RNAs (caRNAs) are intimately associated with the regulation and maintenance of genome organization and transcription, but no high-throughput and standardized methods exist to characterize caRNAs at features of interest. Here, EpiCypher is developing a highly sensitive and scalable platform to identify caRNAs at targeted features to accelerate the discovery of aging and AD/ADRD biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative Providing high-quality instruction and sufficient access to physical education (PE) in elementary schools is a national priority for improving health and educational outcomes for children. Innovative resources targeting elementary classroom teachers, who are increasingly assuming the roles of physical educators with minimal training or experience, are needed for them to deliver effective evidence- and standards-based PE. The project seeks to complete the full development of all digital app features and content of the Pocket PE 3-5TM program (begun in Phase I) for broad-scale commercialization and dissemination to elementary schools and to test initial effectiveness of the program with a diverse school-based sample in a clustered randomized trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative It is estimated that more than 2.5 million individuals in the United States develop pressure injuries annually. Persons living with Alzheimer's disease or a related dementia (ADRD), both in long-term care facilities and private residences, are at an increased risk for pressure injury formation. This project aims to develop an innovative chair to prevent and/or treat pressure injuries in persons living with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this project is to develop clinical image analysis software which will automatically detect and quantify the amyloid related imaging abnormalities (ARIA) during the treatment of Alzheimer’s patients to monitor the effects of the therapeutic intervention, and to improve patient management. The software will use non-invasive MR images with T1, FLAIR and T2* contrasts and report the number of lesions, their volume, and their anatomical locations. These tabulated results, with the images containing highlighted ARIA lesions will help clinicians both to determine the drug response, and to decide to continue with the drug therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) is critical during pregnancy for women living with HIV (PWHIV) for optimal maternal and fetal health, but there are knowledge gaps in pharmacology of new HIV drugs, adverse effect profile, and safety in pregnancy that prevent efficient and effective deployment of our most promising new ART in pregnant women. The objective of this proposal is to advance our knowledge of adverse effect profile associated with -- Dolutegravir (DTG), Tenofovir Disoproxil Fumarate (TDF), and Lamivudine drug combination --in PWHIV and their offspring, using advanced “omics” technologies (integrated proteomics and metabolomics). Research goals include clinical and biomarker characterization of metabolic syndrome, and providing insights into the mechanistic intricacies of metabolic syndrome in large community-based cohorts of black and white PWHIV in the US and Nigeria, with the overall goal of optimizing HIV therapeutics for PWHIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) affects millions of people in the Unites States. Stress and anxiety in those with AUD increase the chance of relapse. In this application Soovu Labs examines a new method of treating stress and anxiety by direct stimulation of targets in the peripheral nervous system specifically TRPV-1 channels and C tactile fibers, and will create a new drug free device to support those with AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: L-asparaginases (ASNases), which are essential drugs for treating pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), also have tremendous potential for use in adults with ALL – as well as other indications including both solid and blood tumors – were it not for the severe toxicity seen with today’s FDA-approved ASNases, especially when given to adults. In previous work, we developed a novel mammalian ASNase, EBD-300, that is significantly better tolerated than the currently approved bacterial versions, while still maintaining the same high efficacy. In this application, we will engineer a next generation version of EBD-300 to have a significantly longer in vivo persistence, which is an essential property for this drug to become the most impactful in 1st line ALL treatment and in the treatment of additional cancers comprising mainly adults where patients can be selected based on biomarkers for sensitivity to asparagine depletion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Kaposi's Sarcoma Herpesvirus (KSHV) is the etiologic agent of Kaposi's Sarcoma, the most common tumor of AIDS patients worldwide. While KSHV is an oncogenic virus little is known about how KSHV initiates growth and cancer formation. These studies will determine the mechanism of KSHV induction of the first steps of tumor cells formation in lymphatic endothelial cells, a cell type relevant to KS tumor cells, leading to better avenues to treat KS tumors through specific inhibition of KS tumor cell proliferation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent studies in mice suggest that specific types of retinal ganglion cells, the neurons that degenerate in glaucoma, are more susceptible to injury. However, translating these findings to the human condition is not straightforward since the mouse and human eye differ in several major ways, including the ocular structures and types of retinal ganglion cells found in the two species. Here we propose a detailed multi-modal assessment of the mechanisms underlying ganglion cell susceptibility in a highly clinically relevant model of glaucoma, which will lead to improved understanding of the disease, novel targets for earlier diagnosis and treatment, and in turn, better options for glaucoma patients to preserve and potentially improve their vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Acquired tracheobronchomalacia (TBM) is an under-diagnosed/misdiagnosed disease causing the airway to collapse on itself with few safe and effective treatment options that, until recently with the develop- ment of minimally invasive TBM repair (R-TBP), resulted in high morbidity, a long recovery period, and high mortality, limiting viability for broad patient treatment. Lazzaro Medical, Inc. is developing a novel LM Scaffold SystemTM to enable widespread adoption of R-TBP by reducing the technical complexity and skill necessary in current procedures that require custom fabrication of generic surgical mesh peri-operatively. The LM Scaffold device and procedure will offer an efficient and practical solution suitable for mainstream thoracic surgery facili- ties to deliver lower risk TBM surgical intervention in the hands of mainstream thoracic surgeons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Current drapery solutions for MRI, CT, and PET scanners are inconvenient to install, prone to failure during use, and can impede image-guided procedures. An important application for drapery for radiological scanners is Emergency Room- based scanners, which can become soiled and unusable for 1-2 hours. Finally, with a recent rise in Hospital-Acquired Infection (HAI), the International Society for Infectious Disease recommends use of a disposable plastic barrier changed between each patient as a best practice for preventing infectious in the radiology department. Our product, Saf-T-Drape, is a semi-rigid liner for the scanner bore that is easily installed, easily disposed, economical for single-patient use, robust against patient movement, and does not interfere with procedures. We propose designing and building prototypes, and testing them in realistic clinical environments. We will examine the effect on image quality for MRI and CT images, we will test the ability of Saf-T-Drape to mitigate scanner-patient cross infection, and we will examine usability and durability factors. The goal is to characterize Saf-T-Drape with regard to image quality, patient safety aspects, and mitigation of disease transmission, so our clinical colleagues can justify requesting approvals to test Saf-T-Drape in a realistic clinical environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Flow cytometry is an essential tool in modern cellular and molecular biology, where the technique is critical in a variety of applications including the diagnosis of cancer and complex cellular assays in pharmaceutical develop- ment and medical research, amongst many others. However, the design and development of modern cytometry experiments is highly complex and error prone. In this project, FluoroFinder will advance development of the IntelliPanel to automatically generate reliable flow cytometry panels tailored to a user’s experimental and instru- ment configurations to yield significant time and cost savings, reduce or eliminate design errors, and lower the barrier to entry for developing successful flow cytometry experiments.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project narrative: This proposal entitled "Defining the epidemiology, diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of invasive fungal infections in the United States" is a broad and ambitious project which seeks to enhance the overall understanding of invasive mycoses in the general population, but also in individuals who are at enhanced risk of complications from these infections. The project will be coordinated through the MSG Central Unit located at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, and will involve the participation of a large number of clinical and laboratory investigators from centers across the country who share the specific interest in clinical mycology. The overarching goal of this project is to reduce morbidity and mortality of invasive fungal infections through greater understanding of their epidemiology, risk factors for acquisition, and specific interventions which might lead to better overall outcomes for individuals with these complex infections.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK-23-001, Clinical and Applied Research Strategies for the Prevention and Control of Fungal Diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We lack knowledge on the health status of hotel housekeepers (HHs) hired through Non-Standard Work Arrangement (NSWA). To address this federally identified gap and in response to PAR-18-797 we propose to conduct a mixed-method study which aims to 1) Describe the health status of HHs hired through NSWA compared to those hired through Standard Work (SW), and 2) to understand the lived experiences of HHs hired through NSWA. This line of inquiry is well aligned with NIOSH’s Healthy Work Design and Well-Being program which identified NSWA as one of its three priority areas.

PROJECT_TITLE: Non-Standard Work Arrangements, Health and Wellbeing Among Hotel Housekeepers

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes is a common chronic condition, affecting an estimated 34.1 million adults, or 13% of all U.S. adults age 18 and older; it also disproportionately affects individuals with lower education and socio-economic status. Diabetes treatment adherence is critical for preventing complications; yet research on diabetes management behaviors does not consider necessary work design factors that may inhibit adherence. This study will assess work-related factors that may lead to work-health management interference, diabetes self-management, and work ability in U.S. full-time blue-collar and service sector workers with diabetes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Work Design, Self-Management, and Work Ability in Workers with Diabetes
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

PHR: Ulnar neuropathy at the elbow is a common condition that can cause pain, tingling and muscle loss in the hand. Surgery is often recommended to eliminate symptoms but controversy exists over the best procedure. We plan to conduct a multicenter randomized clinical trial to compare outcomes for two commonly used surgical procedures and develop an optimal surgical plan for individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sustainable interventions are needed to improve diet and cardiovascular health in American Indians (AIs). However, most efforts to improve health in AIs have been ineffective— likely due in part to an inadequate understanding of multi-level (i.e., individual- , household- , and community- level) factors that may impact diet and cardiovascular risk factors, including multi-level components of the physical environment and socio-cultural environment in rural Tribal Nations. The proposed project will generate knowledge to inform future cardiovascular health interventions by examining community-, household-, and individual-level factors on diet and cardiovascular risk in the largest and longest-ongoing multi-generational and multi-tribal cohort study of AIs from 12 rural communities in the USA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alaska Native people have the highest reported colorectal cancer burden in the world, yet only half have been screened for this disease, which could save lives. This multi-level, mixed-methods randomized controlled trial will investigate the effectiveness of a new at-home multi-target stool DNA test (MT-sDNA; Cologuard) to improve colorectal cancer screening rates among Alaska Native people living in rural/remote communities. If use of MT-sDNA increases colorectal cancer screening, it will help reduce Alaska Native deaths due to this disease, have broad-reaching clinical and policy impacts, and provide insight into a novel method that could improve screening among other integrated health systems that provide care to high-risk and underserved populations in the United States and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorders (AUD) exact a major personal, economical, and societal toll, highlighting the urgent need for developing effective therapeutics. Reciprocal interactions between autonomic arousal and alcohol consumption play a key role in the etiology of AUD, but the underlying neurobiological mechanisms are poorly understood. By establishing how top-down modulation of arousal by the prefrontal cortex affects drinking and how drinking itself modifies top-down control, this proposal will identify novel neural therapeutic targets for treating excessive drinking driven by aberrant arousal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will enhance our capability to invent therapeutics and subsequently prepare these medicines on large-scale. Inspired by Nature’s catalyst, we develop ideal, environmentally friendly, and powerful ways to transform simple building blocks (aldehydes, alkenes, and alkynes) into architectures relevant to medicine. Our expertise in molecular design and synthesis will also be applied to address challenges at the interface of chemical theory, fluorescent microscopy, and drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: CENTRE FOR ADDICTION AND MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use and other psychiatric disorders are highly heritable (i.e., are strongly influenced by genetics) and often occur together. Our project will apply Big Data approaches to develop an analytic pipeline to elucidate the shared genomic liability, biological mechanisms, and potential causal effects underlying concurrent tobacco use and schizophrenia. This pipeline can be expanded to other pairs of concurrent substance use and psychiatric disorders and may lead to novel early intervention and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chromatin replication is a complex cellular process that requires multiple regulatory mechanisms to maintain genomic and epigenomic stability. The histone H3.1-TSK/TONSL pathway plays a major role in resolving stalled or broken replication forks via homologous recombination. We will further characterize the role of H3.1- TSK/TONSL in regulating DNA repair and genome stability, and define new functions for this conserved pathway during replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Periodontitis (PD), an infection of the oral cavity caused by Gram-negative bacteria, is a risk factor for cardiovascular diseases. Endothelial dysfunction is the initial step in the development of cardiovascular diseases. The goal of this project is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms that contribute to the suppression of NO in PD and to delineate their role in the pathogenesis of endothelial dysfunction in diabetic and non-diabetic rodent models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This study will enroll patients diagnosed with pulmonary embolism (blood clots in the lung) in the emergency department and treat them with either supplemental oxygen or normal room air. The purpose of the study is to determine how supplemental oxygen affects the pulmonary artery, right ventricle, and metabolic processes in patients with these blood clots. We will also perform experiments in pigs with pulmonary emboli to determine how treatment with supplemental oxygen affects the flow of blood through the lungs and cardiac metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Uterine serous carcinomas (USC) are the most aggressive subtype of uterine cancers, yet the molecular drivers of disease spread remains incompletely understood. Previous work by our group and others have identified a recurrent mutational hotspot within the gene encoding for the scaffolding subunit of the protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A), PPP2R1A, that occur almost exclusively within the USC subtype of uterine cancer. These hotspot mutations may contribute to uterine tumorigenesis by inactivating tumor suppressive PP2A function by specifically altering holoenzyme biogenesis thereby inducing dysregulation upon WNT mediated EMT while enhancing tumorigenicity in a manner that promotes USC disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal proteins passed from a mother to her progeny can have a profound impact on animal development and immunity. The goals outlined in this project utilize a molecular biology labeling method to elucidate new, fundamental insights into how maternally made proteins are inherited by progeny. Ultimately, the work provides a foundation to determine the breadth of non-genetic maternal information a mother provides her offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: More than 70 million Americans live with pain, but current painkillers work only in a fraction of patients and cause an array of side effects that include the risk of developing addiction. Recent work suggests that an enzyme called N-acylethanolamine acid amidase (NAAA) is critically involved in pain processing and may be targeted to discover non-addictive medicines to treat acute and chronic pain. Here, we propose a series of experiments aimed at testing this hypothesis and at developing NAAA inhibitors as a novel class of safe and effective painkillers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE . Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common type of lymphoma with a very poor prognosis for patients who are diagnosed with relapsed or refractory (r/r) disease. Here we propose to test a promising treatment approach combining a clinical stage intravenously administered oncolytic Vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) with a novel dually targeted checkpoint inhibitor (ONIx) in dogs with r/r DLBCL, to guide clinical development of this novel combination therapy for patients with r/r DLBCL. Detailed analyses to characterize the impact of combination therapy on the DLBCL tumor architecture and comparison of features of tumor microenvironment in responding versus nonresponding dogs will allow us to identify potential, clinically actionable biomarkers of response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is remarkable that ~50% of phenotypic variation and disease in twins and inbred organisms cannot be explained by genetics or environmental effects. We suggest that a significant portion of unexplained disease heterogeneity reflects molecularly encoded but inherently probabilistic properties of the genome, evolved to generate variability within any given context. If true, then we will open the door to a third dimension of precision medicine that answers “what is a normal physiological state for me”, and harness that insight to develop fundamentally new predictive, diagnostic, and therapeutic interventions, irrespective of the disease of interest.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed project is to conduct a randomized clinical efficacy trial (RCT) of a novel guided imagery tobacco cessation intervention delivered by phone. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) continue to pose a significant risk to human health, and both human and animal studies have identified the developing brain as a target of concern. While developmental exposures to at least a subset of the higher chlorinated PCBs found in the commercial PCB mixtures synthesized prior to the worldwide ban on PCB production have been identified as developmental neurotoxicants, the potential for the contemporary lower-chlorinated PCBs (LC-PCBs) that are detected in human brain and blood to interfere with neurodevelopment is understudied. The objective of the proposed research is leverage primary neuron-glia co- cultures derived from a unique animal model to evaluate the developmental neurotoxicity of LC-PCBs found in human tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Southeastern Center for Microscopy of MacroMolecular Machines (SECM4), at Florida State University will be a service center that will enable cryo-EM sample preparation, screening, high- resolution data collection, and training for universities around the Southeast. The SECM4 will lower the barrier to access to cryo-EM for users by making expensive cryo-EM instrumentation available without requiring universities to build their own facilities. The SECM4 will achieve further economies of scale by addressing the biggest bottleneck in cryo-EM right now which is by improving cryo-EM specimen optimization and screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to determine the efficacy and histopathologic effects on synovitis of 6 months of methotrexate (n=100) versus placebo (n=50) therapy for chronic CHIKV arthritis in Colombia in a randomized controlled trial. Our central hypothesis is that methotrexate will significantly decrease chronic CHIKV arthritis disease severity compared to placebo and suppress leukocyte accumulation and inflammatory cytokine expression in synovial tissue. In Aim 1, we will determine the efficacy of oral methotrexate treatment versus placebo for 6 months in chronic CHIKV arthritis, in Aim 2, we will determine the effect of methotrexate on synovial inflammation by obtaining synovial biopsy samples before and after treatment in order to precisely define the role of methotrexate in the treatment of chronic CHIKV arthritis with the goal of advancing the field towards an evidence-based standard treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mammalian anti-viral response is partially regulated by post-translational modifications (PTMs) like phosphorylation. ADP-ribosylation is another type of PTM that is implicated in the anti-viral response, however little is known about how it hinders virus infections. The primary objective of this proposal is to determine how ADP-ribosylation inhibits virus replication and enhances the host immune response, with the goal of developing a better understanding of the mammalian anti-viral response that could lead to novel anti-viral therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As we have previously reported, skeletal sensory nerve fibers critically regulate multiple aspects of bone morphogenesis, response to mechanical load, and bone repair. Yet, the molecular underpinnings that underlie these phenotypic consequences are only now becoming clear. Here, we will precisely define how TrkA+ skeletal sensory nerve axons spatially approximate osteogenic precursors in the developing bone in order to induce skeletal stem cell expansion and coordinately inhibit their differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplants are used to treat certain cancers of the blood and bone marrow. Diseased bone marrow is removed and replaced with healthy cells, but patients are at high risk for infection and other life-threatening inflammatory conditions until the healthy cells expand enough to restart the immune system. Ship of Theseus is developing therapeutic strategy to shorten this window of risk and improve patient outcomes by developing a novel and safe drug, HOXB4(m), that improves HSC expansion within the patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in 100 children worldwide are diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), with diverse symptoms such as social impairment, communication difficulties, and restrictive or repetitive behaviors beginning in early childhood. Thousands of non-coding de novo variants (DNVs) have been identified in individuals with autism, and this proposal will investigate whether DNVs found in human neuronal enhancers alter their regulatory activity and influence expression of downstream gene networks previously implicated in ASD. Deciphering the genetic contributions underlying ASD will enable more thorough diagnostic tools and inform more precise and effective care options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Millions of American teens do not receive appropriate mental health care; teens from underserved populations face the greatest barriers. The proposed research will harness existing digital mental health technologies, such as computerized assessments and mobile health [mHealth] apps, to develop a screening and treatment system which we will then implement and evaluate for engagement outcomes in a pediatric primary care clinic on the West Side of Chicago. The knowledge gained from this project will demonstrate the real-world engagement, acceptability, access, and use of these digital mental health technologies to decrease pediatric mental health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Distant metastases are responsible for the vast majority of cancer deaths, but there is currently a lack of effective anti-metastatic therapies. Collective invasion, in which cohesive packs of cancer cells travel together, is a major mode of metastasis observed in patients across solid tumor types. A better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the cooperation between heterogeneous subpopulations that comprise these invasive packs could lead to new targeted therapies for the prevention and treatment of cancer metastasis in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to understand the roles of post-abscission midbodies (MBs). We already have shown that these MBs are internalized by neighboring cells where they form a novel signaling organelles known as MBsomes. Importantly, it was suggested that the accumulation of intra-cellular MBsomes regulates cell proliferation and differentiation. Thus, completion of this project will identify and characterize the molecular machinery governing the internalization and formation of MBsomes, as well as will define signaling pathways that mediate MBsome function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with asthma are at risk for abnormal lung function growth, lower lung function in adulthood, and adult obstructive lung disease, which are associated with increased mortality risk. The project will examine the effects of indoor allergen exposure and allergen reduction on long-term lung function growth and explore their effects on biomarkers of pulmonary fibrosis and remodeling. This work is designed to test the hypothesis that allergen exposure reduction improves lung function trajectory among children with allergic asthma, which, if true, would have a major public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This study will assess whether a novel class of drugs (dual CCR2/CCR5 antagonists), can be used to improve vascular and metabolic health in people living with HIV. The study will determine if the intervention reduces arterial inflammation, (a primary disease-causing feature of plaque in the arteries), reduces adipose tissue inflammation, and improves insulin resistance (the driver of diabetes). The study will be performed across multiple sites in the United States, in collaboration with an established AIDS research network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Lung cancer remains one of the deadliest malignancies in the United States. Metastasis is the main cause of lung cancer patient death. Our application focuses on a novel mechanism regulating lung cancer metastasis and the role for autophagy related gene in this process. Our studies are expected to not only improve our understanding of the ways in which lung cancer metastasizes, but also form the basis for future developing novel therapeutic strategies for this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Organofluorine compounds, PFAS (per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances) have generated increased public attention due to their potential health hazard and widespread presence in the environment. We will identify possible PFAS toxicological effects on tooth development in a mouse model. Once PFAS toxicological effects are identified in tooth formation, PFAS could be considered as a possible causative factor for cryptogenic abnormalities in dentinogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Lysosomal damage is widely involved in many human diseases and can be triggered by various cellular stressors. Successful completion of this project will provide in-depth mechanistic understanding of how lipid remodeling contributes to lysosomal quality control and cellular homeostasis. These findings are expected to open new avenues to therapeutically intervene a wide array of lysosome-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative My research has focused on the overarching theme of how cell surface receptors mediate an invasive phenotype by promoting adaptations that support cell survival in the face of stress. While this is a critical component of physiological remodeling processes such as angiogenesis, tumor cells often hijack these same pathways to promote metastasis and tumor progression. Throughout my career, I have emphasized the combination of basic and translational cancer research which has resulted in one cancer drug recently approved by the FDA and a second drug that has successfully completed Phase III trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Asma Guardián will be among the first Mexican-American-tailored, community-based asthma intervention that is designed to scale to the state-level, can be launched by any entity and designed to empower families to engage in three actions that are known to improve asthma outcomes. We will pilot test Asma Guardián and will have multi-dimensional data on engagement and process measures as well as an estimate of its effects on asthma outcomes, including asthma control and exacerbations. Completion of the proposed aims will strongly position the investigator team to successfully plan and execute a state-wide trial of Asma Guardián.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There are several factors that likely contribute to healthy esophageal muscular function. Yet, our understanding of diseases of the esophageal muscle has thus far been limited to mechanisms of neurally-mediated contraction and relaxation of the esophageal muscle. The goal of this clinical trial is to study the impact of the biomechanical properties such as muscle fibrosis towards the impairments in muscle function in achalasia with the goal of identifying novel treatment targets and improving patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide and poses a significant physical, mental, emotional, and financial burden on patients and their families. Over the last decade there has been an increased prevalence of immunomodulating therapeutics to treat lung cancer, defining the immune systems role, or lack thereof, in disease progression and relapse; however, dose limiting adverse events and tumor resistance mechanisms still limit these reagents potency and efficacy, and thus, their ability to reduce disease burden. We propose to exploit bispecific aptamer technology to develop alternative or adjuvant therapeutics and understand what molecular design properties drive the induction of the greatest anti-cancer response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are estimated to affect up to 150 million people yearly, with uropathogenic Escherichia coli (UPEC) being a significant contributor to these infections. These bacteria live in nutrient-poor environments in the urinary tract and urine, which can favor antibiotic persistence and relapsing infections. This project aims to elucidate molecular mechanisms that are associated with recurrent UPEC infections, to increase the efficacy of existing antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African Americans are less likely to receive genetic testing to determine if they have a genetic mutation associated with increased risk for certain cancers. When testing is done, it is important to share information with relatives to help them determine whether or not they too would benefit from testing; however, it can be difficult to share this information within families. This project will develop and test an intervention specifically tailored for African American families to support their communication about cancer genetic testing results, communication about behaviors that can reduce their cancer risk, and future decisions about whether or not to complete cancer genetic testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The data generated in preclinical cancer research are often unreproducible and not translatable to the clinic. The goal of this proposal is to better understand the full impact of housing conditions on the animal models we rely on for studying cancer and the anti-tumor immune response by studying the influence of laboratory rodent housing temperature on murine CD8+ T cell anti-tumor immunity and response to immunotherapy. The knowledge gained from these studies will have direct implications on the role of laboratory housing conditions as a variable in murine models of cancer and immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative We aim to develop next-generation medical imaging technologies that would allow the creation of hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) biopsy-like images but without cutting the tissue and in real time. This imaging technology may provide both new basic understanding of cancer development, and clinical tools to aid in early diagnosis and tumor margin detection for better treatment management of cancer patients. As a first application, we aim to demonstrate virtual H&E biopsy on brain tumors, ultimately giving surgeons the ability to precisely determine brain tumor margins during surgery but before actually cutting into the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: In the United States, more than 100,000 carotid endarterectomy or stent procedures are performed annually on patients with narrowing of a carotid artery due to atherosclerosis who have not yet experienced symptoms of a stroke. Recent advances in medical management of atherosclerotic disease have raised questions regarding the net benefit of these procedures to prevent stroke. We are requesting support to complete two parallel multicenter randomized clinical trials, one comparing intensive medical management (IMM) vs. endarterectomy plus IMM (n=1240), the other comparing IMM vs. stenting plus IMM (n=1240).

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular phenotypic heterogeneity within tumors, such as subpopulations of cells with increased capacity for self-renewal referred to as cancer stem cells, exists within many cancers is believed to drive resistance to therapies such and radiation and chemotherapy. Our preliminary results in pancreatic cancer revealed a supportive niche of Wnt-secreting cancer cells that drives a Lgr5+ stem-cell-like state in another cancer cell subpopulation, thereby promoting and maintaining stemness within pancreatic tumors. This proposal will test the hypothesis that Wnt-driven cellular phenotypic heterogeneity and stemness promote radioresistance in pancreatic tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Sharing of multicenter, multispecies central nervous system (CNS) injury data provides a unique and clinically-relevant opportunity to discover treatments, if we can develop data management workflows make these data findable, accessible, interoperable and reusable (FAIR). Our team has assembled some of largest repositories of such data spanning across traumatic brain injury and spinal cord injury under prior NIH support. The proposed project will develop, test, and optimize management workflows to help render these raw data into novel insights that lead to treatments for the major health crisis of CNS injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. A healthy nervous system requires the polarization of neurons into structurally and functionally distinct compartments. Both the axon initial segment and the microtubule cytoskeleton play key roles in neuronal polarity, and disruption of either causes profound defects in neuronal structure and function. This project seeks to understand how the axon initial segment and microtubules interact to establish and maintain neuronal polarity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The needs for skilled academic physician-scientists in Pediatric Pulmonary Vascular Disease and multi- institutional, collaborative and rigorous investigation of new treatment modalities with focus on pathobiology and long-term outcomes are clear. The goal of the training program is to increase the number of highly-trained, successfully-funded and sustainable pediatric pulmonary vascular disease physician-scientists, who will perform high level laboratory, clinical-translational research, and/or health services research that will improve our understanding of the pathobiology of pediatric pulmonary vascular disease, and thereby improve short and long- term outcomes for this complex, vulnerable population. This training program uniquely leverages existing collaborative, multicenter and interdisciplinary academic programs as critical infrastructure that will provide outstanding training opportunities for career development in the field.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) Millions of Americans are misdiagnosed each year, sometimes with devastating consequences such as permanent disability or death. This proposal will expand the activities of an existing academic Center for Diagnostic Excellence whose focus is to eliminate patient harms from diagnostic error. Projects supported by this proposal will focus on achieving diagnostic excellence in the emergency department through research and quality improvement activities, including (a) clinical programs to eliminate stroke misdiagnosis, (b) new methods of diagnostic error incident reporting by physicians, and (c) a software tool to help measure the projected return on investment for new diagnostic strategies that will help spread these innovations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Armstrong Institute Center for Diagnostic Excellence-Pursuing Scalable System-Level Diagnostic Quality, Value and Equity by Applying Safety Science to Emergency Department Diagnosis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will develop truly-”2D” proton-photon joint optimization methods for clinically-deliverable truly- hybrid RT with unprecedented superior plan quality to proton-only and photon-only RT, and first-of-its-kind TPS to bridge truly-hybrid RT from research to clinic. This hybrid TPS can facilitate prospective clinical trials of a broad spectrum of treatment sites for many patients. If succeed, truly-hybrid RT via this first-of-its-kind TPS will likely warrant improved clinical outcomes with reduced OAR toxicities, and potentially become a new paradigm for cancer RT in general, with compelling benefits in both treatment cost and clinical outcomes.
