IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative More than five million people in the United States living with Alzheimer’s disease, and this number grows substantially due to the population aging, resulting in burdens on the economy, families and caregivers of patients. While volumetric MRI biomarkers are useful to assess the risk of Alzheimer’s disease, their diagnostic value is still limited since the association between biomarkers and neuropathological changes remains unclear. With the help of advanced high-gradient MRI system, this project will establish an in vivo diffusion MRI microscopy technology targeting tissue microstructure in the brain gray matter, which will expand our understanding of underlying mechanisms of disease progression, and may provide prognostic and confirmatory biomarkers and aid in the assessment of treatment efficacy for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Perfluorohexanoic acid (PFHxA) is a short-chain per- and polyfluoroalkyl substance (PFAS) whose presence has been reported in maternal serum and breast milk demonstrating that humans are exposed to PFHxA throughout brain development. While other PFAS that have been phased out of production, have been reported to suppress peripheral immune cells, the effects of PFHxA on the immune cells of the central nervous system, microglia, have not been investigated. This proposal will examine whether PFHxA exposure during gestation and lactation affects brain development and microglial function, providing evidence on the developmental neurotoxicity of this PFAS which is as of yet unregulated in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is an increasingly common chronic condition that has harmful effects on the liver and is the leading indication for liver transplantation in the United States. There are no FDA approved drugs for NASH treatment, however, the Farnesoid X Receptor (FXR) has proven to be beneficial in the treatment of this metabolic disorder. The goal of this proposal is to understand underlying mechanisms contributing to the function of FXR in a tissue-specific manner for the development of novel, safe, and targeted therapeutics for the treatment of NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment of cancer is complicated by intratumor variation, in which individual cells and groups of cells within a single tumor respond differently to therapeutic agents. The high degree of intratumor heterogeneity in triple-negative breast cancers confounds treatment efforts. Here we develop a linked set of experiment-computational workflows to measure, track, and predict the behavior of heterogeneous triple-negative breast cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Accurate measurement of physical activity, sedentary behavior, and sleep is necessary to support new science on behavior-related dose-response for major health conditions. We propose to develop novel methods to measure 24-hour physical behavior, as well as a procedure via which those methods can be compared to others. We aim to help the research community to converge on methods that use the devices to accurately measure physical activity type and intensity, sedentary behavior and posture, and sleep in adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Transmembrane adhesion proteins are required for converting mechanical signals into cell activity. This research develops new computational methods based on all-atom simulations in order to quantify precisely how the molecular structure and function of integrin transmembrane proteins enables the conversion of mechanical signals into cell motion. Results will identify targets for treatments of diseases of mechanotransduction, including cardiovascular diseases, fibrosis of many organs and cancer, in which cells sense and transduce altered external mechanical forces. They will also provide the basis for future design of smart materials able to respond to mechanical signals in a controlled way.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative The mesolimbic dopamine system plays a crucial role in our ability to form close bonds with loved ones, and atypical activity of this circuitry is a common feature of several neuropsychiatric diseases that feature an onset during adolescent development. Social experiences play a crucial role in scaffolding brain development, but the ways in which changing adolescent reward circuits are shaped by early social interactions to facilitate adult bonding remains unknown. I will leverage the use of the socially monogamous prairie vole system to discover the activational, functional, and transcriptional features of dopaminergic reward circuit development, furthering our understanding of the pathophysiology of diseases that involve impaired social bonding behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dental caries is an enormous health problem worldwide and there is a shift towards oral microbial community dominated by cariogenic bacterium, eg: Streptococcus mutans, in caries-active subjects. Commensal bacteria normally help to control S. mutans via bioactive products such as H2O2; however, high-sugar consumption, which is frequently found in populations with high caries rates, could inhibit the generation of H2O2 through carbohydrate catabolite repression and disrupt the homeostasis. This project will investigate if selective photoactivated semiconducting metal titanates will produce extrinsic H2O2 from O2 reduction and other reactive oxygen species (ROS), to inhibit S. mutans, while giving an advantage to commensal bacteria and thereby maintain homeostasis in dental biofilms and thus prevent dental caries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A striking characteristic of bilingual speakers is code-switching (alternating two languages within a single discourse) to meet pragmatic and/or linguistic needs. Prior research has explored the grammatical constraints and sociolinguistic aspects of code-switching independently. However, few have examined how these constrain may interact to influence differences in code-switch patterns between children with and without developmental language disorder. Therefore, the proposed research will investigate the sociolinguistic characteristics (interlocutors, language proficiency and language ability) among bilingual children with and without language disorder. The objective is to enhance the theoretical foundation and gain deeper insights into the code switching behaviors of bilingual children as they learn to navigate between two languages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Seizures are a common neurological disorder in infants occurring in some 14,000 newborns annually in the US. Early detection and treatment can result in more effective seizure control and lower rates of morbidity and mortality. Quantum Applied Science and Research (QUASAR), in collaboration with Children’s National Hospital (CNH), propose to develop an innovative Neonatal EEG MOnitor (“NEMO”) system intended as a reliable and easy-to-use EEG system that will increase availability of neonatal EEG monitoring at all hours of the day and to hospitals that typically lack this capability. This advance will lead to more neonates at risk for seizures being quickly screened and appropriately treated, which in turn is expected to shorten hospital stays and improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bladder removal surgery (radical cystectomy) and bladder-sparing chemoradiotherapy (CRT) are the two curative treatment approaches for muscle-invasive bladder cancer supported by long-term safety and efficacy data, but no molecular biomarkers are currently available to inform the choice between these approaches. We have identified a subset of ~15% of MIBCs with somatic alterations in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) gene ERCC2, and we have shown that clinically observed ERCC2 mutations are unable to perform cellular NER and are sufficient to confer cisplatin sensitivity in MIBC preclinical models. We will define the impact of NER deficiency induced by ERCC2 mutations on bladder tumor properties and on response to clinically relevant bladder-sparing CRT regimens by integrating genomic and clinical data from clinical MIBC cohorts with functional data from novel NER-proficient and NER-deficient preclinical models.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Interhospital transfer, the process of a patient being moved from one hospital to another for advanced and/or specialized care or patient preference, is occurring more frequently but the current process has many problems. These include poor communication between the doctors, poor communication between doctors and the patient and family, and inconsistent clinical practices. We will use methods from engineering and design to understand the reasons for these problems, get help from doctors, nurses, paramedics, patients, and families to create solutions, and test those solutions in two hospitals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mounting evidence correlates the dysregulation of spatial mRNA organization to an increasing number of diseases, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), fragile X syndrome (FXS), and spinal muscular atrophy (SMA). However, the regulatory mechanism and pathological consequences of spatial RNA organization have only been explored for a limited fraction of mRNAs, due to a lack of technologies that allow for tracking and manipulating the subcellular localization of endogenous mRNAs. We develop a transformative framework including several technologies: single-molecule, real-time RNA monitoring (RNA-LiveFISH), manipulation of any endogenous mRNA(s) for spatial localization on a large scale (CRISPR-TO), and related machine learning algorithms, and we will apply the framework to gain new insights into the functional roles of spatial RNA organization in axon development and guidance in primary neurons and explore the approach of modulating mRNA localization as a therapeutic strategy to treat spinal muscular atrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  We are proposing to develop an axon-specific bidirectional optical neural interface and test the system's efficacy to neuromodulate the parasympathetic nervous system by modulating heart function. We will use optogenetics and multiphoton optical excitation to simultaneously detect the neural activity and photostimulate individual axons from the exterior of the nerve i.e. an approach that is non-invasive yet has specificity. This technology has potential for major impact on the ability to treat many conditions; for example, vagal nerve stimulation in humans has been found to control epilepsy and depression, and evidence points to improvements in treatment of inflammatory bowel disease and Alzheimer's Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE This research plan addresses one of the most critical issues at the interface of the mental health and criminal justice systems for individuals living with serious mental illnesses (SMI): how to implement evidence-based practices within a complex environment in order to improve outcomes for adults with SMI. This project adapts and tests an implementation strategy to improve collaboration and coordination between specialty mental health probation officers and mental heath service providers to increase linkage to treatment. In the long-term, this research will improve fidelity of the specialty metal health probation model, define best practice standards for addressing SMI among individuals on probation, and address Goal 4, Objective 4.3 of the NIMH Strategic Plan to enhance the reach of mental health services to underserved populations (e.g., individuals in the criminal justice system).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Approximately 42%of American adults are obese, and this condition is strongly related to the development of colorectal cancer. Innovative lifestyle strategies to treat obesity and reduce colorectal cancer risk are critically needed. The proposed research will demonstrate that time-restricted eating, a type of intermittent fasting, is an effective therapy to help obese individuals reduce and control their body weight and prevent the development of colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While wound healing by regeneration is highly desirable, skin wounds in adult mice and humans most commonly repair by fibrotic scarring. We discovered that when wounds in mice are treated with immune-modulating biomaterials, they heal by regenerating new hair follicles. Here, we propose a series of bioengineering and animal studies to test the hypothesis that immune triggers within biomaterials can shift interactions between wound immune cells and fibroblasts from fibrotic toward a highly desirable regenerative response.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research is expected to increase our understanding of the role of sensory feedback on the recovery of movements post-stroke. The proposed work is likely to provide a new way to assess movement dysfunction from the sensory perspective, especially in more impaired individuals who have difficulty performing movement tasks. Findings of the proposed research may permit the future development of targeted interventions, from a novel sensory or sensory-motor perspective, to combat post-stroke movement impairments.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects an approximate 6.2 million Americans and results in more than 120,000 death per year in the United States alone. In four years, the incidence is expected to increase by 22% and by 2050 its will nearly double. The pathology is hypothesized to initiated by abnormal deposition of beta-amyloid (A13) and progresses with the abnormal phosphorylation and deposition of tau. Despite its economic and societal impact, no drug has been able to prevent or halt progression of the disease. In this study, we will identify novel treatment approaches that have the potential to provide lasting Al3 clearance and prevention of Al3 deposition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Approximately 19 million deaths were attributed to cardiovascular disease (CVD) globally in 2020, an increase of ~20% from 2010, and heart disease remains the leading cause of death for men and women in the US. Hypertension is a major modifiable risk factor for CVD, and it has been suggested that eliminating hypertension could reduce CVD mortality 30.4% in men and 38.0% in women. This proposal will increase our understanding of how blood pressure increases in females and increase awareness of the risks associated with hypertension and cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic consumption of a diet high in saturated fat causes obesity, dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, diabetes, renal dysfunction, and hypertension. The first study to show diets high in saturated fat are directly associated with cardiovascular disease was published in 1978, yet the average American continues to consume twice the daily recommended amount of saturated fat. A better understanding of the mechanisms by which a diet high in saturated fat increases blood pressure will improve treatment options for both men and women and reduce the overall cardiovascular risk burden in the United States.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE African American women are disproportionally covered by Medicaid and are at greater risk than non-Hispanic white women of losing insurance coverage after pregnancy and of poor maternal health outcomes. Dr. Steenland will train in domestic health policy, maternal health, and advanced econometric methods to prepare her to complete her research aims and for a career as an independent investigator focused on health policy solutions to reduce poor maternal health outcomes among racial/ethnic minority women. In the proposed research aims, Dr. Steenland will examine the effect of Medicaid expansion on disparities in postpartum insurance coverage nationally, and the effect of Medicaid expansion in Arkansas, the state with the largest coverage gains after Medicaid expansion, on disparities in postpartum health care use in Arkansas.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Reducing Postpartum Health Care Disparities through Increased Insurance Coverage after Childbirth

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) collectively impact approximately 24 million Americans, and cardiovascular disease is one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in this patient population. The presence of both obesity and elevated leptin have been shown to correlate with increased disease activity in SLE patients, but mechanistic contributions of these factors to autoimmune disease progression and the development of hypertension are poorly understood. This proposal will examine the pathogenic role of obesity and leptin in the development of autoimmune-associated hypertension.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammation is a hallmark of many diseases, including cancer, autoinflammatory disorders, immunodeficiencies, and neurodegeneration; thus, understanding the molecular mechanisms regulating inflammation is critical to identifying opportunities for therapeutic intervention. The signaling pathway identified in this proposal represents a completely novel mechanism by which an apoptotic caspase controls inflammation via a network of proteins with both recognized and unknown roles in inflammation. Mechanistic elucidation of this pathway will shed light on fundamental biology and enable novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Immune system activation has been linked to the development of hypertension and is also directly linked to rheumatic diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) that predominantly affect women. This proposal will explore how immune system activation during SLE impacts kidney function and leads to hypertension with a focus on understanding a specific immune cell type (neutrophils) and the powerhouse of cells (mitochondria). Examining how the immune system impacts blood pressure during this disease will not only provide new insights for women with SLE, but also will add to the overall understanding of hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Approximately 19 million deaths were attributed to cardiovascular disease (CVD) globally in 2020, an increase of ~20% from 2010, yet awareness of this is low, particularly among women in rural communities and from non- white communities. This proposal will increase understanding of the science behind how CVD impacts women and build community relationships to improve awareness in culturally diverse populations in the Southeastern United States. The proposed Leadership Administrative Core will support all aspects of this project to ensure that the goals are met.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Niemann-Pick disease type C (NPC) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease bear striking resemblances with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and has no cure. This project will investigate how an innate immune pathway drives neuropathology in the NPC disease. This project will also develop and test targeted therapies against this innate immune pathway that may be used to treat the NPC disease and possibly other neurodegenetive diseases in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE  While monoclonal antibodies inhibiting immune checkpoints (ICI) and CAR T-cell therapies are able to restore antitumor immunity and have dramatically changed the therapeutic options for many cancer patients, up to 60% of patients will experience immune-related adverse events (irAE) depending on the tumor type and ICI. The importance of predicting and managing immunotherapy-related adverse events has already been identified as a critical gap in knowledge and clinical practice. Targeting a common molecular node of integration between the various inflammatory mechanisms of irAE, we have developed a novel positron emission tomography (PET) radiopharmaceutical that provides a robust reagent for mechanism-based studies and quantitative characterization of inflammatory foci and immunotherapy-mediated irAE by PET in combination with multiplexed analysis of biologic materials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We have assembled a multi-institutional collaborative center with the aim of creating a cellular taxonomy of molecularly defined cell types in the developing human, Rhesus macaque, and marmoset brain. Our project employs technologies for automated single nucleus and spatially-resolved RNA-sequencing and single cell transposase accessible chromatin sequencing to create spatial gene expression and epigenomic developmental expression maps for human and NHP brain. We will sample 30 brain regions at four key epochs of development and register our cellular data onto MRI-based Common Coordinate Frameworks to create a unique resource that will serve as a blueprint for studies of human brain function and selective vulnerability of cell types to disease and will provide foundational data for the development of primate and in vitro models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The research plan we propose aims at a comprehensive multi-level understanding of how the brain and the body interact to respond adaptively to a potentially harsh and unforgiving environment. Among the many internal factors that are under constant homeostatic regulation, we focus on the bi-directional dialogue between the brain and the heart, since the cardiovascular system and its role in regulating oxygen delivery is one of the most critical and universal control systems within the animal kingdom. A central aspect of our approach is the generation of a complete brain and body connectome of the larval zebrafish, a map which will be the first ever generated in a vertebrate, and which will be critical in both testing the validity of many extant models, and perhaps discovering new pathways within the interconnected neural circuits that serve the changing needs of the body during behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The research plan we propose aims at a comprehensive multi-level understanding of how the brain and the body interact to respond adaptively to a potentially harsh and unforgiving environment. Among the many internal factors that are under constant homeostatic regulation, we focus on the dialogue between the brain and the heart, since the cardiovascular system and its role in regulating oxygen delivery is one of the most critical and universal control systems within the animal kingdom. Our approach aims to not only explain the core mechanisms of top down cardiac control, but also to provide first insights into what is measured at the level of the heart itself, and what is the nature of the signals that are being sent from the heart to the brain. A central aspect of our approach is the generation of a complete brain and body connectome of the larval zebrafish. This map, the first such map in any vertebrate, will be critical in both testing the validity of many extant models, and perhaps discovering new pathways within the interconnected neural circuits that serve the changing needs of the body during behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Approximately 19 million deaths were attributed to cardiovascular disease (CVD) globally in 2020, an increase of ~20% from 2010, and heart disease remains the leading cause of death for men and women in the US. The Career Enhancement Core (CEC) is designed to develop a foundation for long-term relationships among the research, medical and lay communities in GA, MS and SC to bring greater awareness to the risk of CVD in women and the consideration of SABV in CVD research. This will be accomplished through education, mentorship, strategic partnerships, and training of community-engaged researchers to increase research and awareness in at-risk communities throughout the Southeast.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative BioSensics' newly developed sensor-based technology, called StrokeWearTM, consists of a proprietary software and bilateral wrist-worn sensors that continuously monitor upper extremity movements performed by patients in the home setting and deliver vibratory stimuli to remind patients to use their stroke-affected arm. The goal of the system is to enable patients to achieve levels of upper extremity use during daily activities in the home that will enhance motor recovery and improve function. In this study, we will build upon StrokeWearTM by improving and testing enhanced sensor design, new components to the system for patient monitoring, goal setting, feedback, motivation, and behavior change, and new platforms to enhance engagement of patients with the system.

PHR: Narrative: Epilepsy is characterized by recurrent seizures and is frequently resistant to antiepileptic drugs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The research plan we propose aims at a comprehensive multi-level understanding of how the brain and the body interact to respond adaptively to a potentially harsh and unforgiving environment. Among the many internal factors that are under constant homeostatic regulation, we focus on the bi-directional dialogue between the brain and the heart, since the cardiovascular system and its role in regulating oxygen delivery is one of the most critical and universal control systems within the animal kingdom. A central aspect of our approach is the generation of a complete brain and body connectome of the larval zebrafish, a map which will be the first ever generated in a vertebrate, and which will be critical in both testing the validity of many extant models, and perhaps discovering new pathways within the interconnected neural circuits that serve the changing needs of the body during behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Halide-containing nucleosides and nucleotides represent an important family of synthetic drugs for anticancer and antiviral treatments, thus it is essential to develop novel and effective synthetic strategies to expand halogenated nucleoside/nucleotide compound library for drug discovery. Radical halogenation via carbon- hydrogen bond activation catalyzed by iron and 2-oxoglutarate (Fe/2OG) dependent enzymes represents an attractive strategy to install carbon-halide bonds in a regio- and stereo-specific fashion. In this projects, two newly discovered Fe/2OG enzymes that catalyze radical halogenation to generate halide-containing nucleotide natural products and amino acids will be mechanistically investigated, the obtained mechanistic insights will be further deployed to develop these enzymes into biosynthetic platform to access new halide-containing nucleotide/nucelosides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Gene clusters are widespread in genomes but mechanistic understanding of their within-cluster chromatin looping and among-cluster crosstalk is unclear. This study aims to illustrate a stepwise chromatin-protein cas- cade that spatially organizes complex gene clusters from a two-dimensional DNA sequence to a three-dimen- sional subnuclear structure.

PHR: The goal of the Cleveland Open Source Modular Implant Innovators Community (COSMIIC) is to establish an implanted electrical stimulation system that can be used for treatment of diseases, particularly in the peripheral nerves. All of the plans and instructions necessary to create this implanted system will be made available freely to the research community so that everyone can benefit. We hope that this will quickly advance the treatment of many diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child psychotic-like experiences (PLEs) are common disturbances of perception and ideation that occur in childhood and that (if they become persistent) may be risk factors for poor mental health in adolescence and beyond. As risk factors that predict persistent PLEs have not been reliably identified, the goal of this study is to use deep learning combined with explainable artificial intelligence to identify features from multimodal data in the Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development Study dataset that predict future levels of PLE distress, and then use these features to model PLE trajectories using structured equation modeling. The results of this study will help develop novel, personalized ways to prevent persistent PLEs from developing and ultimately improve mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In this project, we will create a reference atlas containing microstructure growth curves of different brain regions across the lifespan, which enables us to assess neurobiological variability at the individual level. This will create an opportunity to advance clinical translation, where individual neurobiological signatures can be used to predict clinical outcomes. We will showcase the value of this approach by showing the clinical relevance of microstructure variations in early psychosis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UAB Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center (CF Center), supported by the NIH P30, is dedicated to advancing high-impact, multidisciplinary research that heightens the field’s understanding of CF disease mechanisms and accelerates the development of treatments for availability to CF patients. Success toward this goal is made possible by the Center’s well-funded Research Base, robust and cutting-edge Biomedical Research Core resources and services, effective Administrative Core offerings, and successful Pilot & Feasibility and Enrichment Programs, in addition its strong commitment from the University and its role as a valuable local, national, and international clinical hub. Progress is measured by the output of innovative contributions, scientific discovery, and clinical translation designed to improve the lives of patients with the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Our understanding of primate evolution was transformed by the sequencing and assembly of the human  reference genome which identified the content and context of genes shared amongst the many different taxa in  the primate lineage. Here we propose to construct complete reference genomes from 50 diverse primate species  spanning 75 million years of evolution. This resource will greatly enhance the potential for research that will  advance our understanding of primate evolutionary history, population genomics, infectious disease, human  origins, and primate biodiversity and conservation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Our movements are shaped by sensory information, and though much progress has been made in understanding how proprioceptors (muscle sensory neurons) shape motor function, much less is known about how touch receptors (skin sensory neurons) influence motor pathways. To generate a complete picture of how sensory information affects motor actions, this project incorporates a multidisciplinary approach to provide a functional roadmap of how skin touch receptors interact with spinal cord motor centers to shape movement. By understanding the final path for movement organization (i.e., the spinal cord) our research lays the critical foundation for novel ways to modulate spinal circuits for improving motor function affected by disease or injury.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative For the significant fraction of metastatic breast cancer patients that are yet unable to realize the unparalleled benefits of cancer immunotherapy, focused ultrasound (FUS) is poised to play a transformative role - owing to its diverse capacity for destroying solid tumor tissue, enhancing drug delivery and promoting anti-tumor immune response. The goal of this proposal is to design and deploy rational combinations of FUS and immunotherapy in primary and disseminated breast cancers (with special emphasis on CAR T cell therapy), as well as to develop non-invasive tools for monitoring and individualizing these combinations through the use of innovative approaches in molecular imaging, liquid biopsy and radiogenomics. The highly translational structure of this proposal offers the potential for quantum improvements in metastatic breast cancer prognosis and therapy and meanwhile ushers FUS into the burgeoning era of precision immuno-oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Cholesterol crystals (CC), which are formed by increased lipid levels, cause tissue damage and are recognized by the immune system as foreign bodies because of their shape, firmness and inability to be dissolved. In this study, we will test whether retinal CC can cause retina damage leading to the development of diabetic retinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL – PROJECT NARRATIVE The presence of major cancer health inequities in Chicago is well-documented. The Chicago Cancer Health Equity Collaborative (ChicagoCHEC), a comprehensive cancer research partnership between the Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center of Northwestern University, the University of Illinois at Chicago, and Northeastern Illinois University, builds upon its productive first U54 award to continue strengthening collaborative infrastructure and implementing innovative cancer research, education, and outreach programs aimed at eliminating Chicago’s deeply-engrained cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project examines how school-age blind children acquire word meanings, and whether the trajectory of vocabulary development in blind children is altered or delayed relative to that in typically sighted children. Findings from this research have the potential to improve instructional approaches and language and literacy interventions for blind children.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Healthcare organizations can improve patient safety by using their electronic health record data to identify what systems and process changes can prevent harm to patients. We will implement methods to help organizations electronically identify patients who may have experienced errors and delays in diagnosis and understand why they occurred. Our center will create new knowledge, tools, and strategies that health care organizations can use for learning how to prevent and reduce harm from diagnostic error.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The UC Davis Comparative Oncology T32 program will provide an outstanding environment for biomedical research training. The goal is to train 1) veterinarian- and physician-scientists and 2) graduate students pursuing dual DVM-PhD degrees to integrate the study of companion animals, which have naturally occurring cancers, with human cancer biology and therapy (comparative oncology). This will create a new generation of scientists engaged in basic and translational cancer research that advances the health of people and animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Experiencing, producing, and performing music can help the symptoms of psychotic illness but we do not know why. The predictive processing framework for brain and mind function and dysfunction helps us understand why people with psychosis perceive and believe unusual things about themselves, other people, and the world. Using tasks devised through the framework and a group musical intervention we aim to learn how and for whom music might be helpful so that, in future, we can deliver music more effectively to the people who will benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Pediatric asthma is a heterogeneous disease, with different etiologies, triggers, clinical manifestations, severities, and treatment responses. Identifying groups of children with asthma by those specific characteristics (i.e., asthma subtypes) can improve asthma management, including primary care and emergency treatment. This project applies novel privacy-preserving machine learning tools to a large (~ 20 million patients) real-world data source to identify pediatric asthma subtypes and their progression over time (i.e., progression subtypes), with the goal of improving care and outcomes for the millions of children with asthma in the United States.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The complexity and breadth of its host-cell remodeling machinery make the malaria-causing parasite P. falciparum a rich and exciting system for the study of host-pathogen interactions. However, many of the molecular mechanisms underlying this parasite's ability to hijack human red blood cells remain enigmatic, as much of the P. falciparum proteome has proven recalcitrant to structural and biochemical characterization using traditional recombinant approaches. The proposed research will build upon our previous studies in structural microbiology of the malaria parasite and leverage recent advances in cryoelectron microscopy to directly visualize how protein complexes mediate host-pathogen interactions in malaria parasite-infected red blood cells, providing insight into malaria pathogenesis and informing structure-guided design of novel anti-malarial therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  PRSS1 mutations cause human hereditary pancreatitis with high risk of developing to pancreatic cancer. We developed a novel mouse model by expressing a mutant human PRSS1 to study the mechanisms of pancreatic cancer tumorigenesis. We expect these studies will significantly improve our understanding of this disease and provide new insights on interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research will use molecular simulations to reveal new rational design principles of light-regulated drugs with minimized side effects in chemotherapy. Also, it will elucidate the electron transfer mechanism in proteins associated with circadian rhythm, magnet field sensing, and energy metabolism. The microscopic understanding of these biochemical reactions from a quantum perspective will be foundational for biomedical research in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polygenic risk scores (PRS) use genetic data to predict the likelihood or (risk score) that a person will develop a specific disease/trait. We will to recruit 2,500 patient from across the CHOP network, about 75% of whom will be of African ancestry, and calculate and return PRSs for 20 diseases/traits to all. Target diseases include asthma, autoimmune disease, inflammatory bowel disease, lipid levels, and diabetes, and we will provide patients and provide with extensive education and clinical supports.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal seeks to create magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-visible devices for minimally invasive interventional procedures that will help diagnose diseases in the heart wall called cardiomyopathies and treat heart disease to decrease the likelihood of developing heart failure. Extensive testing of an MRI-compatible endomyocardial biopsy device, an MRI-compatible injection catheter, and MRI-compatible pigtail catheter will be performed on the benchtop and in dogs as a model for both pediatric and adult patients. In addition, we will test these devices using a new paradigm for device development in cardiovascular disease by studying spontaneously occurring non-ischemic cardiomyopathies in client-owned dogs, such as Irish Wolfhounds, to provide a more realistic model for translation to human clinical trials using the same whole body MRIs that are also used for patient studies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The current study will systematically disentangle the impact of light exposure from screens from the impact of arousing media content on children’s sleep regulation as well as next-day emotion regulation and executive functioning. Using innovations in the objective assessment of tablet use, we will control for differences in children’s objectively assessed tablet use history. Our findings will have implications that will inform screen media use guidelines for school-age children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The purpose of this renewal application is to continue and refocus the work of the Health Delivery Systems Center for Diabetes Translational Research (HDS-CDTR) (P30 DK092924), renamed the Diabetes Research for Equity through Advanced Multilevel Science Center for Diabetes Translational Research (DREAMS- CDTR), on reducing diabetes related health disparities and improving health equity. Refocused on northern California and its Central Valley, the DREAMS-CDTR is a collaborative partnership between the Kaiser Permanente Northern California’s Division of Research and the University of California at San Francisco, Merced and Davis. This Center leverages expertise in two Core Translational Research areas of health equity and methods and data integration and from a national diabetes policy resources core to accelerate the translation of diabetes research into changes in healthcare delivery, public health practice, and policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early treatment of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can improve long-term outcomes, but only when at-risk children are identified promptly and accurately. Early risk factors common to both conditions (e.g. premature birth, perinatal complications) are collected during routine care and are accessible in the electronic health record (EHR), but have not been used at scale to stratify risk or improve early screening. The proposed study will develop improved methods and machine learning models for predicting ASD and ADHD based on EHR data available early in child development, then take critical steps toward clinical use by prospectively evaluating these models, deploying them in the Duke University Health System EHR, and working with providers to develop and evaluate a comprehensive ASD and ADHD risk prediction dashboard to inform clinical decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Adolescents who begin alcohol use early in life and continue drinking at high levels during adolescence put themselves at risk for alcohol-related effects on brain and behavior. This project will investigate the contribution of the brain “social” neuropeptide oxytocin system to social anxiety induced by adolescent alcohol exposure and will determine mechanisms underlying the anti-anxiety effects of oxytocin system activation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relapsed and refractory T-cell lymphomas (TCL) are associated with poor clinical outcomes. However, we have identified a multikinase inhibitor that is selective for multiple kinases that have important cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous roles in the T-cell lymphomas. Therefore, we will conduct an investigator-initiated, multicenter, phase II study with this agent in multiple cohorts of relapsed/refractory T-cell lymphomas.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to address the urgent need for effective, scalable adult literacy interventions by integrating breakthroughs in two separate fields: 1) the brain network science of resilience to reading disorders and 2) high-definition non-invasive brain network stimulation. This study will first establish the efficacy of a novel, non-invasive stimulation protocol on reading behavior and brain metrics; then will determine how stimulation-induced effects interact with baseline reading comprehension ability; and lastly, will identify whether stimulation-induced effects are more clinically-beneficial than canonical behavioral interventions. Results may foundationally change how we treat low adult literacy, and have the potential for wider reaching impacts on non-invasive stimulation protocols for other clinical disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of our LAUNCH Program is to provide research training to talented trainees who are poised to become the future leaders of scientific inquiry in nephrology, urology, and hematology. Our proposed LAUNCH Program will aim to train 22 trainees annually and prepare these pre- and post-doctoral individuals to become well-rounded scientists equipped with the skillsets they need to thrive in successful research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The vast majority of adults with obesity do not enroll in comprehensive evidence-based behavioral weight loss programs and as a result are less likely to achieve clinically meaningful weight loss. This study will test the effects of a brief, individually tailored intervention aiming to increase initiation of comprehensive behavioral weight loss treatment on weight. If the intervention is effective, it could be disseminated within primary care practices to increase the number of adults with obesity who achieve clinically meaningful weight loss.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ECHO Pregnancy Cohort will improve the health of children for generations to come by identifying, in a diverse population, how environmental exposures involving pregnant individuals and their conceiving partners, before and during pregnancy, impact the health of their children from birth to the transition to adulthood. The ECHO Ohio Cohort Site will specialize in evaluating lifestyle exposures, in a diverse group of pregnant individuals and conceiving partners from preconception through the perinatal period, and their relationship to perinatal and child health outcomes. In addition to actively contributing to all areas of ECHO data collection and providing leadership for the program, we propose to focus on how cardiovascular health, including dysglycemia, during pregnancy are associated with an infant’s health at birth and a child’s neurodevelopment from birth to early adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Patient Engagement Research Lab and J.C. Walter Jr. Transplant Center at Houston Methodist will partner with Saint Louis University, the Cooperman Barnabas Transplant Center, the National Kidney Foundation, and the Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients’ Living Donor Collective initiative to improve living donor care and increase the number of potential living donors proceeding to actual donation. A team of scientists, ethicists, patient engagement and education specialists, clinicians, and living donors will conduct a multi-step study to identify clinical factors, social determinants of health, and other modifiable factors that contribute to evaluation discontinuation, especially for potential donors from underserved communities; develop and validate a living donor drop-out risk prediction index (LD-DROP) to identify which individuals would benefit from greater support; conduct community-engaged research to better understand how to support potential living donors at high-risk for drop-out; and pilot a positive donor experience intervention. This project will not only establish critical metrics and resources to better support and tailor the potential transplant donor experience, but also help decrease the kidney shortage by improving living donor support for everyone, particularly communities of color.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary goal of the Deep South KUH Premier Research and Inter-disciplinary Mentored Education (PRIME) program is to establish a fully integrated, interdisciplinary network of pre- and post-doctoral trainees in KUH research across the Deep South. We will do so by bringing together the unique research and training assets of Augusta University, Tulane University and the University of Alabama at Birmingham to create a unified KUH training ecosystem. The overall intent will be to better prepare translational scientists and clinician- scientists to become the future drivers of scientific breakthroughs in KUH research in our region and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project uses complementary psychophysical and electrophysiological approaches to evaluate the biological processes that underlie visually guided foraging behavior and will have two public health outcomes. First, it will inform the development of effective interventions for humans with diseases that impair navigation and object interaction while leaving visual processing intact. Second, it will suggest behavioral metrics and educational tools based on explicitly guiding visual attention for early detection of these disorders and to improve navigational decisions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obstetric Life SupportTM (OBLSTM) is a validated simulation curriculum to train prehospital and hospital-based health care workers on preventing, recognizing, and managing maternal medical emergencies. This project will identify barriers and facilitators to implementation of OBLSTM in rural and low-resource settings, and adapt and test the intervention for these contexts. Findings will be used to promote national scale-up of this important health care innovation with the goal of improving patient safety and reducing inequities in maternal mortality and severe maternal morbidity.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Adaptation of an Evidence-Based Curriculum to Teach the Prevention, Evaluation and Treatment of Maternal Medical Emergencies for Pre-hospital & Hospital Healthcare Workers in Rural Context

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While studies confirm that rapid whole genome sequencing accelerates diagnoses and life-saving therapies in critically ill newborns, its adoption in clinical setting is lagging. We propose a dissemination and implementation science project to decrease healthcare inequities and improve adoption of genome sequencing in Level 4 (tertiary, metropolitan, higher resourced) and Level 3 (non-tertiary, rural, lower resourced) neonatal intensive care units.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project narrative It is imperative to train researchers in clinical, scientific and technological areas to advance the fields of Kidney, Urology and Hematology (KUH) towards bringing better understanding and management to KUH conditions and diseases. This program in North Carolina combines expertise and novel concepts in Training, Research, Innovation, and Outreach to form the NC KUH TRIO Program, bringing together six institutions across the state; 3 academic medical centers and 3 historically black universities that have strong science, technology, and engineering programs. TRIO will support pre- and post-doctoral trainees, providing them with innovative research tools and a professional development foundation to launch KUH research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major barrier to treatment for maternal opioid use disorder (OUD) is the buprenorphine induction process, which requires moderate withdrawal symptoms and is a critical timepoint of treatment dropout. A bridge induction method using a transdermal buprenorphine patch may be an efficacious method to minimize withdrawal symptoms and increase induction success. We propose a prospective, mixed-methods study at two OUD- specific prenatal clinics to evaluate the feasibility of conducting a randomized controlled trial comparing buprenorphine transdermal bridge induction versus standard sublingual induction in pregnant patients with OUD.

PHR: Prescription and non-prescription medications, which include vitamins, herbal preparations, or, non-traditional forms of medicines, can very rarely cause significant liver injury. Because these events are so rare, the NIH has established a network of investigators to identify these rare causes of liver injury so that a shared database can be used for future studies. The USC-UCLA Drug-Induced Liver Injury Clinical Center desires to continue to work with this established network to better understand causes of liver injury due to these agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microphthalmia, anophthalmia and coloboma (MAC) are eye defects that can be caused by damaging sequence variants in the genes in the retinoic acid synthesis pathway and by vitamin A deficiency. In this proposal, we will examine patients with MAC, perform genome sequencing and measure vitamin A levels to examine the importance of genotypic and environmental factors relating to the retinoic acid pathway in the severity of MAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Pa) cause severe infections in patients with burns, severe wounds, pneumonia, or undergoing nosocomial procedures; however most Pa strains are resistant to many antibiotics limiting the treatment options. Vaccination is perhaps the greatest health advancement of our lifetime, and our vaccine to prevent Pa – regardless of initial injury or Pa strain – will positively impact all of us since as we age we all have a greater risk of a potential Pa infection. Our vaccine is aimed at preventing these infections as well.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of this prospective, randomized, double blind, controlled trial is to determine if the early initiation of bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP) is effective and safe in pediatric patients presenting to a pediatric emergency department with acute moderate to severe asthma exacerbations who fail first line therapy. BPAP is a form of non-invasive positive pressure ventilation that may stent open airways, improve mucous clearance, recruit alveoli, and increase responsiveness to continuous beta-agonist therapy in the small distal airways. Given the large burden acute asthma exacerbations places upon the healthcare system, the results of the proposed study are of great public health importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Each year, millions of patients with acute respiratory failure or sepsis present to U.S. emergency departments at high risk for death but without requirements for life support. Admission of these patients to intensive care units (ICUs) or hospital wards varies considerably with hospital capacity strain, and significantly impacts patient outcomes. Using detailed electronic health record data, instrumental variable and mediation analyses, and machine learning, we will identify the subgroups, care processes, and complications of care that account for these triage-related outcomes, thereby promoting personalized triage and better outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Telomere maintenance by telomerase is critical for genome integrity, regulation of cellular lifespan, and tumor suppression. Here we focus on the cell biology of telomerase and investigate the timing, dynamics, and spatial coordination of telomere extension in the crowded nucleus of cancer cells. Our study will have profound implications for the development of strategies to block telomere maintenance and design better cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Significant racial disparities in organ donation impact health outcomes for patients in need of a transplant. Organizations that are best suited to engage local communities to increase awareness and support for organ donation often lack a research and data infrastructure to monitor organ donation disparities and guide continuous improvement. A Learning Health System model can provide equity-focused data resources to support local interventions to reduce organ donation disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cloud computing promises to scale up storage, analysis and sharing of health data needed to accelerate research in genomics and precision medicine but methods for evaluating how responsible access to and sharing of genomic data is governed in the cloud remain severely underdeveloped. The proposed K01 aims to develop, validate, and implement a reliable tool in partnership with global stakeholders to assess genomic data stewardship across publicly funded repositories worldwide. Findings from this project will expand current strategies for ensuring stewardship systems reinforce community values and proposes a transparent model for reporting stewardship impact among cloud-native repositories going forward.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our goal is to develop the next generation of T cell therapies for adult solid tumors. Recent advances in CRISPR- Cas9 technology allow investigators to design better and safer T cell products for adoptive cell therapy. An outstanding team of investigators has been assembled to develop a new TCR-T cell therapy directed to mutant KRAS that overcomes the critical challenges posed by the tumor microenvironment and T cell exhaustion. Laboratory correlatives using state-of-the art single cell technologies will be employed to investigate mechanisms of response and resistance after treatment. In this personalized medicine-based strategy, we estimate that 5,000 new adult cancer patients in the US per year will be eligible for this cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Extracellular matrix stiffness and viscoelasticity regulates cell proliferation in 3D microenvironments through mechanotransduction, but the mechanisms mediating these effects remain largely unclear. Here we will combine biophysical approaches with genome-wide analyses and CRISPR screens to determine the mechanisms mediating the impact of matrix stiffness and viscoelasticity on cell proliferation. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of human disability and disease.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Neuroscientists commonly use viral vectors as tools to evaluate how diverse brain cell types function and interconnect in animals and in models of neurological, neurodevelopmental, and neurodegenerative disorders. Moreover, viral vectors are increasingly being used to shuttle replacement genes and other molecules into brain cells to treat brain disorders. The BRAIN Viral Vector Service and Distribution Core will serve as a national resource for the distribution of high- quality viral vectors tailored specifically to neuroscientists working on topics relevant to the BRAIN Initiative and enable neuroscientists to pioneer new viral vector-based treatments for brain disorders.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative The primary goal of this cooperative agreement proposal is to continue the comprehensive food safety partnership between the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Western Center for Food Safety (WCFS) at UC Davis. Similar to the past 15 years, WCFS will partner with FDA on conducting joint collaborative research projects, provide extension and technical assistance to agricultural communities, and assist FDA in implementing the Food Safety Modernization Act standards associated with the produce safety and preventive controls regulation. As a result of these efforts, the risk of foodborne microbial contamination of produce for the U.S. consumer will be reduced, thereby improving public health and the safety of the nation's food supply.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Prostate cancer is the most common serious cancer diagnosed in men in the United States, and a leading cause of cancer mortality. This proposal is focused on understanding whether prostate cancer emerges from inflamed regions of the prostate, and in the process, gains the ability to evade the immune system. Through this research we will identify new ways to prevent and intercept the development of aggressive prostate cancer.

PHR: Narrative The workforce in data science and STEM continues to lack representation by key groups: women, minorities, and those from rural and lower socio-economic backgrounds. This novel, experiential problem-based learning approach uses population-based Big Data to engage diverse middle school students to apply real data to solve real community health problems. The goal of the Data Detectives SEPA program is to promote greater diversity in the future science and STEM workforce through an informal science education curriculum focused on data sciences and application to community health issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is focused on longitudinal change in muscle mass and how it relates to impaired insulin-glucose homeostasis, diabetes, and adverse health outcomes (functional limitation, falls, and fractures) in a diverse cohort of older women (56% from racial/ethnic minority groups). The results will provide insight into mechanisms underlying sarcopenia and diabetes/pre-diabetes that will enhance our ability to develop geroprotective or gerotherapeutic interventions in the future. The novel remote measurement approach for assessment of muscle mass via the D3-creatine (D3Cr) dilution method has potential to revolutionize screening for sarcopenia in clinical settings and public health research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Keratoconus (KC) disease is the degeneration of the corneal stroma, which causes the cornea to slowly change from its’ normal curved shape to a more conical shape, leading to vision distortion. Unfortunately, to-date, the etiology of the disease is unknown, and in most cases, patients require some kind of surgical intervention. The proposed studies have potential to revolutionize the field and establish new diagnostic and treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative This project will identify precision treatment regimens for individuals with schizophrenia that are effective for many of its clinical manifestations and associated comorbidities through novel machine learning applications to large observational datasets including electronic health records and claims data previously prohibitively complex to test with clinical trials. These treatment regimens provided to individuals clustered by common characteristics in the datasets, and whose efficacy is validated in comparative effectiveness studies, will define personalized treatment rules for clinicians to use when treating individuals with schizophrenia. These rules will be further tested to determine whether they help clinicians identify effective treatments early in the illness trajectory leading to better outcomes and will enhance existing evidence-based practices with this new person- centered approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding whether cardiovascular devices are safe and effective for different groups of patients is an important public health and clinical concern. The overall goal of this proposal is to evaluate how the large amounts of data collected each day in the routine course of clinical care can best be used to study commonly used devices to treat serious heart conditions. The study will use state-of-the-science approaches for data analysis to examine whether several high-risk cardiovascular devices are being used safely and effectively in the United States today, including among patient subpopulations that are rarely included in clinical trials. The results of this research will determine how ubiquitous data collected by registries, health systems and payers, and advanced causal inference methods, can best be combined to improve our present and future understanding of new medical devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of the proposed research project is to determine how the HDL receptor SR-BI in adipocytes regulates the process by which high-fat diet feeding induces lipid accumulation in adipose tissue. We anticipate that the new knowledge gained will deepen our understanding of adipocyte biology through investigation of a novel, previously unappreciated role of HDL- cholesterol and its receptor SR-BI. Considering the staggering impact of obesity on metabolic and cardiovascular diseases, the goal of the research project is in line with the objectives of the National Institute of Health to address these disorders through medical research.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this application is to support Dr. Singer's efforts and career development as a mentor to early career researchers through both individualized training and a cohort focused training program. She will develop the diabetes and obesity focused investigator pipeline with directed mentoring in her laboratory-based research focusing on sex differences in meta-inflammation and studies of meta-inflammatory monocytes in adolescent insulin resistance. The impact of this mentoring plan is broadened by bringing focused training on diversity, equity and inclusion, leadership and career development, and peer mentorship to cohorts of graduate and post-doctoral trainees in diabetes, obesity and metabolism research to build networks that support future leaders in the field.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal aims to determine the appropriate factors to scale the modified-release tablet formulation for additional strengths, and to identify the critical quality attributes and formulation design spaces for oral modified-release tablets with different formulation design strategies. Filling these knowledge gaps will facilitate the development of complex generic oral modified-release tablets. This will ultimately help enhance the public access to high quality and cost-effective complex oral modified-release drug products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic alcohol consumption is linked with an increased risk of breast cancer development and progression in women. We have found that ethanol administration causes changes in the phosphorylation status of StarD10, an essential lipid transporter, and it is associated with altered cell growth and malignancy. Our proposal aims to investigate how phospho StarD10 modifications under alcohol abuse can be controlled and may provide a therapeutic target for alcohol-induce breast cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on investigating a specific mechanism that may contribute to increased seizure sensitivity in eclampsia, a condition in which pregnant women have novel spontaneous seizures. By identifying whether the endocannabinoid system is disrupted in our preclinical model of eclampsia, there is potential for development of novel therapeutic targets for reducing seizure severity in pregnant women and women with preeclampsia/eclampsia. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed work takes a multidisciplinary approach to studying the retrosplenial cortex and the subiculum, both of  which are important for memory. The retrosplenial cortex is one of the first areas to be affected by Alzheimer’s  disease, and topological disorientation is one of the first symptoms. Greater knowledge of retrosplenial cortex and  subiculum function will help determine earlier identification of those at risk for these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal describes a comprehensive approach to systemically deliver small molecule immunomodulators for improving the therapeutic index of combination cancer immunotherapy. The key objective is to develop these therapies using safe prodrug linkers, precise sizes and dosing schedules tuned to circumvent tolerance, which will improve the ability of these drugs to induce a potent and selective immune response. This work will focus formulation design efforts and dosing schemes to advance anti-cancer immunotherapy platforms into the clinic sooner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because obstructive sleep apnea is a disorder of repeated upper airway obstruction during sleep that is associated with substantial cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, daytime somnolence, and decreased quality of life and because available treatments have important limitations. For patients who do not tolerate positive airway pressure therapy, alternative treatment options include surgery, which often improves but may not eliminate obstructive sleep apnea; studies suggest that two reasons for limited surgery outcomes are an abnormal control of breathing (elevated loop gain) and increased tendency to awaken from sleep (decreased arousal threshold). Our strategy is to understand the mechanisms explaining surgery success/failure as well as results of increasing loop gain with acetazolamide and raising arousal threshold with eszopiclone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Body symmetry is crucial for physiological posture and function. A prominent example of  developmental failure in symmetry maintenance is fetal hemivertebrae, a rare congenital malformation  that affects 5-10 in 10,000 births, resulting in spinal deformation such as scoliosis. This project will  contribute to understanding the developmental origin of such body symmetry/asymmetry issues, and  this improved understanding could lead, at term, to new medical treatments or preventive measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Dominant-negative mutations in the membrane transport gene SLC4A11 cause a progressive vision loss called Fuchs Corneal Endothelial Dystrophy (FECD). We have introduced such a mutation into a transgenic mouse with the goal of understanding how genetic and extrinsic factors combine to influence the progression of the disease and why these mutations are dominant. This mouse model, the first genetic model of late- onset FECD, will be a useful tool for developing and testing novel therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative Systematic risk assessment in primary care populations is critical to identifying those at increased risk of disease and initiating appropriate preventive care. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Achieving optimal bone accrual and strength in adolescence reduces risk of fractures and osteoporosis throughout life. Bone health may be affected by exposure to endocrine disrupting chemicals commonly found in consumer products. We will investigate the impact of these chemicals on bone strength and fractures in adolescence with the aim of identifying new ways to optimize lifelong bone health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Polyether natural products hold tremendous therapeutic potential as they possess antibacterial, antifungal, immunosuppressive, and antiproliferative activities. Our work will greatly enhance our understanding of how living organisms synthesize these important molecules. It is essential that we comprehend how nature produces polyethers because it will enable rational engineering of biosynthetic enzymes and biosynthesis pathways for production of novel polyethers for drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bowel resection leads to Short Bowel Syndrome (SBS), a devastating condition resulting from inadequate remaining intestines to sustain nutritional needs though enteral feeding, and thus worldwide, tens of thousands of such patients require intravenous nutrition support via a process called Total Parenteral Nutrition, many with lifelong dependence. However, SBS patients suffer from side effects of potentially fatal liver and gut injury despite this lifesaving therapy. We have published novel findings of disrupted gut derived signals as a driver for injury in SBS and this project, using our highly translatable, novel ambulatory SBS piglet model, closely recapitulating human SBS, proposes to critically understand the altered gut signaling and test if its restoration in SBS would mitigate injury and advance our scientific knowledge with insights into mechanistic pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Corneal scarring is a major cause of blindness in the world today but its epidemiology is proven to be very complicated and dependent on a variety of factors, including trauma, infections, and inflammation. Currently, and for the last four decades, the only available treatment for corneal scarring is corneal transplantation; however, this therapy has significant side effects and concerns. Through our studies, we have shown that PIP can blunt fibrosis both in vitro and in vivo, and therefore, we propose to extend, modify, and optimize our findings in order to develop a novel therapeutic agent that can help ameliorate corneal scarring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Renal gene therapy for monogenic diseases such as cystinuria would allow for new therapeutic options for previously difficult to treat conditions with significant morbidity and mortality. The barriers to renal gene therapy could be overcome with targeted delivery to proximal tubules using adeno-associated viruses (AAV) and stable integration of transgenes using transposons. Therefore, restoration of the pathogenically deficient cystine transporter using AAV delivery and transposon integration could prevent the stone-forming phenotype of cystinuria and provide new therapeutic opportunities for other monogenic renal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a highly aggressive cancer that is associated with dysregulated tumor and whole-body metabolism that impacts therapy and quality of life. An opportunity for better exploiting metabolic vulnerabilities in PDAC for cancer treatment is to systematically examine how dietary interventions impact PDAC progression, therapy responses, and survival. This proposed research will elucidate the metabolic mechanisms underlying potential synergies between dietary factors and standard-of-care or emerging PDAC therapies in an effort to provide scientific evidence that can benefit patients with guidance on how to best incorporate diet and nutrition into PDAC treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Neonatal hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) occurs in 3-4 per 1,000 live births in the USA and may cause grave consequences including cerebral palsy, epilepsy, and cognitive impairment, but the outcome prognostication and early detection of brain damage in these neonates remain challenges. In this project, we will use advanced imaging technology and biochemical methods to test whether the cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen (CMRO2) can serve as a bedside biomarker for HIE brain damage. Outcomes of this project will also shed insights into the mechanisms of therapeutic hypothermia and suggest novel treatments of HIE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Unstructured domains of a family of RNA-binding proteins form aggregates implicated in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (also known as ALS or Lou Gehrig’s Disease) and make up cancer-causing domains in forms of leukemia and sarcoma. Determining the structural details of the RNA-binding protein Fused in Sarcoma and its assemblies is the first step to finding new therapies to prevent these difficult-to-treat diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a common, often fatal lung condition for which there are few effective treatments. Use of a mechanical ventilator is critical for survival; however, the ventilator may also cause lung damage and increase risk of death in patients with ARDS. This research evaluates a new approach to mechanical ventilation using the Driving Pressure as a target for lung-protective ventilation, with the ultimate goal of minimizing lung damage and improving survival for ARDS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Clear cell ovarian cancer is a rare and lethal malignancy with limited treatment options. Molecularly it is similar to much more frequent clear cell renal carcinomas, of which around 25% respond to immunotherapy. We will take a systems biology approach to identify similarities in the ovarian and renal clear cell cancer tumor environments, and how cellular crosstalk in these environments drives therapy response.
